title: Company History-SBD
body:
SportsBusiness Daily is the leading daily trade publication on the business of sports. Since 1994, SportsBusiness Daily has been a vital information service, providing decision-makers in the sports industry with comprehensive, real-time business news each business morning.

Monday through Friday, SportsBusiness Daily summarizes industry news reported by over 500 media outlets in the United States, Canada, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia and South America – as well as relevant original features by our experienced editorial staff. Our clients receive essential information while it is still timely, helping them make more informed business decisions.

In addition to being real-time, SportsBusiness Daily is comprehensive. We help our clients focus on the latest news by taking a global perspective and prioritizing such important sports business issues as:


• Sponsorships & Endorsements • Marketing & Advertising
• Sports Media • Collegiate Sports
• Labor & Management Relations • League & Governing Bodies
• Licensing & Merchandising • Olympics
• Sports on the Web • Executive Transactions
• Facilities & Venues • Events & Attractions
• Sports Finance • Sports Business Research

In prioritizing the day's most important news, SportsBusiness Daily offers readers both the substance and "the spin" of how the news "is playing." In addition, SportsBusiness Daily provides timely original features that go beyond the headlines and analyze the latest trends impacting the billion-dollar sports enterprise. Original features from SportsBusiness Daily have been cited by such media outlets as the N.Y. Times, Washington Post, USA Today, N.Y. Daily News, Atlanta Constitution, Houston Chronicle, L.A. Times, Chicago Tribune, Sports Illustrated, ESPN, Fox Sports Net, and other major media entities.

SportsBusiness Daily is the source for busy executives in keeping up with the industry personalities and newsmakers shaping today's global sports business. It is a "must read" for the top decision-makers, keeping them ahead of the game. This is evident by our extraordinary subscription renewal rate of more than 80% over the past six years. See what some of today's top sports executives are saying about SportsBusiness Daily.

Register now for a free trial to SportsBusiness Daily.

SportsBusiness Daily is a publication of Street & Smith's Sports Group.

title: SBO History
body:
SPORTSBIZONLINE.COM

 SportsBizOnline.com is presented by Street & Smith's Sports Group and is a joint production of Street & Smith's SportsBusiness Journal and The Sports Business Daily, the two leading trade publications on the business of sports. Drawing on the expertise of these respected publications, SportsBizOnline.com provides real-time industry news on the business of sports, and serves as a vital research source for the industry professionals and sports enthusiasts.

title: Editorial Mission
body:
SportsBusiness Daily provides today's top decision-makers in sports real-time industry news, allowing them to make more informed business decisions. Since 1994, SportsBusiness Daily has been recognized as the sports industry's leading daily trade publication, providing a comprehensive and smart business tool that keeps readers ahead of the news.

SportsBusiness Daily is relevant, contemporary and edgy. Each day, in an effort to cut through the clutter and save our clients precious time, SportsBusiness Daily monitors hundreds of respected media sources – daily metropolitan newspapers; weekly business journals; the top sports, business and news periodicals; sports, news and business television and radio shows; and some of the industry's leading Internet publications. We provide our high-end readers – consisting of team owners, top TV network, league and marketing executives, attorneys, corporate sponsors and other Fortune 500 companies – with the essential information they need to perform their job effectively. We provide not only the substance of today's news, but also the "spin," while our original features from our experienced staff provide in-depth analysis of the industry's latest trends.

If you have any questions or would like to receive a free trial subscription to SportsBusiness Daily, please register now or call (704)-973-1500.

In addition, if you would like to alert us to a news story in your market, please e-mail our editorial department at news@sportsbusinessdaily.com.

title: Policy and Specifications
body:
If you have a product to sell, a conference or meeting to promote or a job to fill, and you want to reach the top decision-makers in sports, you should place a classified ad in The Sports Business Daily.

Size of Advertisements
There are three sizes of classified advertisements in The Sports Business Daily.

80 Words or less
160 Words or less
400 Words or less

All advertisements are based on the number of words.

What You Need to Do
All advertising copy should be submitted to us by the advertiser. We will edit the copy to fit with the style of our publication and to fit the size of the advertisement purchased. If you would like us to write the copy, we will for an additional fee. We have final approval and editing authority over all copy submitted to or written by us, but advertisers will be consulted in the event of significant and substantive editing.

If you would like to place an order or discuss terms or procedures, please e-mail Heather Crawley at heatherc@sportsbusinessdaily.com or call 704-973-1500.

title: The Daily Insider
body:
THE SPORTS BUSINESS DAILY
THE DAILY INSIDER

The Daily Insider, a product of the editorial staff at The Sports Business Daily, is an exclusive online resource of the latest sports industry news, trends and research presented in a fast, fun and candid format. By subscribing to The Sports Business Daily, readers receive unlimited access to The Daily Insider, which consists of exclusive news and research data essential for today's top sports business executive.

The Daily Insider offers updated information on:

  • The latest news, facts and figures on the sports industry.
  • Complete Nielsen television ratings from recent sports events.
  • Expanded coverage of international sports industry issues.
  • Comprehensive analysis of nightly sports TV news shows.
  • Complete link service to relevant articles on the sports industry.
  • Expanded coverage of the latest sports sites on the Internet, women's sports issues
    and extreme and alternative sports.

Comprehensive research listings of:

  • League corporate partners
  • Facility naming rights agreements
  • Broadcast and cable television rights deals
  • League-by-league and team-by-team attendance
  • Top corporate sponsors in sports
  • Latest rankings of sports-related Web sites
  • The latest data on today's player salaries
  • and much, much more.

The Daily Insider is your full-service information source to the industry. It's smart, comprehensive and essential. To receive your unlimited pass to The Daily Insider, sign up for a free trial now or call (704) 973-1500.

title: Advertising Terms Sheet
body:
Classified Advertisements

General Policy
 A. Submission of an order is deemed an acceptance of all applicable rates and regulations set forth by SportsBusiness Daily, which reserves the right to revise rates at any time.

B. All orders and copy are subject to the approval of SportsBusiness Daily, which reserves the right to classify, edit, omit or reject advertising.

C. This publication will not knowingly accept advertisements of a fraudulent, misleading, controversial or discriminatory nature.

D. Specifications on orders regarding position and competitive advertising are treated as requests only. SportsBusiness Daily reserves the right to determine the position of all advertisements.

E. New accounts are to be prepaid until a credit line has been established. All advertising bills are due and payable in full during the month following the date of publication. Accounts 45 days in arrears will be refused further advertising until bills have been paid.

F. Upon request, we will submit bills to a designated recipient but payment for all advertising placed by a third party, i.e. advertising representative or agency, will ultimately be the responsibility of the company, business, service or group for which the individual advertisement is being placed.

G. No advertiser may include in their advertisement any direct reference to any other company or advertiser without the expressed written consent of that company or advertiser.

Processing
 A. Written confirmations of orders, cancellations or changes given over the telephone must be received prior to publication deadlines.
Adjustments
 A. The publication will make no allowances for errors that do not materially affect the value of the advertisement. Claims must be made in 30 days.

B. The publication will not be liable for failure to publish any advertisements for any reason; nor for claims of libel, unfair trade practices, infringement of trademarks, patents and copyrights or violations of an advertisement or its content.

Closing Times
 A. All orders for advertisements must be made by 3:00 pm ET two publishing days prior to publication.

Terms and Conditions
 A. A signed contract or insertion order for each advertisement must be completed and returned prior to the advertising copy deadline.

B. The advertiser will be charged for the actual number of ads published at the rates shown on the rate card. Advertiser may alter or reduce the indicated insertion schedule with advance notice, at least 24 hours prior to the insertion date. If the number of advertisements is reduced below a frequency discount shown, the advertiser must pay retroactively, the higher rate per advertisement within 30 days of such reduction.

C. Payments for advertisements are due prior to publication for new advertisers and within 30 days for credit worthy advertisers. Discounts are not recognized for advertising agencies.

D. No copy changes will be accepted after the advertising copy deadline. Advertiser is responsible for full payment of space after advertising copy deadline regardless of copy status.

SportsBusiness Daily Copy Protective Clause
Advertisers and advertising agencies assume all liability for content (including text, representation and illustrations) of advertisements printed, and also assume responsibility for any claims arising therefrom made against SportsBusiness Daily. SportsBusiness Daily reserves the right to reject any advertising.

title: Abe Madkour Bio
body:
Abraham D. Madkour
Executive Editor

Abraham Madkour is Executive Editor of Street & Smith’s SportsBusiness Journal and The Sports Business Daily.

Mr. Madkour is responsible for determining the editorial content and shaping the editorial direction of the two leading publications on the business of sports, while managing the entire editorial staff.

Mr. Madkour is an expert on the business of sports and news media analysis, and has served as an industry analyst and commentator for a number of print and electronic media.

Mr. Madkour joined The Sports Business Daily as a Senior Staff Writer when the publication launched in August 1994. In April 1995, he was promoted to Assistant Editor, and he was named Editor-in-Chief in September 1996. After the publication was acquired by Street & Smith’s Sports Group in 1998, Mr. Madkour led the relocation of The Sports Business Daily to Charlotte, NC, and oversaw the publication’s move from an e-mail text newsletter to a comprehensive online news service. Mr. Madkour added the duties of Executive Editor of SportsBusiness Journal in 2003.

Prior to joining The Sports Business Daily, Mr. Madkour was a Legislative Assistant for U.S. Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont. He worked for Vermont's Senior Senator beginning in 1990 and helped direct his re-election campaign in 1992. In addition to working with Senator Leahy, Mr. Madkour also had stints working for the Washington Bullets and the Baltimore Orioles in 1993 and 1994.

Mr. Madkour, 34, has a B.A. in Political Science from the University of Vermont.

title: Sample Classified Advertisement
body:
80 Words – (Position Available)

OCTAGON SEEKS ATTORNEY/DIRECTOR OF LEGAL AFFAIRS

Octagon, a world-class sports marketing company located in Stamford, CT, seeks experienced Corporate Attorney. Responsibilities include overseeing all legal and risk management issues (including events-related insurance items), liaison with outside counsel, advise on third party documents, and conduct industry research.  We are looking for an enthusiastic, proactive, team player with excellent written and oral communication skills.  Position requires Juris Doctorate and at least 3 years relevant work experience in the industry.  If interested, please fax resume and salary requirement to: (203) 351-4933.

80 Words – (Product Description)

THE ULTIMATE REPORT ON THE SPORTING GOODS INDUSTRY    

Looking for comprehensive information on the sporting goods industry?  Look no further.  The Harris SGB Poll provides quarterly detailed tracking data on key issues within the sporting goods industry.  Did you know... 60% of Americans participated in sports in the last year -- the top sports were outdoor sports, swimming, bowling, biking, and golf?  54% are interested in trying new sports with the majority interested in team sports.  For more information on this new marketing and retailing tool, call 877-228-7986, email info@harrissports.com, or visit www.harrisinteractive.com.

160 Words – (Conference/Promotion)

SPORTS SUMMIT 2001 JANUARY 18-19, NEW YORK MARRIOTT MARQUIS

Agencies, Content Providers, Event & Facility Suppliers, Leagues, Rights Holders, Sponsors, Site Developers, Teams, etc. all together at one time - Only at Sport Summit 2001 & Sport Summit Interactive, January 18-19, 2001, Marriott Marquis, New York City. title: Marcus DiNitto bio
body:
Marcus A. DiNitto
Managing Editor

Marcus DiNitto is Managing Editor of SportsBusiness Daily, the leading daily trade publication for the sports industry.

Mr. DiNitto helps determine the editorial content of the publication on a daily basis and oversees the management of its editorial staff. He formulates new story ideas, identifies industry trends and establishes new industry relationships vital to the publication.

Mr. DiNitto is an expert in sports marketing and sponsorship and joined SportsBusiness Daily as a staff writer in September 1998. He was promoted to Managing Editor in April 2000.

Prior to joining SportsBusiness Daily staff, Mr. DiNitto worked as an Account Executive with the Copeland Companies, a subsidiary of Travelers Insurance Company, specializing in retirement planning for employees of not-for-profit organizations.

Mr. DiNitto, 32, received an MBA with a concentration in marketing from the University of North Carolina-Charlotte in 2001, and a B.A. in advertising and mass communications from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1993 . Additionally, Mr. DiNitto attended and earned a certificate from New York University's Sports and Event Marketing Institute in 1998. He is single and lives in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Who We Reach
body:
SportsBusiness Daily Is A Powerful Marketing Platform:

Frequent and Broad Reach to the Power in the Sports Industry
Each day, SportsBusiness Daily reaches more than 35,000 executives in the sports industry. The Daily’s reach is broad covering every segment of sports business and every level of decision-making. With three releases Monday through Friday – The Morning Buzz, The Daily and the Closing Bell and one additional release on Friday – The Weekly Replay, SportsBusiness Daily is a constant and much-relied on source for sports business executives.

On average, SportsBusiness Daily generates more than 135,000 requested e-mails a week, more than 540,000 such e-mails a month.

In combination with sportsbusinessjournal.com our online assets attract more than 57,000 unique number visitors, 2.7 million impression s and more than 660,000 page views on average each month.

Leaders in Sports Business Have Come to Rely on The Daily

  • 93% read it at least 3 times a week
  • 89% read the Daily on the same day or receipt
  • 73% read the Daily every day
  • 82% read the Morning Buzz at least 3 times weekly
  • 70% read the Closing Bell at least 3 times a week

SportsBusiness Daily Readers Are Decision Makers in Every Aspect of Sports Business

  • 38% advertising, sponsorships, licensing, brand
  • 24% communications, PR, media, broadcasting
  • 17% professional services, including financial, legal and player representation
  • 21% management and operations including sales, human resources and infrastructure

SportsBusiness Daily Readers can be found at every executive level

  • 8% owner, partner, principal, president, CEO, commissioner
  • 13% executive vice president, C-level officers
  • 37% vice president, director or similar titles
  • 35% manager
  • 7% professionals servicing the industry

Source: SportsBusiness Daily, Subscriber Study, 2006

title: Game Plan
body:
The Sports Business Daily encourages contributions and submissions from our readers. “Get In The Game” allows you to be a player and offer your thoughts on some of the most important issues facing the industry. All reader comments will be reviewed by the editorial staff for consideration to post in our “Op-Ed” page, which will be the daily forum and leading Internet community for the sports professional.

In addition, Monday through Friday, The Sports Business Daily will highlight some of the top stories “In The News” where our readers will be asked to comment on the most significant and timely stories facing the sports industry. Once a reader’s submission has been reviewed and approved by our editorial staff, it will be posted in our “Op-Ed” page, where the sports industry’s leaders can read exactly what YOU feel about the most relevant issues of the day.

“Get In The Game,” allows you to express your views on the issues that you have read about in The Sports Business Daily, The Sports Business Daily Insider or any other sports-business topics.

The Sports Business Daily will not alter or edit any letters submitted without the approval granted by the original writer. By submitting any Letter to the Editor, the writer grants permission for reproduction on SportsBusinessDaily.com. Please note: All letters and comments submitted for posting must contain the writer’s name, company name, job title and address. Those submissions failing to contain the proper information will not be considered for publication.

So remember, don’t stay on the sidelines – “Get In The Game”!

title: In The News
body:
SHOULD MLB CBA TALKS BE POSTPONED A YEAR?

In light of the current international crisis, should MLB and the MLBPA agree to a one-year extension of the current CBA and put off its labor negotiations, or should the two sides attempt to work out a new agreement over the off season but be susceptible to fan disenchantment and a possible industry shutdown?

Question: Should MLB players and league officials hold off on CBA negotiations until next year?

editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com

WHAT IS THE FUTURE OF SPORTS BROADCASTING?

What is the next great idea for sports broadcasting? Is it on TV, radio, the Internet? While sports is purest example of unscripted drama, could there be some sort of reality-based TV series on the sporting life? Become a media programming executive for a day and tell us your brillant ideas.

Question: What's the next great idea in sports broadcasting?

editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com

title: OP-ED Page
body:
FSN ‘Best Damn Sports Show Period’ Threatens Future Of ‘NSR’

December 4, 2001: The Sports Business Daily

As the popularity of "Best Damn Sports Show Period" continues to grow, FSN execs are "considering retiring `National Sports Report' sometime in the first quarter of 2002," according to R. Thomas Umstead of MULTICHANNEL NEWS. Sources said that "Best Damn Sports Show Period" — a 90-minute show that offers live updates — "would become the default national sports-news service" for 18 FSN-owned and affiliated RSNs. After "initially airing for one hour at midnight," the "sports talk-comedy hybrid," hosted by Chris Rose and Tom Arnold, was moved to primetime in September, "when it became an instant ratings hit." Since its move to 7:30pm ET — with a repeat showing at 11:30 pm ET — ratings have increased 131%, from a 0.35 to a 0.81. But FSN VP/Media Relations Lou D'Ermilio said, "While we continually assess our programming and our schedule, this latest rumor of the demise of the `National Sports Report' is premature" (MULTICHANNEL NEWS, 12/3). The SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL's Andy Bernstein reports the show "expands to a two-hour format this week." Fox execs called the show FSN's future prime-time "backbone" when no live games are airing. Bernstein notes the show's original "lowbrow approach was a tough sell" to some FSN affils. FSN Exec VP George Greenberg: "We have toned it down a bit. We don't do as racy comedy as we did from day one. ... ESPN would never attempt a project like this. I applaud everything they do, but they're sort of stiff" (SBJ, 12/3 issue).

READER RESPONSE:
December 5, 2001
For all the popularity of this show, there's one reason I personally don't watch: Tom Arnold. If I want to see and hear a fat drunk going on about professional athletes, there are plenty of sports bars in my neighborhood where I can do that! (Granted, I won't be running up a tab if I'm staying home.) Here's an idea for FSN: Sign Jimmy Kimmel on to a huge contract, take him off Comedy Central and let him host the show while keeping him on as part of Fox NFL Sunday. If that happens, I'll watch every night from now on.

Carl Cronan, Tampa FL

Do you have an opinion you'd like to share with The Sports Business Daily? If so, please send them to:

editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com

October 25, 2001: The Sports Business Daily

READER RESPONSE:
October 25, 2001
There is no need to worry about the drop in attendance of the MLS playoffs. Like other leagues, MLS too was a victim of September 11th. Attendance was down in baseball and MLS across the country. Had the tragedy never occurred, MLS figures would have been undoubtedly higher this year, as compared to last. Attendance only dropping some 1.5% actually displays that the league has a strong future with loyal fans. Fans that would have considered coming to an MLS event for the first or second time for the playoffs for the nostalgia and novelty of the event were the most likely culprits that stayed home.

Eric Simantel
University of Oregon
James Warsaw School of Sports Marketing
MBA 2002

Do you have an opinion you'd like to share with The Sports Business Daily? If so, please send them to:

editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com



Some Question Timing Of World Series Contraction Talk

October 30, 2001: The Sports Business Daily

If MLB decides to contract any teams, the Expos "[top] the list," according to USA TODAY's Hal Bodley, who writes that the Twins probably are "second, but don't count out" the Marlins or Devil Rays (USA TODAY, 10/30). In Toronto, Mike Ulmer writes, "Amen to the end of baseball in Montreal. ... It is time to put a final, merciful end to the notion that if mollified with a new ballpark ... people in Montreal will care about baseball" (TORONTO SUN, 10/30).

NOT FANS OF CONTRACTION: CBS SPORTSLINE's Scott Miller wrote that the discussion of contraction during the World Series is "inexcusable. Yet thanks to baseball's continued penchant for flapping in the wind, it isn't surprising." More Miller: "For the commissioner during World Series week to discuss the idea of baseball eating some of its young — but without offering specifics, thus causing panic and headlines in places like Florida and Minnesota — is just plain wrong" (CBS SPORTSLINE, 10/29). In MN, Patrick Reusse writes, "The ability of [MLB Commissioner Bud Selig] and his advisors to always hit the wrong chord at the worst possible moment never ceases to amaze." Reusse reports the "rumored buyout fee" for contraction is $250M, or double what Twins Owner Carl Pohlad "could get from a Twin Cities buyer" (STAR TRIBUNE, 10/30). In Chicago, Ron Rapoport: "Two questions naturally arise: Couldn't this have waited until next week? And is this any way to run a sports league?" Rapoport, on contraction: "Would this save any real money? It would not. Would it institute any real cost controls? It would not. What contraction would do is continue the owners' unbroken streak of doing the wrong thing the wrong way at the wrong time" (CHICAGO SUN-TIMES, 10/30).

READER RESPONSE:
October 30, 2001
Lest we forget, it was GWB who was the lone voice of reason at the owners meeting ten years ago in Kohler, WI when the Lords of Baseball conspired to userp long-time Bush family friend Commissioner Fay Vincent of his authority to 'act in the best interests of baseball'. Perhaps tonite W will once again impart some common sense to the baseball braintrust. If MLB goes forward with any contraction scenario without stronly considering relocating the Expos to DC, baseball will surely lose it's get-out-of-jail-free card (federal antitrust exemption) in a measure that will find equal bipartisan support as Operation: Enduring Freedom.

Rod Nelson / Denver
Member: Society for American Baseball Research

title: FAQ
body:
• I already subscribe to sports newsletters, so why read SportsBusiness Daily?
• Where does SportsBusiness Daily get its information?
• How is SportsBusiness Daily different from a clipping service?
• If SportsBusiness Daily is only published Monday through Friday, how are readers exposed to weekend news?
• What if my site login and password do not work?
• Why is "Enter your e-mail address here" in the login box?
• What if I can't remember my password?
• Is my password case sensitive?
• Can others use my login to access SportsBusiness Daily?
• Can I access SportsBusiness Daily from more than one computer?
• What if I can't remember my site login?
• What is a "cookie"?
• How do I sign up for an e-mail alert?
• Is there a print version of SportsBusiness Daily?
• What is your policy for publishing Letters To The Editor?
• How do I search the archives on SportsBusinessDaily.com?
• How does the search system work?
• How do I print a story from the archives?
• How do I access a complete past issue of SportsBusiness Daily?
• What is the user agreement for reprinting stories from SportsBusiness Daily?
• Where do I direct questions on how to use the archives?
• How can I submit a press release, story ideas or news to SportsBusiness Daily?
• How does SportsBusiness Daily protect my privacy?
• How can I place a classified ad in SportsBusiness Daily?
• How can I advertise directly on SportsBusinessDaily.com?

I already subscribe to sports newsletters, so why read SportsBusiness Daily?

SportsBusiness Daily is a daily executive news briefing – not a newsletter – and there is nothing like it in the sports industry today. Unlike newsletters, SportsBusiness Daily updates you on the latest industry news every morning. On a daily basis, we "cover the coverage" from media outlets around the world, in a reliable, concise and user-friendly format. This means you will have more of "the news you need to know" to make better business decisions. In addition, SportsBusiness Daily offers a comprehensive listing of the latest research data, more news and opinion, and a link service to other articles of interest on the industry.

RETURN TO TOP

Where does SportsBusiness Daily get its information?

SportsBusiness Daily draws its information from major, mid- and small-market metropolitan dailies throughout the world; sports, entertainment, and business news shows on TV and sports radio broadcasts; industry trade publications; national sports and business periodicals; and directly from sports leagues, teams, sponsors, agencies, media and licensees.

RETURN TO TOP

How is SportsBusiness Daily different from a clipping service?

SportsBusiness Daily condenses and prioritizes the news for you every day, instead of providing entire news articles as they appear in newspapers. Our staff repackages the news in a way that allows you to get the information you need immediately.

RETURN TO TOP

If SportsBusiness Daily is only published Monday through Friday, how are readers exposed to weekend news?

The Monday edition of SportsBusiness Daily covers the industry news that is published and broadcast during the previous Saturday and Sunday – in addition to the news that is published Monday morning.

RETURN TO TOP

What if my site login and password do not work?

If you have problems with your site login and password, please contact our client services staff by e-mail at help@sportsbusinessdaily.com, or call us at 704-973-1500.

RETURN TO TOP

Why is "Enter your e-mail address here" in the login box?

This is just to remind you that your site login is your e-mail address. Please type over or delete the phrase before entering your e-mail address.

RETURN TO TOP

What if I can't remember my password?

If you can't remember your password, please let us know. We will send your password to the e-mail address that you have registered with us.

RETURN TO TOP

Is my password case sensitive?

Yes, your password is case sensitive. Passwords may be a combination of lowercase letters, uppercase letters and numbers. The combination that you used must be typed in exactly the same each time you log in.

RETURN TO TOP

Can others use my login to access SportsBusiness Daily?

Your site login and password are only for your use, as the subscriber. Multiple users will not be able to access The Daily under the same login. Please see our Terms of Service for further information

RETURN TO TOP

Can I access SportsBusiness Daily from more than one computer?

You can access The Daily from multiple computers. However, your site login and password are for your use only, as the subscriber. Multiple users cannot access The Daily under the same login. Please see our Terms of Service for further information.

RETURN TO TOP

What if I can't remember my site login?

Your site login is your e-mail address.

RETURN TO TOP

What is a “cookie”?

It is a small file that SportsBusinessDaily.com downloads to your personal computer. This file stores your site login and password which allows SportsBusinessDaily.com to automatically identify you when you access SportsBusinessDaily.com from the computer you are currently using. If you choose not to accept our cookie, you will have to enter your site login and password every time you access the site.

RETURN TO TOP

How do I sign up for an e-mail alert?

You can choose your preferences on alerts at My Account.

RETURN TO TOP

Is there a print version of SportsBusiness Daily?

We are an electronic/digital publication available only on the Web.

RETURN TO TOP

What is your policy for publishing Letters To The Editor?

Letters submitted for posting on SportsBusinessDaily.com will be reviewed by our editorial staff. Once a letter has been submitted, changes cannot be made by either the original writer or the staff of SportsBusinessDaily.com. By submitting said letter, the writer grants permission for republication of the letter on SportsBusinessDaily.com. Editor's Note: Letters submitted for publication must contain the writer's name and address. Those not containing these items will not be considered for publication.

RETURN TO TOP

How do I search the archives on SportsBusinessDaily.com?

KEYWORDS:

To search, you can enter a word or words in the keyword box and use either "any word," "all words" or "whole phrase" to refine your search.

The search system is not case sensitive. Entering "Nike" will search for "Nike", "nike", and "NIKE".

Keywords should include words that you feel are vital to the story that you want from our database. The keywords could appear either in the story headline, text or source credit.

The "whole phrase" search method looks for the exact phrase you type into the search box. You do not need to add quotes, just enter in the phrase you want to find.

An "all words" query will return results containing at least one concurrence of every single one of the keywords or phrases you enter.

An "any word" query will return results containing at least one occurrence of at least one of the keywords or quote phrases you enter. This is the least specific type of search.

In addition to the keyword search, you can specify a sport, company or team to search by, and the time period in which the article was published. You can select a specific category by checking or unchecking with the CTL key. For example, if you want all stories that relate to attendance issues in sports, you might click only Attendance in our Search By Topic feature. You can search with any combination of one of more checkboxes checked.

RETURN TO TOP

How does the search system work?

The default action of the Advanced Search page is "Whole Phrase." This is not a boolean search, so the system will search for words like "AND," "OR," "NOT," that are put in the search string. If user puts in the search term, "Cowboys not stadium," the system would offer the following results:

ALL WORDS: Matches any articles containing some form of "Cowboys," "not," and "stadium." The words may not be near one another or in any order, the only criteria is that all three words (in some form, even as parts of other words) must be in an article, to result in a match.

ANY WORD: Matches any articles containing any or all (but at least one) of some form of "Cowboys," "not," or "stadium."

WHOLE PHRASE: Matches any articles containing the entire phrase as it is typed (spaces are counted also) in a case insensitive manner. "Cowboys not stadium" will match "Cowboys not stadium," "COWBOYS NOT STADIUM," or "cowboys not stadium."

SEARCH BY TOPIC: Items appearing in SportsBusiness Daily from January 2001 to the current issue have been categorized by certain industry subjects. NOTE: Issues from 1994 through 2000 are not searchable using the topic categories. Please use the keyword search for best results.

SEARCH RESULTS: Search results will feature articles with the story headline, the first few sentences of the story, section of the publication, and issue date.

If your request matches a story in our database, a listing of all the stories that match your search request will appear. Click on the headline to read the full story. The full text of these stories is only accessible to subscribers of SportsBusiness Daily. If you are not a subscriber, register now for a free trial subscription.

Articles, by default, are sorted by the most recent story first. You can change that function with the "Sort By" feature.

By default, the first ten articles of a search request are displayed on a page. However, a user can change that with the "How Many Items Listed’ feature

RETURN TO TOP

How do I print a story from the archives?

If you wish to print the archive article after viewing the entire text, just click on the "Print This Story" feature on the lower right-hand side of the story.

RETURN TO TOP

How do I access a complete past issue of SportsBusiness Daily?

If you are interested in getting a complete online issue of SportsBusiness Daily for a specific date, use the Specific Issue Calendar box to select the year, month and day. This will provide all the headlines and stories posted to the online edition for that date.

RETURN TO TOP

What is the user agreement for reprinting stories from SportsBusiness Daily?

Articles taken from this database are for personal use only and may not be reprinted without the permission of the original source. If you have questions, please contact help@sportsbusinessdaily.com

RETURN TO TOP

Where do I direct questions on how to use the archives?

If you are a subscriber to SportsBusiness Daily and are having problems accessing our archives, e-mail help@sportsbusinessdaily.com or call 704 973-1500.

RETURN TO TOP

How can I submit a press release, story ideas or news to SportsBusiness Daily?

Press releases, story ideas or news can be submitted either by e-mail at news@sportsbusinessdaily.com or fax at 704-973-1501. For more detailed contact information, please see our Contact Us page.

RETURN TO TOP

How does SportsBusiness Daily protect my privacy?

Please refer to our complete privacy policy for details.

RETURN TO TOP

How can I place a classified ad in SportsBusiness Daily ?

Visit Advertise With Us for information on all of your advertising needs and questions.

RETURN TO TOP

How can I advertise directly on SportsBusinessDaily.com?

Contact Julie Tuttle at 212-500-0711 for information on advertising online.

RETURN TO TOP

title: About the Program
body:
Through heavily discounted student rates, Street & Smith’s Sports Group, College & University Program gives students the opportunity to develop a broader understanding of the sports industry by reading both SportsBusiness Journal and SportsBusiness Daily.

SportsBusiness Journal is a national weekly magazine that provides original sports business news, covering everything from sports marketing, sponsorships and media to in-depth analysis of the latest trends in the business. It has become an invaluable teaching tool in the classroom and is considered the preferred textbook for the 500+ participating sports marketing professors.

While SportsBusiness Journal provides original and weekly sports business information, SportsBusiness Daily is a comprehensive, online and real-time business news source that is provided each business day. It summarizes and prioritizes the industry news reported by over 500 media outlets and presents it online at www.sportsbusinessdaily.com. It is the perfect complement to SportsBusiness Journal and a natural teaching tool for the classroom.

For a sample listing of colleges and universities that participate in the program, click HERE.

About the Program
Subscription Options
Professor Information
What Participants Say
Contact Us
Policies and Procedures

title: Program Highlights
body:
From the Classroom to the Boardroom

The Sports Business Daily is available to students and faculty in sports management and marketing programs at a deeply discounted rate. Through our program, future industry leaders can "read what the insiders read" – the same daily news-briefing read by the commissioners of major league sports, network executives, team owners, leading player agents, corporate sponsors of sports events, and team marketing directors across the country.

Instructors benefit from our program by having a comprehensive teaching tool at their disposal, every day. The Sports Business Daily is a perfect text for courses on any aspect of the business of sports, and makes an ideal research and supplemental reading tool to help students make the transition from the classroom to the boardroom.

Program Highlights

  • Students individually purchase semester long e-mail subscriptions to The Sports Business Daily at the special student rate.
  • Each instructor that assigns The Sports Business Daily as reading for their classes will receive a complimentary one-year subscription of the publication.
  • Instructors collect all the subscription fees from the students and send a contract and a class roster to our Marketing Department.
  • Students have the option of continuing to receive The Sports Business Daily at the same special student rate, after classes end and for the remainder of their time in your program.

For more information about how to put The Sports Business Daily in your classroom and subscribe at our special student rates, please call 704-973-1500 or e-mail us at thedailylesson@sportsbusinessdaily.com.

title: Testimonials
body:
What University and College Educators are Saying about
The Daily Lesson:

“The Sports Business Daily is an excellent addition to the classroom. Students that wish to pursue careers in sports should read this publication everyday, just as business executives read the Wall Street Journal.”

Dr. Ken Shropshire
Wharton School of Business
University of Pennsylvania

“The Sports Business Daily provides faculty with a real-time industry publication to reference in class, and offers students invaluable insight into the sports industry.”

Dr. Peter Titlebaum
University of Dayton

"The Sports Business Daily is a valuable resource and an excellent teaching tool. Our sports marketing students have the chance to see exactly how the business of sports is conducted through the eyes of today's sports executives. We require it as class material and suggest daily readings for students intent on entering the sports industry."

Rick Burton
James H. Warsaw Sports Marketing Center
University of Oregon
