See this week’s issue of SportsBusiness Journal as well as www.sportsbusinessjournal.com for these stories and more.

THIS WEEK'S HEADLINES

• This week’s In-Depth examines faith-based marketing.
• A look at the financial state of the player unions.
• NBA discusses developing national basketball academy with IMG.
• Nike pushing to make Cavaliers F LeBron James face of company.
•

This week’s One-on-One features SI senior writer Alexander Wolff.

 
1.   THREE YOUNG NBA STARS LAND DEALS WITH NIKE’S JORDAN BRAND
          Hornets G Chris Paul, Hawks G Joe Johnson and Mavericks
     F Josh Howard have signed on to endorse Nike’s Jordan Brand
     line of footwear, apparel and accessories (Jordan Brand).
     In Oklahoma City, Darnell Mayberry noted Paul in ’05
     originally signed a four-year deal with Nike worth about
     $600,000 annually but it is not known how much Paul’s new
     six-year contract with Jordan Brand is worth.  Paul, on his
     new deal with the brand that carries Michael Jordan’s name:
     “It’s huge.  That’s the best player to ever play the game.
     I think it’s a tremendous honor to wear the shoe.”  Paul
     wore Jordan 9.5’s for the Hornets’ season-opener Wednesday
     night against the Celtics (DAILY OKLAHOMAN, 11/3).
          LEADING THE COMEBACK: In New Orleans, John Reid wrote
     Paul “could become the perfect ambassador” for the
     rebuilding effort in New Orleans.  When the Hornets “make
     their expected full-time return to New Orleans” next season,
     Paul’s plans are “likely to center on helping children.”
     Paul said that he talked with Saints RB Reggie Bush last
     month “about possibly teaming for a few New Orleans
     community-related projects.”  Octagon Dir of Marketing
     Jennifer Keene, whose agency reps Paul, said, “It’s in the
     very early planning stages, but he wants to do a basketball
     camp in New Orleans next summer.  He’ll do a camp in Winston-
     Salem (N.C.) and Oklahoma City, and he didn’t want to leave
     out New Orleans.  Many of the kids will attend on a
     scholarship, thanks to the generosity of our sponsors.”
     Paul said of his CP3 Foundation, “I always think about
     expanding the foundation, but at the same time, it’s just
     getting started.  But I just want to keep trying to give,
     because I get so much out of it” (TIMES-PICAYUNE, 11/5).

  
2.   HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET: NEW BALANCE INKS PBS SHOW DEAL
          New Balance signed a four-year, multimillion-dollar
     deal to sponsor Sesame Workshop that “will put New Balance’s
     imprint on a range of Sesame Street properties both on and
     off air,” according to Donna Goodison of the BOSTON HERALD.
     The TV portion begins this month and runs through ’07, and
     includes 15-second English- and Spanish-language spots that
     will air before and after each episode. New Balance Global
     Marketing & Brand Management Group Manager Christine Madigan
     said of the deal, “We’re absolutely targeting moms of kids
     age 0 to 5.”  The deal does not include product placement on
     the show. Sesame Workshop VP/Sponsorship Anita Stewart: “The
     Muppets cannot promote a product or endorse a product.”
     Goodison notes New Balance’s name and products “will be
     incorporated more freely into off-air programs not bound by
     federal broadcasting regulations.”  That includes the first
     exclusive national sponsorship of Sesame Street’s
     interactive play areas at a traveling exhibition. New
     Balance is the show’s fifth sponsor (BOSTON HERALD, 11/6).

  
3.   SELLING OF THE CHAMP: BRADY’S MARKETING FEATURED IN NEW BOOK
          BOSTON GLOBE MAGAZINE yesterday ran an excerpt from
     Charles Pierce’s new book about Patriots QB Tom Brady,
     “Moving the Chains,” which examines how Brady “manages his
     fame -– and shapes his public image –- on his own terms.”
     Brady is featured on the magazine’s cover.  NFL Lead Exec
     for Marketing & Sales Phil Guarascio said, “If I were
     marketing Tom Brady, and I was looking toward the future, I
     might do some things differently to build up his personality
     value outside the game, as opposed to relying on the
     exposure he gets from being part of a winning team.”  Pierce
     writes Brady, who has had deals with Gap, Nike, Sirius and
     Visa, is “cautious with his commercial endorsements.”
     Brady: “I don’t need to be the showstopper, the entertainer.
     I’d much rather be one of the guys.”  Guarascio added, “He's
     done a good job so far managing his brand.  Clearly, he
     needed the platform more than some of the more extroverted
     guys did.”  Guarascio described Brady as “All-American with
     an edge, an edge toward hipness and coolness, and
     understated elegance, low-key, but there's that edge there,
     when he gets into the red zone, there's that steeliness,
     that '(Expletive) you, we're going to get this in the end
     zone' thing.  Sort of a Cool Hand Luke thing.  A guy people
     like, but who you don't fool with. If I were managing him,
     I'd exploit that."  But producer Jimmy Siegel, who created
     the Visa ads featuring Brady and his offensive line, said
     that Brady was “far less loose than his teammates.”  Siegel:
     “He was probably a little stiffer than all five of the
     linemen were, which was part of the surprise” (BOSTON GLOBE
     MAGAZINE, 11/5 issue).

  
4.   DICKIES RENEWS NEXTEL CUP RACE TITLE SPONSORSHIP THROUGH ‘09
          Ft. Worth-based Dickies has extended its title
     sponsorship of the fall NASCAR Nextel Cup race at Texas
     Motor Speedway (TMS) through ’09, with options to extend the
     deal through 2011, according to Brad Townsend of the DALLAS
     MORNING NEWS.  Dickies originally signed a three-year deal
     with two option years before the ’05 race, and the company
     “had until next June to exercise the option but chose to do
     so early.”  Meanwhile, TMS’ contract with RadioShack to
     title sponsor the Samsung 500, the spring Cup race at the
     track, is set to expire after the ’07 event.  However, TMS
     President Eddie Gossage said that RadioShack “has an option
     to add up to two years” (DALLAS MORNING NEWS, 11/5).

  
5.   OUTSIDE THE LINES LOOKS AT TOYOTA’S ENTRANCE TO NEXTEL CUP
          Sunday’s edition of ESPN’s “Outside The Lines” examined
     Toyota’s entry into the NASCAR Nextel Cup next season.
     ESPN’s Mike Massaro noted Toyota “maintains that squashing
     the competition is contrary to their company’s philosophy.
     They say their main objective in entering NASCAR’s Cup
     series is to gain exposure and sell cars.”  NASCAR Chair &
     CEO Brian France: “We’re in a competitive world.  We’re in a
     global economy.  (Toyota) is a big part of this country
     today, and they’re going to do an outstanding job of being a
     part of NASCAR.”  Charlotte Observer writer David Poole
     added, “If Toyota comes in and dominates NASCAR, it won’t be
     Toyota’s fault.  It’ll be NASCAR’s.”  France said “it’s our
     job to make sure the rules package are even (and) they’re
     balanced.”   Massaro said some of the resistance to Toyota’s
     Nextel Cup foray “stems from American autoworkers who
     associate lost jobs and plant closings with the influx of
     Japanese cars” in the U.S.  But Toyota Racing Development
     President Jim Aust added, “We don’t consider ourselves
     predators.  All we want to do is be able to come into the
     series.  We want to be able to compete and we want to be
     able to win some races.”
          EFFECT ON THE BOTTOM LINE: NASCAR driver Jeff Burton,
     the Detroit News’ Angelique Chengelis and ESPN’s Marty Smith
     appeared via satellite to discuss Toyota.  Burton: “The cost
     of racing because of Toyota coming in has without a doubt
     gone way up, and the fact is, and regardless of what Toyota
     wants to say, they are trying to outspend a tremendous
     amount of people.”  Smith added, “Their factory backing is
     going to be substantially larger than we typically see. ...
     Toyota team owners ... are going to go out to Corporate
     America and sell their sponsorships for less money than the
     other manufacturing owners do.”  But Chengelis said
     opposition to Toyota “smacks a little bit of the small-
     market whining that you hear in (MLB). ... I don’t think
     that having a lot of money means Toyota has instant success”
     (“Outside The Lines,” ESPN, 11/5).

  
6.   NBC CHARTS BEST “SNF” OVERNIGHT OF THE YEAR FOR COLTS-PATS
          NBC earned a 15.1/22 overnight Nielsen rating for Colts-
     Patriots last night, down 1.9% from the comparable 15.4/23
     for the same matchup on ABC’s “MNF” in Week Nine of the NFL
     season last year.  Last night’s game was NBC’s ninth NFL
     telecast this season, and the 15.1 marks a 24% increase from
     Ravens-Steelers on ABC last year, that network’s ninth
     telecast of the ’05 season.  Last night's 15.1 is the best
     overnight of the year for “SNF” and the best for a primetime
     regular-season NFL game on broadcast television since a
     15.9/24 for Steelers-Colts on “MNF” last year. In the
     overnights, NBC won the night in primetime and "Sunday Night
     Football" won every hour of the night.  “SNF” earned a 15.6
     from 9:00-10:00pm ET, beating the 14.8 for ABC’s “Desperate
     Housewives.”  The NASCAR Nextel Cup Dickies 500 ran late,
     and NBC’s “Football Night in America” did not come on the
     air until about 7:30pm.  It is scheduled to start at 7:00pm.
     Postrace coverage was shifted to CNBC (THE DAILY).
          POSTGAME: In this week’s SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL, Andrew
     Marchand reports that during Fox’ first four NFL
     doubleheader weeks, the net has carried games until 7:30pm
     ET and has earned a 7.7 Nielsen rating from 7:30-8:00pm for
     “The OT.”  NBC’s “Football Night in America” has earned a
     4.4 from 7:30-8:15pm.  CBS’ philosophy is to “switch to
     compelling games if action warrants it, but as soon as there
     is no intriguing action left, it usually leaves the air as
     soon as possible” for “60 Minutes.”  For CBS’ doubleheaders,
     “Football Night” has averaged a 4.83; that rating drops to a
     3.68 when Fox has a doubleheader and goes to “The OT”
     (SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL, 11/6 issue).
          ON LOCATION: “Fox NFL Sunday” Coordinating Producer
     Scott Ackerson said of moving the show from a studio to the
     location of the network’s top game, “Some people -– from
     other networks -– thought that we’d be an unmitigated
     disaster.  I think that’s the term that they used.  And
     they’re just wrong.  We’re going to be doing this for the
     rest of the year” (WASHINGTON TIMES, 11/4).  However, in
     N.Y., Phil Mushnick writes Fox “took a tough-to-watch show
     and turned it into an impossible-to-watch show.  Yesterday’s
     shout session [at FedEx Field for Cowboys-Redskins] looked
     and sounded like it was surrounded by a prison riot” (N.Y.
     POST, 11/6).
          MEA CULPA: CBS SportsLine.com posted a message this
     weekend to address “periods of slow or interrupted service”
     experienced by some fantasy football customers this season.
     The note says SportsLine “set ambitious and often competing
     goals for ourselves” to enhance its fantasy product, and
     states, “In the past, we’ve met that challenge, but so far
     this year, we’ve fallen short. ... Addressing the quality of
     service issues that have occurred this fantasy season is the
     No. 1 priority for nearly every member of the CBS SportsLine
     staff.  Be assured that our staff has been on high alert
     since the beginning of the season and will remain so until
     YOU tell us that our service is running smoothly.”
     To see SportsLine’s Report Card to assess its own
     performance for the first half of the season, visit
     SportsBusinessDaily.com (THE DAILY).

  
7.   CBS NAMES QUINCY SMITH HEAD OF NEWLY NAMED CBS INTERACTIVE
          CBS named Allen & Co.’s Quincy Smith President of the
     newly named CBS Interactive.  He replaces Digital Media
     President Larry Kramer, who will stay on in an advisory
     role.  Smith will oversee CBS’ wholly owned Web sites,
     including CBS SportsLine.com, CBSNews.com and CBS.com (CBS).
     Smith, who has been working with CBS during the past nine
     months as an advisor for Allen & Co., said that the company
     “is interested in finding companies with the potential to be
     the next generation of YouTubes” (HOLLYWOOD REPORTER, 11/6).
     But CBS CEO Leslie Moonves “was quick to reassure Wall
     Street that the company did not plan to make large, costly
     acquisitions.”  Moonves: “We are not going to spend $1.6[B]
     on YouTube.  We are looking for the next YouTube and Quincy
     knows all the players” (N.Y. TIMES, 11/6).  In L.A., Meg
     James writes CBS’ hiring of the 35-year-old Smith
     demonstrates it is “eager to make acquisitions to better
     position itself in digital media.”  Smith’s “relationships
     and Silicon Valley experience -- he worked five years at
     Netscape -- should help him” (L.A. TIMES, 11/6).
          KRAMER DEPARTING: Kramer indicated that it “was his
     choice to leave CBS.”  Kramer: “I knew there were a set
     number of things that I wanted to accomplish, that there
     would be stages after that.  I wasn’t sure if I wanted to be
     involved or not” (HOLLYWOOD REPORTER, 11/6).  Kramer: “It’s
     amazing how far we’ve come.  We’re a division now, and a
     profitable operation.  But it’s been an exhausting two
     years” (L.A. TIMES, 11/6).

  
8.   MISSPEAK EASY: NASCAR ADDRESSES MARTY SNIDER’S COMMENTS
          NASCAR said that NBC’s Marty Snider “used ‘poor
     judgment’ in comments he made during Speed Channel’s
     broadcast of Nextel Cup qualifying at Texas Motor Speedway”
     on Friday, according to Jim Utter of the CHARLOTTE OBSERVER.
     While talking with driver Carl Edwards about Edwards needing
     a haircut, Speed’s Steve Byrnes said, “Another fan wrote in
     and said we were the whitest men on Earth.”  Snider then
     said to Edwards, “Can you not dance?”  Edwards: “I’m truly
     as white as we get.  The only (whiter) guy than me is Steve
     Byrnes.” Snider is not employed by Speed, but Speed uses NBC
     talent when it broadcasts qualifying (CHARLOTTE OBSERVER,
     11/4).
          LOOSE LIPS: In Pittsburgh, Sam Ross Jr. wrote ABC
     studio analyst Craig James, during halftime of Penn State-
     Wisconsin on Saturday, “quipped that [Penn State coach Joe]
     Paterno, who was upset at the half, must have had his
     Geritol kick in.”  He also called Paterno an “old fart.”  He
     later apologized on air (TRIBUNE-REVIEW, 11/5).
          LYON’S EYES: In Boston, gossip columnists Fee & Raposa
     report Entercom “is making a pitch” for Steve Lyons to join
     the Red Sox radio broadcast next season.  Lyons was fired by
     Fox for comments made during the ALCS.  Lyons, still a part-
     time TV analyst for the Dodgers, said that “if he could work
     around his schedule with [the team], he would ‘seriously
     look at’ a job with the Sox” (BOSTON HERALD, 11/6).
          FIRING BACK: Former ESPN analyst Harold Reynolds, who
     filed a wrongful termination lawsuit over his firing for
     sexual harassment, said, “I was counseled by a lot of people
     who told me, ‘Hey move on man. It will blow over, it will go
     away.’ I couldn’t do it. ... This is not right.  I’ve not
     been treated properly.”  One network exec said that the
     lawsuit “could brand him a ‘troublemaker.’”  Another exec
     said, “He’s a talent.  I’m not here to second-guess ESPN,
     but Harold deserves a second chance as a broadcaster” (Bob
     Raissman, N.Y. DAILY NEWS, 11/6).  Reynolds added, “They
     have (sensitivity) classes at ESPN for things like this.
     But never in the 10 previous years I’ve been there have I
     ever had to go to one of those classes.  The way they are,
     if they want to work with me on new interview techniques, if
     they want to show me a new studio, anything like that, they
     take me by the hand and walk me down the hall to the studio
     or the meeting room.  You would think if they thought there
     was a problem, I would have had to go to one of those
     training session” (SEATTLE TIMES, 11/6).
          TRAINING DAY: In Ft. Lauderdale, Charles Bricker wrote
     under the header, “Networks Have Little Tolerance For
     Sportscasters’ Insensitive Remarks.”  ESPN “has in place a
     series of compulsory meetings for its on-air talent, and in
     addition to a preseason seminar, there are cautions
     throughout the year about being aware of sensitive remarks.”
     ESPN Senior VP & Dir of News Vince Doria: “All analysts,
     play-by-play and studio people come to Bristol, where they
     are addressed by several people in the company on issues of
     editorial integrity and balance.”  Comcast Sports Southeast
     GM Mark Fuhrman, who fired analyst Lamar Thomas for comments
     during the Univ. of Miami-Florida Int’l brawl last month,
     said the incident “made us more cognizant of the talent we
     look at.  But, across the board, everyone is taking a longer
     look at who they hire” (South Florida SUN-SENTINEL, 11/5).

  
9.   NBC’s N.Y. MARATHON OVERNIGHT FLAT; NYRR WEB SITE FAILS
          NBC’s coverage of the ING N.Y. Marathon yesterday drew
     a 1.1/2 overnight Nielsen rating, drawing even with the
     rating from last year’s competition (THE DAILY). In St.
     Petersburg, Tom Jones writes NBC’s marathon coverage “was
     the best-directed sports show of the weekend” (ST.
     PETERSBURG TIMES, 11/6).
          SITE UNSEEN: In N.Y., Frank Litsky reports the N.Y.
     Road Runners (NYRR), the group that runs the ING N.Y.
     Marathon, “experienced technical problems with the event’s
     official Web site” during the race yesterday, meaning
     “thousands of visitors from around the world were not able
     to use the Athlete Tracker service, which was billed as a
     way to follow runners’ progress every five kilometers.”  The
     tracking system went down at about 10:15am ET, five minutes
     after the men’s field started, and was restored two hours
     later.  NYRR Dir of PR Richard Finn: “We were unable to
     deliver what we said we would be able to do. ... We point
     the finger at ourselves” (N.Y. TIMES, 11/6).  Some users
     were still unable to access the Athlete Tracker at about
     2:00pm ET yesterday.  They were able to get on the site at
     about 3:00pm (THE DAILY).

  
10.  MEDIA NOTES
          The Breeders’ Cup World Championships earned a 1.0
     overnight Nielsen cable rating from 12:00-5:45pm ET on
     Saturday.  This was the first year the event was held on
     ESPN.  Preliminary information also shows that hits on horse
     racing section of ESPN.com were up 68% from a year ago (THE
     DAILY).
          NIELSEN: Nielsen Media Research on Friday “delayed the
     launch of a controversial system to measure viewership for
     commercials after encountering stiff resistance from TV
     programmers who believed the ratings system wasn’t ready for
     prime time.”  Nielsen was planning on launching the
     initiative December 11, but findings “revealed another
     shortcoming” -- most DVR watching “occurred within two days
     of a program’s being recorded, but its system was designed
     to capture viewing live, within 24 hours of the original
     airing or within a week of it” (L.A. TIMES, 11/4).
          TURNED OFF: In Houston, David Barron notes Saturday
     marked the end of Turner Sports’ sublicensing deal with FSN
     for Big 12 and Pac-10 college football games.  Turner “is
     not interested in another contract, citing its new [MLB]
     deal and financial concerns, so the onus will be on FSN to
     clear the games on FSN [or] find another channel to carry
     the games” (HOUSTON CHRONICLE, 11/6).

  
11.  NBAers STRUGGLING TO CONFORM WITH ON-COURT BEHAVIOR POLICY
          With the NBA’s new crackdown on on-court behavior in
     place, players and coaches were called for 30 technical
     fouls in the first 17 games this season, according to Peter
     May of the BOSTON GLOBE, who noted only seven technical
     fouls were called in the first 17 games last season.  Four
     players were ejected through the first 17 games, compared to
     none at the same point last year.  NBA Commissioner David
     Stern said, “We’re not making our players into robots and
     we’re not making our coaches into robots.  Spur-of-the-
     moment emotion?  Of course.  Let’s just not make it into one
     big harangue or complaint session.”  But Pistons F Rasheed
     Wallace, who was ejected from the team’s opener last
     Wednesday, responded, “He’s trying to turn players into
     robots because of the dress code and with this no-tolerance
     law. It takes the fun out of the game” (BOSTON GLOBE, 11/5).
     After receiving his third technical of the season Saturday,
     Wallace said, “They’re going to have to do something about
     this crazy zero-tolerance law. That’s retarded.  In my mind,
     it’s kind of like a slave and master or father and son.
     You’ve got your little son and (you say) don’t say nothing
     back to me -- and to me, that’s totally wrong.  It ain’t
     like that in any other sport” (DETROIT FREE PRESS, 11/5).
     Stern said the new policy is “about the game.  It’s about
     our players, our teams, and we want our arenas to be places
     where they can come and enjoy the games” (Toronto GLOBE &
     MAIL, 11/4).  But 76ers G Allen Iverson said, “These things
     have nothing to do with the game.  I don’t see no reason to
     concentrate on stuff like that -- the officiating, the
     shorts and wristbands, dress code.”   Stern said, “With the
     dress code, people think we were mandating black tie.  These
     are not draconian measures.  But, the anti-complaining
     enforcement could be draconian” (N.Y. TIMES, 11/6).
          PLAYER REAX: Kings G Mike Bibby, who was ejected from
     the team’s opener against the T’Wolves, was “upset with what
     he perceived as a double standard used in the application of
     the new rules.”  Bibby: “They’ve got people on the other
     team cursing at the same guy who kicked me out, and he’s
     telling him, ‘Calm down, just calm down.’  And I say one
     word to him and he’s going to kick me out of the game?”
     (SACRAMENTO BEE, 11/3).  Spurs F Francisco Elson on Thursday
     received a technical foul when he “screamed as he dunked”
     and “happened to land in front of” Mavericks C Erick
     Dampier.  Heat G Dwyane Wade: “What is the line?  You can’t
     talk to anybody anymore or you can’t show emotion?” (MIAMI
     HERALD, 11/5).  Rockets F Tracy McGrady added, “We play with
     passion out there.  It seems like they’re taking that away
     from us. You make an unbelievable play and you can’t yell
     and scream?”  NBA Senior VP/Basketball Operations Stu
     Jackson said, “We understand emotional, passionate reaction
     to plays.  If the reaction dissolves quickly, we’ll allow
     that.  It’s a judgment here” (HOUSTON CHRONICLE, 11/5).
          IS IT REALLY HELPING? In Philadelphia, Stephen A. Smith
     wrote Stern “is clearly a bit confused.  Evidently, he’s
     convinced he’s moving forward when it’s quite apparent he is
     moving backward.”  One league GM said, “We have absolutely
     no say in how our game is officiated. ... We’d prefer the
     situation to be different, but what can you do?”  Smith
     wrote NBA players “have enough problems with their image.
     The last thing they need is knowing there’s no help from the
     very man empowered to do, practically, anything he wants to
     them” (PHILADELPHIA INQUIRER, 11/5).  On Long Island, Ken
     Berger wrote, “It doesn’t seem like good business for a
     league to take some of the players it is trying to promote
     so fiercely off the court and send them to the locker room”
     (NEWSDAY, 11/5).  Pistons coach Flip Saunders: “This hurts
     the teams, but the people who really are hurt by this are
     the fans.  Somebody who took his kid to watch the Clippers-
     Nuggets game the other night because the kid loves Carmelo
     Anthony, only to see him thrown out of the game with 10
     minutes left in the third quarter –- that’s the guy that’s
     hurt by this” (DETROIT NEWS, 11/4).
          OTHER RULES: Suns Managing Partner Robert Sarver was
     fined $25,000 after he “briefly lost his cool Wednesday
     before game officials reversed an incorrect out-of-bounds
     call in front of his courtside seat.” Sarver said of the new
     code of conduct for owners, “I voted for the new rule, and I
     think it’s good.  Sometimes, your greatest strength is your
     weakness.  I have a lot of passion and energy. ... I did
     pretty good that night, except that was right in front of
     me” (ARIZONA REPUBLIC, 11/6)....Heat C Shaquille O’Neal, a
     late scratch from yesterday’s Heat-76ers game due to an
     injury, watched the game from the locker room “to avoid
     potentially being fined for a violation of the NBA’s dress
     code.” O’Neal “did not have a sport coat to complement his
     gray outfit” (MIAMI HERALD, 11/6).

  
12.  NASCAR’S BRIAN FRANCE SAYS CHANGES ON HORIZON FOR CHASE
          NASCAR Chair & CEO Brian France said that “offseason
     changes to the Chase for the Nextel Cup will focus on
     increasing the importance of victories without overhauling
     the format,” according to Ryan & Livingstone of USA TODAY.
     France: “The one thing we can all agree on is that we’ll be
     looking to make the win more important.”  He added that
     increasing the size of the Chase field is “off the table but
     left open the possibility of increasing the points margin by
     which drivers become Chase-eligible.” Also, having a
     “separate points system for Chase drivers is unlikely.”
     France said that NASCAR would decide on the changes in
     December (USA TODAY, 11/6).  In Dallas, Tim Cowlishaw writes
     that in the current Chase format, “NASCAR continues to
     attach much greater significance to failure, which at times
     can be nothing more than bad luck, than it does to success.”
     Winning races “should be what it’s all about ... but playing
     it safe and not suffering a bad finish is really what gets
     rewarded.”  NASCAR driver Jimmie Johnson said, “I don’t know
     how to change it, but you need more of a reward for
     performance than for losing.  You have a lot more to lose in
     any given race than you can achieve by winning” (DALLAS
     MORNING NEWS, 11/6).
          CHASING FANS: In Dallas, Richard Durrett noted TV

     ratings for the ten Chase races in the first two years of
     the format “were higher than those before a playoff
     existed,” but through seven races this year have dropped
     from a 4.4 to a 4.1.  NASCAR President Mike Helton said, “I
     don’t think we cannot be concerned about ratings when they
     aren’t where we want them.  But when you look at the last
     three years, you’re a little more at ease.”  Also,
     NASCAR.com VP/e-commerce Joe Mattes said that sales at the
     Web site increased by 40% from pre-Chase ’03 to ’04-05, and
     he “expects sales to go up again this year.”  Mattes: “I
     can’t say for sure that the Chase drove all those sales, but
     it couldn’t have hurt.”  Mattes said prior to the Chase, 40%
     of merchandise sold on the site was from the final ten races
     of the year, and that has increased to 50% since the Chase
     started.  Visitors to the online store have increased an
     average of 15% the last two years.  Durrett noted sponsors
     also “notice a difference with the Chase in place.”  But
     Roush Racing President Geoff Smith said that the “non-Chase
     participants didn’t see their exposure decrease during the
     final 10 races” in ’04-05.  Smith: “We studied it and showed
     our sponsors that, because TV ratings are up, exposure
     remains the same for those that don’t make it.  But it goes
     up for the Chase cars.  It’s like a bonus for the Chase
     guys.  But if the ratings don’t stay up, that exposure could
     go down” (DALLAS MORNING NEWS, 11/5).
          DICKIES 500: Yesterday’s estimated attendance for the
     Nextel Cup Dickies 500 at Texas Motor Speedway (TMS) was
     181,500, “the lowest in 12 NASCAR Cup events” at the track.
     Some seats on the backstretch were “tarped over with
     advertising signs.”  TMS President Eddie Gossage said of the
     empty seats, “Whether you’re going to sell them (to fans) or
     not, I don’t know.  But we got revenue for them.”  Race fan
     Spencer Jackson “suspects the lower attendance was caused by
     the grim weather forecast” (DALLAS MORNING NEWS, 11/6).

  
13.  FROM THE PBR WORLD FINALS: ATTENDANCE TOPS HALF-MILLION MARK
     By Ross Nethery, Managing Editor, SportsBusiness Journal

          The Professional Bull Riders had 93,223 fans attend the
     seven sessions that made up the ‘06 World Finals in Las
     Vegas, which ended Sunday.  That number boosted total
     attendance for the top-level Built Ford Tough Series over
     the half-million mark for ‘06, the first time that has
     happened. The final number for the year was 559,119. Last
     year’s number was about 453,000.
          ARMY: U.S. Army Chief of Staff Gen. Peter Schoomaker
     attended the PBR Finals and gave a talk to riders before the
     beginning of the last session.  During his few minutes with
     the riders, which were filmed and used later as part of the
     opener for the event, Schoomaker said the riders have a lot
     of fans in uniform. “You believe in the same things,”
     Schoomaker said. “You’re focused on your mission. You never
     accept defeat. And you never leave a fallen comrade -– you
     take care of each other.”  The Army is a major sponsor of
     the PBR and had a heavy presence at the Finals. Soldiers
     rappelled from the ceiling of the Thomas & Mack Center
     before the beginning of this weekend’s sessions, at the same
     time as a giant American flag was unfurled for the national
     anthem.  The All-American Chorus of the 82nd Airborne,
     stationed at Fort Bragg, sang patriotic songs before each
     night’s session, as well as during breaks. And on Saturday
     night, 14 Army recruits were sworn in on the floor of the
     arena, to rousing cheers from the crowd. The only
     disappointment for the Army came on Sunday when Mike Lee,
     one of the riders sponsored by the Army, just missed out on
     winning his second world championship in three years.
          MEDIA: About 125 media credentials were handed out for
     this year’s World Finals, which PBR CEO Randy Bernard said
     was about a 40% increase over last year. What Bernard was
     particularly pleased with, though, was the presence of news
     organizations such as USA Today, the AP and Dallas Morning
     News.  Bernard in the last two years has placed a big
     emphasis on improving media coverage for the PBR, and he
     thinks the group’s efforts, which include visits to news
     organizations to educate them about the sport, are paying
     off. “This is exactly the kind of stuff we’ve been hoping
     for,” he said. “More and more news organizations are finally
     looking at us as a credible sport. But we have to convince
     them one by one.” There was also a strong international
     presence among the media contingent, including reporters
     from Canada, Japan and Brazil, which is home to newly-
     crowned world champion Adriano Moraes.
          SEEN AND HERD: The governor and mayor of Chihuahua,
     which is the name of both a city and a state in Mexico,
     attended Friday night’s session and were given a Tiffany
     trophy and custom-made spurs by Bernard for hosting what
     Bernard called the PBR’s event of the year.  More than
     25,000 people attended the first ever Built Ford Tough
     Series event in Mexico last August.  The two-day event was
     so successful that it will be expanded to three days in ’07.
     Meanwhile, Baseball HOFer Tommy Lasorda sat in Bernard’s box
     for a couple of sessions. Speaking shortly after the Army
     recruits were sworn in, he told the crowd that its
     appreciation for men and women in uniform brought tears to
     his eyes. “You people are the heartbeat of America,” he
     said.
          GRAND THEFT AUTO: Versus, which covered the World
     Finals, took the “Only in Vegas” cliché to a new level last
     week when it lost a cargo van and a trailer that was filled
     with hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of production
     equipment.  The crew was moving its gear from Mandalay Bay
     to the Thomas & Mack Center, the setting of the tournament's
     second week.  Following the World Finals first three
     telecasts, the crew packed its gear on Sunday night, October
     29, and parked it overnight outside of the Embassy Suites.
     When they woke up Monday morning, they realized that the
     trailer and van had been stolen. Versus leased both
     vehicles. “My first thought was that we could be screwed,”
     said Versus Production Manager Gary Peterson.  In addition
     to equipment leased by the network, master tapes featuring
     footage the network planned to use for an upcoming special
     on rodeo clowns was in the trailer.  That special has been
     put on hiatus until the footage is recovered. The theft did
     not disrupt the network's coverage of the event. Footage
     taken by a producer to his hotel room was used during the
     event's second week.  The crew scurried to rent jibs from
     Vegas, and had its L.A.-based wireless provider bring over a
     new wireless system. “There are a million things we could
     have done differently,” Peterson said. “Still, we're all
     amazed that we didn't lose as much stuff as we could have.”

          Staff Writer John Ourand contributed to this report.

  
14.  NYRA SECURES $8M LOAN FROM STATE, LOOKS FOR MORE THIS WEEK
          A day after being “criticized as incompetent” in NYRA’s
     bankruptcy filing, New York Gov. George Pataki’s
     administration lent NYRA $8M on Friday, according to James
     Odato of the Albany TIMES UNION.  The money, “arranged
     during a bankruptcy court proceeding, replaced private
     financing NYRA had set up.”  As collateral, NYRA would have
     “put up the three state tracks that it claims it owns” –-
     Saratoga, Aqueduct and Belmont.  The state claims it owns
     the tracks, and New York Attorney General and gubernatorial
     candidate Eliot Spitzer said that NYRA’s bankruptcy filing
     is a “work of fiction and said the track operator is wrong
     if it thinks it owns” the tracks (Albany TIMES-UNION, 11/4).
     In N.Y., Ed Fountaine noted even with the loan, the
     “bankruptcy declaration will continue.”  NYRA will go to
     court Wednesday, “hoping to get a $50[M] loan from the hedge
     fund SB Capital, subject to approval from the judge.”  Nader
     said that the issue of who owns the three tracks “did not
     come up” Friday.  Before Friday’s races, Nader and NYRA
     Chair Steven Duncker met with employees and horsemen “to
     assure them that, despite the bankruptcy, business will
     continue as usual” (N.Y. POST, 11/4).

  
15.  STERN REAFFIRMS HORNETS RETURNING HOME FULL TIME NEXT SEASON
          NBA Commissioner David Stern, who attended last night’s
     Rockets-Hornets game in New Orleans, “reaffirmed the Hornets
     are returning full time next season” to the city, according
     to Benjamin Hochman of the New Orleans TIMES-PICAYUNE.  Last
     night’s game sold out, and Hornets Owner George Shinn said
     only five of the 56 suites in New Orleans Arena have not
     been sold for the five remaining games scheduled for New
     Orleans this season.  However, Hochman notes “two other
     slippery issues –- minority investors and corporate sponsors
     -– remain” (New Orleans TIMES-PICAYUNE, 11/6).
          ISSUES: Shinn said that he would “like to close a deal
     with a group of minority investors with the financial means
     to buy a 35[%] share” in the team by the end of the year.
     That would create a $50-70M infusion into the team.  Shinn:
     “The investors are important for two reasons.  No. 1 to show
     that local folks think this is a good investment and very
     much want to participate in the team’s success.  No. 2 to
     enlist them as sales people, to tell their friends and
     colleagues this is worthy of your support on a long-term
     basis” (New Orleans TIMES-PICAYUNE, 11/6).  Shinn added that
     if a deal is not reached, “he is prepared to move on by
     refinancing the bank loan he took out to buy out” former
     minority partner Ray Wooldridge’s 35% share for $65M in ‘04.
     Meanwhile, the TIMES-PICAYUNE’s John Reid noted the NBA
     “continues with its efforts to help the Hornets land
     corporate sponsors.”  Shinn said that as of last week, he
     had “received only verbal commitments from some businesses,
     no finalized deal.”  Shinn: “Our plan is not to exit, but we
     need all [the] support we can get.  If we don’t have a
     successful franchise, we all lose” (TIMES-PICAYUNE, 11/5).
     When asked if he was concerned over the club’s long-term
     viability in New Orleans, Shinn said, “Concern, I don’t know
     if that’s the right word.  I’ve got my own opinions on what
     might could happen, but I’m not a politician and I’m not
     going to step on that ground. ... The thing that’s positive
     to me is the will of the people.  We’ve got a job to do and
     we’re going to do it” (DAILY OKLAHOMAN, 11/6).
          WHAT TO WEAR: The TIMES-PICAYUNE’s Reid reported the
     team is considering wearing a special Oklahoma City jersey
     three times this season during games at the Ford Center,
     including tomorrow night’s home opener at the arena against
     the Warriors.  Other games being considered are February 14
     against the Kings and the April 13 regular-season finale
     against the Nuggets.  The team will wear during all games a
     patch representing either New Orleans or Oklahoma City; the
     club will wear a New Orleans jersey with an OKC patch for
     all road games (New Orleans TIMES-PICAYUNE, 11/5).

  
16.  BRIAN DAVIS, LOCAL GRIZZLIES OWNERS MEET TO TALK SPECIFICS
          An hour-and-a-half meeting Friday with prospective
     Grizzlies Majority Owner Brian Davis was “less enlightening
     than local minority-share owners had hoped,” as Davis and
     partner Christian Laettner “didn’t unveil their full group
     and financial specifics,” according to David Williams of the
     Memphis COMMERCIAL APPEAL.  Investor J.R. Hyde III said,
     “They assured us they will get us that information very
     shortly.”  Williams noted the local group must decide by
     December 1 whether it wants to buy out current Majority
     Owner Michael Heisley’s 70% share for $252M.  If not, the
     Davis group “could proceed with its plan” to buy the club.
     Davis said that his group “draws from the NFL, Hollywood and
     institutional investors,” but Williams noted the group’s
     composition “remains largely a mystery.”  Heisley said that
     he “remains ‘absolutely’ convinced the sale will happen, if
     the local group doesn’t step up.”  Heisley: “We wouldn’t
     have gotten involved if we didn’t think [Davis] could do the
     thing.  I’m not that stupid. ... We’ve met some of his
     people and we feel confident that they will perform on the
     contract.”  Hyde said that the local group “knows some, but
     not all, of Davis’ partners.”  Hyde: “We’re still in the
     process of evaluating them as partners here in Memphis,
     versus exercising the (right-of-first-refusal).  Brian comes
     across as a very nice guy with a genuine interest in the
     team and the city” (Memphis COMMERCIAL APPEAL, 11/4).

  
17.  MAPLE LEAFS CONTRIBUTING MOST TO NHL REVENUE-SHARING FUND
          Maple Leafs GM John Ferguson said that the Maple Leafs
     “put more money –- between [US$9-10M] -- into the NHL’s
     revenue-sharing fund than any other team in the league,”
     according to Kevin McGran of the TORONTO STAR.  Ferguson:
     “That was more money than we originally projected.  Our
     percentage was not a function of revenue.  It’s just the
     formula.”  McGran notes the NHL “collected [US$96M] from
     high-revenue teams like the Leafs, national TV contracts,
     and playoff revenue,” and over the weekend, the league
     “began distributing cash to the lowest-revenue clubs,
     believed to be between 11 and 15 teams.”  NHL Deputy
     Commissioner Bill Daly: “The exact distribution and identity
     of the teams who are revenue sharing recipients is not
     something we disclose publicly.  But, yes, we are very
     satisfied with the manner in which our new revenue-sharing
     system operated in its first year” (TORONTO STAR, 11/6).

  
18.  FUNDING PLAN FOR NBA KINGS ARENA APPEARS POISED FOR DEFEAT
          The plan to build a new NBA Kings arena is “headed for
     defeat by a ‘phenomenally high’ margin,” according to a new
     poll of 600 registered voters conducted October 26-30 and
     cited by Vellinga & Hardy of the SACRAMENTO BEE.  Opposition
     to Measures Q and R “has swelled since a Bee poll in
     September, while support has remained static.”  In the most
     recent poll, 67% said they planned to vote “no” on Measure
     R, which “would raise the county sales tax by a quarter
     cent,” up from 58% in the earlier survey.  Only 21% said
     they would vote “yes” on R, down from 23% in the previous
     poll.  Measure Q “is an advisory measure that asks voters
     whether they like the idea of spending half the money raised
     by Measure R on an arena and the other half on community
     projects.”  Cheryl Katz, VP of Baldassare & Associates,
     which conducted the poll, said that the “momentum is ‘all
     negative.’”  Katz: “It’s unusual to see a measure this
     lopsided.”  But Kings President John Thomas said that he
     “agreed with NBA Commissioner David Stern, who said he
     didn’t believe people should be expected to vote for
     something they don’t understand.”  Thomas: “Voters don’t
     know what they’re being asked to vote on.”  Yes on Q&R
     spokesperson Doug Elmets noted that “sports funding
     proposals often take ‘a couple of election cycles’ to pass”
     (SACRAMENTO BEE, 11/4).
          CUP OF JOE: Kings co-Owner Joe Maloof said of the
     Carl’s Jr. spot that shows the Maloof brothers eating
     hamburgers with a $6,000 bottle of wine, “The people who
     don’t want an arena made a big issue out of it.  But the
     thing is, this is exactly who we are.  We ride around in
     limousines, but we eat hamburgers.  We weren’t any different
     when we first moved here, and everybody thought we were
     great.”  Maloof was asked, “Why did you stop hanging around
     town?”  Maloof: “I know it’s part of the game, but I just
     got tired of getting beat up all the time in the newspaper
     and on the radio.  For some reason, no one wanted to hear
     our point of view.”  Maloof: “The No. 1 point we failed to
     get across is that the Maloofs are not going to make a
     tremendous windfall here. ... You can only raise ticket
     prices so much, which is why you need the parking and the
     other revenue.”  Maloof, on the expected defeat of Measures
     Q and R: “People are disgusted. A lot of it will be a
     negative vote, caused by some things that aren’t right. We
     got a bad rap” (SACRAMENTO BEE, 11/6).
          LOAN TERMS: In a separate piece, the BEE’s Hardy &
     Vellinga cited documents as showing that arena supporters’
     hopes of moving forward with arena plans for the downtown
     railyard “even if the [Maloofs] don’t participate,” could
     “cost the city” $70M.  A stipulation approved by the
     Sacramento City Council in a ’97 loan agreement would allow
     the Kings to “walk away from repayment if the city or county
     helps finance an arena and then offers better terms to
     another major league sports franchise playing or planning to
     play in the Sacramento area or Yolo County.”  Sacramento
     City Attorney Eileen Teichert: “It’s somewhat like an option
     or first right of refusal.”  Thomas said, “This is the first
     time I’m hearing about it” (SACRAMENTO BEE, 11/4).

  
19.  TIMING OF JOB FOR NY ASSEMBLY SPEAKER’S DAUGHTER QUESTIONED
          New York state Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver’s
     daughter, Esti Fried, “was hired as a temporary office
     worker at [Madison Square Garden] the summer of 2003,” as
     “the battle over a West Side Stadium plan was just heating
     up,” according to Tom Topousis of the N.Y. POST.
     Cablevision, which owns MSG, spent $34M on “lobbying and
     advertising to block the project.” The $2.2B stadium plan
     for the Jets won every government approval, except “that of
     the Public Authorities Control Board, where Silver has a
     deciding vote.”  Fried, who was hired when she was seven
     months pregnant and made about $15 an hour in the job, was
     hired also as “plans were being formulated to convert the
     Farley Post Office into the Moynihan Train Station, a
     $900[M] project that could also serve as a site for a new”
     MSG.  While one source said Fried’s hiring was “under a
     directive ‘that came from the top,’” MSG Senior VP/Corporate
     Communications Barry Watkins said, “She was well qualified
     for the position and did an excellent job in her time with
     the company.”  A spokesperson for Silver could not be
     reached for comment (N.Y. POST, 11/6).


  
20.  ANAHEIM CONSIDERING CONDO PLAN ON POSSIBLE NFL SITE
          Anaheim officials said that a 50-acre plot “touted as
     the possible site for [an NFL] team stadium could instead
     become home to condominiums, a hotel and low-cost housing,”
     according to McKibben & Powers of the L.A. TIMES.  The $80M
     proposal from California-based SunCal, which values the land
     at $30M more than the city’s own appraisal, is “one of
     several the city has received since announcing that after
     two years of wrangling with the [NFL], it would entertain
     developers’ ideas for the land.”  Anaheim City Council
     member Richard Chavez said, “I believe the City Council is
     sending a strong message to the NFL that we’re serious about
     further development.  If we don’t hear from them, I’m sure
     council is ready to move forward without them.”  City
     Council member Lorri Galloway added, “It would still be a
     good idea to have an NFL stadium, but what’s not a good idea
     is to wait forever.  We can’t wait for the NFL so long that
     this highly valuable land goes stagnant” (L.A. TIMES, 11/5).

  
21.  FACILITY NOTES
          In Boston, Mike Reiss reports a new synthetic grass
     field in Brookline, Massachusetts, has been named The Kraft
     Family Athletic Facility at Harry Downes Field.  The Kraft
     family donated $400,000 for the field, while the NFL gave
     $200,000 (BOSTON GLOBE, 11/6).
          ISLAND DREAMS: In N.Y., Joseph Barracato reported
     Mandalay Entertainment Group has been hired to promote the
     7,500-seat Richmond County Bank Ballpark, home of the Single-
     A N.Y.-Penn League Staten Island Yankees.  Mandalay Chair &
     CEO Peter Guber “plans to target the business world of lower
     Manhattan” for sponsors (N.Y. POST, 11/5).  Mandalay
     Baseball is also taking over management of the team, in
     which the Yankees have purchased a majority stake (THE
     DAILY).
          TRACK-ING DEVICE: LOCOG Chair Sebastian Coe has
     “effectively ruled out the prospect” of Premier League club
     West Ham United “moving into a new Olympic Stadium by
     placing a prohibitive [US$190.1M] price tag on the project.”
     Coe said that “none of the prospective tenants ... are
     ‘remotely in the same ball park’ when it comes to financing
     such a move.”  He also said that he would “stick by his
     pledge to the [IOC] that athletics rather than [soccer]
     would take precedence on the site at all times” (London
     DAILY MAIL, 11/5).
          BRIGHT LIGHTS: Cable distributor Bright House Networks
     will sponsor the 600-member Legends Club at Conseco
     Fieldhouse during Pacers games through the ’08-09 season.
     The company will provide “wireless Internet service, [HDTV]
     and other high-tech services for use by members” during
     Pacers and WNBA Fever games (INDIANAPOLIS STAR, 11/4).

  
22.  BREEDERS’ CUP WAGERING SETS NEW RECORD; DEATH MARS EVENT
          Preliminary wagering totals from all common pool
     sources for Saturday’s Breeders’ Cup World Championships at
     Churchill Downs established a new Breeders’ Cup record of
     $136.7M, breaking the old mark of $124M set last year at
     Belmont Park.  The figure does not include separate pool
     wagering and some international wagering outlets.  A record
     on-track total of $18.3M was wagered, breaking the previous
     Breeders’ Cup record of $16.3M set in ’03 at Santa Anita
     (NTRA).  The crowd of 75,132 was the third-largest in the
     event’s 23-year history, behind 80,452 in ’98 and 76,043 in
     ’00, both at Churchill Downs (COURIER-JOURNAL, 11/5).
          TWO YEARS AND COUNTING:  The THOROUGHBRED TIMES’ Mike
     Curry noted Churchill Downs again “could host the Breeders’
     Cup in just two years.”  Breeders’ Cup VP/Event Management
     Damon Thayer said Churchill Downs has the “infrastructure
     and facility to host the event, frankly, better than any
     other facility in the country.”  NTRA & Breeders’ Cup Ltd.
     CEO Greg Avioli said, “We are already in discussions with
     (Churchill Downs President) Steve Sexton.  Nothing has been
     finalized, but we’re looking at coming back as early as
     2008.”  Thayer noted “options are limited with the New York
     Racing Association filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and no
     timetable for expanding the turf course at Del Mar”
     (THOROUGHBRED TIMES, 11/5).
          TRAGEDY AT THE TRACK: In L.A., Robyn Norwood noted Pine
     Island pulled up lame during the Breeders’ Cup Distaff on
     Saturday and was later euthanized.  A second horse, Fleet
     Indian, also pulled up, but “her injuries were not life-
     threatening and she was scheduled to retire to become a
     broodmare at the end of the year” (L.A. TIMES, 11/5).  In
     Philadelphia, Mike Jensen wrote Saturday “turned into
     another sad day for a sport.”  The death “cast a shadow on
     the main event,” the Breeders’ Cup Classic, “which turned
     out to be a blockbuster” (PHIALDELPHIA INQUIRER, 11/5).  In
     N.Y., Joe Drape wrote under the header, “Death Overshadows
     Upset Of Bernardini In The Breeders’ Cup” (N.Y. TIMES,
     11/5).  Prior to the injuries to Pine Island and Fleet
     Indian, veterinarian Rick Fischer said of the need for a
     hospital at Churchill Downs, “We’re gonna get egg on our
     face here one day.  It’s just a matter of time when one of
     these Breeders’ Cup horses has something happen to them, and
     they die on the way to Lexington instead of being able to go
     right to a hospital built on the grounds, or close to the
     grounds anyway.”  Sexton said he does not believe a hospital
     is “mandatory. ... There’s a higher degree of veterinary
     care within a very short distance here than almost any
     track, including those who have facilities on property.”  In
     Louisville, Gregory Hall noted a $7M hospital is planned
     across from Belmont Park, the site of four Breeders’ Cup
     championships (COURIER-JOURNAL, 11/4).
          RULING FAMILY: USA TODAY’s Tom Pedulla reports the
     ruling Maktoum family of Dubai “completed a sensational
     season that may signal future dominance” when Invasor and
     Bernardini gave them a 1-2 finish in the Classic.  Invasor
     won for Sheik Hamdan bin Rashid Al Maktoum, who had won the
     Belmont Stakes with Jazil.  Bernardini, who gave the
     Maktoums their first Triple Crown victory when he won the
     Preakness, is owned by Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum,
     Sheik Hamdan’s younger brother.  Shadwell Farm GM Rick
     Nichols said, “The al Maktoum family is going to be a force
     to be reckoned with for a long time” (USA TODAY, 11/6).

  
23.  NONREFUNDABLE PROCESSING FEE HELPS FUND N.Y. MARATHON
          About $360,000 of the ING N.Y. Marathon’s funding “came
     from a nonrefundable $9 processing fee paid by the tens of
     thousands of runners who tried to get into the field but
     were denied,” according to Jennifer Blecher of the N.Y.
     TIMES.  More than 90,000 applicants tried to get into the
     field, of which 50,000 were accepted and 37,000 were
     expected to run the race.  N.Y. is “unique among the major
     marathons in charging processing fees to runners who are not
     selected in its lottery system.”  N.Y. Road Runners
     President & CEO Mary Wittenberg said that the processing
     expenses are “largely a staffing issue.”  Blecher noted the
     marathon has 12 full-time employees who handle applications
     and customer service. Wittenberg: “We could easily drop that
     fee and raise the entry fee.  But this works fine. I don’t
     remember ever receiving a complaint.” However, Blecher wrote
     some runners who were not chosen in the lottery “said they
     should be reimbursed.”  Wittenberg said that fees, including
     $15 for a shuttle to the starting area on race day, “covered
     about half of the marathon’s [$15-18M] budget, with the rest
     covered by sponsors and advertisers” (N.Y. TIMES, 11/4).
          HOW DID YOU DO? Did you run Sunday’s N.Y. Marathon?
     Was your goal finishing your first marathon, setting a
     personal best or raising money for charity?  If you were one
     of the 35,000 running across the Verazano-Narrows Bridge on
     Sunday morning, we’d like to hear from you.  Send us your
     time and any other anecdotes for possible publication at
     editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com.

  
24.  EXECUTIVE TRANSACTIONS
          Nike VP/Global Marketing JOAQUIN HIDALGO will add the
     additional duties of overseeing an integrated consumer-
     focused growth strategy for soccer.  Nike said his goal is
     to achieve “clear Nike brand dominance by 2010” (Nike).
          AGENCIES: In this week’s SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL, Terry
     Lefton reports Octagon has promoted BILL HART to National
     Sales Manager for Athletes & Personality marketing.  Also,
     former Relay exec JIM KENYON was named Managing Partner of
     Gravitas, a marketing agency started in partnership with
     Chicago-based ad agency Schafer Condon Carter.  Meanwhile,
     former SI marketer MERRILL SQUIRES sold a minority interest
     in his five-year-old Squires Sports Group to Hawkeye FFWD
     and will head the company’s new sports and entertainment
     division (SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL, 11/6 issue).
          EXECS: Sirius Satellite Radio named DANIEL NORWOOD,
     Exec Producer for WFNZ-AM’s “Prime Time with the Packman,”
     Exec Producer of its new NASCAR channel.  Norwood will be
     based in Charlotte and “be instrumental in programming the
     new channel” (CHARLOTTE OBSERVER, 11/4)....USA Boxing named
     JOHN STAVROS acting Exec Dir while the NGB conducts a search
     for a permanent candidate (AROUND THE RINGS, 11/3
     issue)....The Hurricanes named former NHLer RON FRANCIS Dir
     of Player Development (Hurricanes).

          Do you have an executive announcement? If so, please
     send to editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com.

  
25.  NAMES IN THE NEWS
          SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL’s Liz Mullen reports CREATIVE
     ARTISTS AGENCY has signed its first basketball client, Heat
     President & coach PAT RILEY, and will explore off-the-court
     opportunities for him (SPORTSBUSINESS JOURNAL, 11/6 issue).
          SPORTS & ENTERTAINMENT: In N.Y., Peter Lauria cited
     sources as saying that Redskins Owner DAN SNYDER “has been
     actively meeting with Hollywood talent agencies ... to get
     advice about how to break into the film business.”   His
     talks “are aimed to be both tutorial sessions” and a “chance
     to network with the creative forces that drive the industry”
     (N.Y. POST, 11/5)....Clippers F ELTON BRAND will be profiled
     in an upcoming episode of Cartoon Network’s “Lifestyles,” in
     which subjects explain “how they achieved success and what
     kids can do to prosper” (L.A. TIMES, 11/6).
          NAMES: Jaguars Owner WAYNE WEAVER and his wife,
     DELORES, listed their home for $10M.  The couple paid $2.4M
     for a riverfront condo in Jacksonville in April (FLORIDA
     TIMES-UNION, 11/4)....MIKE DITKA has partnered with
     California-based MENDOCINO WINE CO. to produce five wines.
     A red blend called Mike Ditka Kick Ass Red will cost $40-50,
     a chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon will cost $15-17 and a
     merlot and pinot grigio will be $10-12 (CHICAGO SUN-TIMES,
     11/6)....Former NFLer EMMITT SMITH is partnering with
     CYPRESS EQUITIES, an affiliate of HOFer ROGER STAUBACH’s
     real estate company, on a proposed 237,738-square-foot
     retail center in Phoenix (ARIZONA REPUBLIC, 11/6)....The
     crowd of 9,427 at the FLOYD MAYWEATHER JR.-CARLOS BALDOMIR
     fight at Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas on Saturday night
     included MICHAEL JORDAN, MAGIC JOHNSON, TIGER WOODS, REGGIE
     JACKSON and SYLVESTER STALLONE (USA TODAY, 11/6).
          BOOK SHELF: LEIGH STEINBERG, the agent for suspended
     Dolphins RB RICKY WILLIAMS, said that Williams “soon will co-
     author a book on his life” (MIAMI HERALD, 11/5)....SI’s JACK
     MCCALLUM has written “:07 SECONDS OR LESS: MY SEASON ON THE
     BENCH WITH THE RUNNIN’ AND GUNNIN’ PHOENIX SUNS,” an inside
     look at the Suns during the ’05-06 season (THE
     DAILY)....Former St. John’s basketball player GUS ALFIERI
     has written “LAPCHICK: THE LIFE OF A LEGENDARY PLAYER AND
     COACH IN THE GLORY DAYS OF BASKETBALL,” about former St.
     John’s coach JOE LAPCHICK. The book is being published by
     The Lyons Press (N.Y. TIMES, 11/5).

          The following lists overnight Nielsen ratings from

28.  DECEMBER 4 SBJ IN-DEPTH EXAMINES COLLEGIATE SPORTS
          What’s new in the business of college sports?
     SportsBusiness Journal looks at key business areas in
     collegiate sports and examines how colleges and conferences
     are positioning themselves in the marketplace to take
     advantage of opportunities. With athletic department budgets
     growing increasingly tighter, the pressure is on schools to
     find new revenue streams yet balance their needs with calls
     on campus to limit commercialization. With the college bowl
     season just around the corner, what creative activation do
     sponsors have in the works and how do media partners plan to
     market the events? Publishing Date: December 4.  Ad Close
     Date: November 20.  For information on advertising contact
     National Advertising Director Julie Tuttle at 212-500-0711
     or jtuttle@sportsbusinessjournal.com.


                               -30-

title: Daily-Testimonials
body:
Read what some of the top executives in the industry are saying about SportsBusiness Daily. If you would like to see for yourself just how valuable this publication can be for you, register now for a free trial subscription.

“SportsBusiness Daily has become an invaluable tool for keeping one's finger on the pulse and direction of the business of sports. There is no fluff. Information is condensed into highly readable summaries with interesting and sometimes amazing quotes. References are provided so that the full, original articles can be obtained when desired. The business of sports is never boring. Thanks for providing me daily news in a format that is perfect for a busy executive.”

— John Henry, Owner, Boston Red Sox

"I make it my business to check SportsBusiness Daily every day."

— David Hill, Chairman & CEO, Fox Sports Networks

"With time being my most precious commodity, SportsBusiness Daily is required reading. It gives me just enough of the right information to stay on top of our industry’s most important developments. I make it a point not to miss an issue."

— Don Garber, Commissioner, Major League Soccer

"I rely on SportsBusiness Daily as much as I rely on the New York Times or any other publication, in fact, I probably rely on it more. To me, it is as essential and useful of a tool as I have at my disposal."

— Jon Miller, Senior VP/Programming, NBC Sports

"I read SportsBusiness Daily everyday. It's an invaluable source of information on the business."

— Tim Brosnan, Exec VP/Business, Major League Baseball

"In looking after the business interests of Visa Member banks, I have to stay on top of the industry and its trends. SportsBusiness Daily provides me with a comprehensive summary of news that I wouldn't have time to access on my own. I make it a point to read my SBD each and every day."

— Michael Lynch, Senior VP Event & Sponsorship Marketing, Visa USA

"Everyone in the business is reading SportsBusiness Daily. If you are not, why not?"

— Gene Upshaw, Executive Director, NFL Players Association

"The Daily provides unprecedented access to information in a concise format. Its brevity is key."

— Ed Goren, President & Executive Producer, Fox Sports

"There is one place for 'one stop shopping' in the sports industry, and that place is SportsBusiness Daily. Whether it's television, new media, sponsorships or other industry trends, SportsBusiness Daily tells me what I need to know concisely and quickly. It is essential reading for everyone who needs to stay on top of what is going on in the business."

— J. Pierce O'Neil, Chief Business Officer, USTA

"I don’t have time to read everything that comes to me. SportsBusiness Daily is the first ‘must read’ document that reaches me every day. It summaries everything I need to know about sports business on a daily basis."

— W. James Host, CEO, Host Communications

"Quite simply, SportsBusiness Daily provides the most comprehensive coverage of our industry. It's a vital tool for everyone in the business of sports."

— Ed Horne, President of NHL Enterprises

"There are few essentials in the sports marketing business. SportsBusiness Daily is one of them. It's a treasure chest of facts, industry insights, and professional perspective. It's must reading for anyone who wants to get ahead in this business."

— Dean Bonham, Chairman & CEO, The Bonham Group

"SportsBusiness Daily is the Wall Street Journal of the sports industry. The chessboard of the sports business is complicated. If you don’t see all of the news and analysis in one place, it’s difficult to predict trends and stay ahead of the curve. There is no other publication that serves this function for the sports sponsor, marketing or business professional."

— Donna Lopiano, Ph. D., Executive Director, Women’s Sports Foundation

"SportsBusiness Daily is concise, to the point and a quick way to keep up with the sports industry on a daily basis. I look forward to each issue."

— John Wildhack, Senior VP/Programming, ESPN Inc.

"SportsBusiness Daily's compilation of news from around the country is absolutely essential to my television sports consulting business. How did we survive before cell phones, lap tops, palm pilots and SportsBusiness Daily?"

— Neal Pilson, President, Pilson Communications

"SportsBusiness Daily is essential reading for anyone connected to the business of sports. The Daily informs you on the development of new concepts on all fronts, while providing important industry feedback in real time."

— Dennis Mannion, Senior VP/Business Ventures, Baltimore Ravens

"I start each day by reading SportsBusiness Daily. The information contained in The Daily has such a major value to me and the work of the Center for the Study of Sport in Society. It is not only a quick yet thorough summary of everything that is important in the world of sport but it also helps me put the news in a context for me to be effective when I talk about sport in society."

— Dr. Richard Lapchick, Director, Northeastern University Center for the Study of Sport in Society

"It’s difficult to read everything related to the sports industry. I trust and rely on SportsBusiness Daily to give me pertinent information – and it has not let me down yet."

— Hank Adams, CEO, Sportivision

"SportsBusiness Daily is an indispensable tool. It connects you very efficiently every day with all the key issues in the industry. For our office, it's a must-read."

— Greg Aiello, VP/Public Relations, National Football League

"Information is power. With the amount of information in each issue of SportsBusiness Daily, I think it’s fair to call it an extremely powerful tool."

— Doug Pirnie, Senior VP, IMG

"It's impossible to read everything in my business. But one publication that I have to read every day is SportsBusiness Daily. It cuts through all the news clutter for me, and just gives me the information that I need to know. It's a competitive advantage."

— Reggie Williams, VP, Disney Sports Attractions

"If you are in the sports industry, you have to read each issue of SportsBusiness Daily. There is no other news source that is as comprehensive, informative or real-time."

— John Moag, Chair, Moag & Co.

"I find an average of three or four stories per day in SportsBusiness Daily that wind up on my television, radio, or Internet reports. The only entity comparable in terms of comprehensiveness is The Associated Press.

— Keith Olbermann, sports commentator

"I'm biased, but SportsBusiness Daily is the premier source of news and information about the sports industry. If you're not reading The Daily every day, you're not in the game."

— Jeffrey Pollack, Founder, SportsBusiness Daily & Managing Director of New Media, NASCAR

"Without question, reading SportsBusiness Daily is a vital part of my business day. It enables me to get the latest sports industry news quickly."

— Neal Tiles, Exec VP, Marketing, DirecTV

"The speed and complexity of today’s event marketplace makes thorough and timely industry information a strategic imperative. SportsBusiness Daily delivers for us – it’s a must read."

— Jim Millman, Chair & CEO, Millsport LLC

"Working for a non-profit with limited staff and international reach, I find SportsBusiness Daily a great tool to stay current on the business side of athletics in a short amount of time. It contains a great deal of timely information in a very concise format."

— Jon Butler, Executive Director, Pop Warner Little Scholars/
Pop Warner Football

“SportsBusiness Daily is a valuable informational tool for our sales and marketing company. The concise style and format employed by The Daily allows us to keep abreast of industry news to effectively manage our time.”

— T.J. Nelligan, President & CEO, Nelligan Sports Marketing

“I find SportsBusiness Daily to be indispensable. I review it every day to keep on top of this ever-growing, ever-changing industry.”

— James M. Kahler, Exec Dir MBA Sports Business Program, AZ State Univ.

“SportsBusiness Daily is a quick way to stay on the pulse of the sports business world.”

— Lydia Stephans, President & Executive Producer, Oxygen Sports

“SportsBusiness Daily is the ultimate source for sports business information. It is so indispensable that those that don't read it everyday are vulnerable in today's fast paced and fiercely competitive sports business world."

— David M. Carter, Principal, The Sports Business Group

“SportsBusiness Daily is like the stock ticker for our industry: Right to the point; Just the facts; Up-to-date. It's indispensable."

— David Grant, Founding Principal, Velocity Sports & Entertainment

“SportsBusiness Daily is a must read if you want to stay ahead of the game. With the face of sports changing constantly, the easy access through the Internet and their e-mail distribution is second to none. Everyone at Comcast-Spectacor makes it a priority to read it every day.

— Peter Luukko, President, Comcast-Spectacor Ventures

"Traveling around the world on business can be unpredictable. But one constant for me is SportsBusiness Daily. I can easily access all the news, information and research online -- no matter where I am. I have relied upon it for years and I don't know what I would do without it."

— Marc Ganis, President & CEO, Sportscorp Ltd.

title: Archive
body:
Archive FAQ's

1.

What are the basic keyword search tips?
2.
 How does the search system work?
3.
 How do I print a story from the archives?
4.
 How do I access a complete past issue of The Sports Business Daily?
5.
How do I use the calendar search?
6.
Can I generate a combined search using any of the fields (such as team, sport, etc.)?
7.
 What is the user agreement for reprinting stories from The Sports Business Daily or The Sports Business Daily Insider?
8.

Where do I direct questions on how to use the archives?


1. What are the basic keyword search tips?

To search, you can enter a word or words in the keyword box and use either any word, all words or whole phrase to refine your search.

The whole phrase search method looks for the exact phrase you type into the search box.
 
An all words query will return results containing at least one occurrence of every single one of the keywords or phrases you enter.
 
An any word query will return results containing at least one occurrence of at least one of the keywords or quote phrases you enter. This is the least specific type of search.

*NOTE: The archive search will not recognize a limited number of words that have been removed from the search list. The following includes a full alphabetical listing of words that will show no results when searched. Please avoid using these words when using the all words prompt.

Keywords should include words that you feel are vital to the story that you want from our database. The keywords could appear either in the story headline, text or source credit. The search system is not case sensitive. Entering "Nike" will search for "Nike", "nike", and "NIKE".

Refine your search further by selecting to search a particular section of or either:

- The Sports Business Daily or The Daily Insider
- The Sports Business Daily
- The Daily Insider

In addition, you can specify a sport, company or team to search by, and the time period in which the article was published. You can select a specific category by checking or unchecking with the CTRL key.

RETURN TO TOP


2. How does the search system work?

The default action of the Advanced Search page is Any Word. This is not a boolean search, so the system will search for words like "AND", "OR", "NOT" that are put in the search string.

EXAMPLE: If a user puts in the search term, "Cowboys not stadium", the system would offer the following results:

 ALL WORDS: Matches any articles containing some form of "Cowboys", "not", and "stadium". The words may not be near one another or in any order, the only criteria is that all three words (in some form, even as parts of other words) must be in an article, to result in a match.
 
ANY WORD: Matches any articles containing any or all (but at least one) of some form of "Cowboys", "not", or "stadium".
 
WHOLE PHRASE: Matches any articles containing the entire phrase as it is typed (spaces are counted also) in a case insensitive manner. "Cowboys not stadium" will match "Cowboys not stadium", "COWBOYS NOT STADIUM" or "cowboys not stadium".

SEARCH BY TOPIC:

Items appearing in The Sports Business Daily from January 2001 to the current issue have been categorized by certain industry subjects.

*NOTE: Issues from 1994 through 2000 are not searchable using the topic categories. Please use the keyword search for best results.

SEARCH RESULTS:

Search results will list feature articles with the story headline, the first few sentences of the story, section of the publication, and issue date and publication the item appeared in.

EXAMPLE:

Click on the headline to read the full story. The full text of these stories is only accessible to subscribers of The Sports Business Daily. You can register now for a free trial subscription. If you want full access to our archives, please complete your subscription by calling our sales department at (704) 973-1500.

By default:

 Articles are sorted by the most recent story first. You can change that function with the Sort By feature.
The first ten articles of a search request are displayed on a page. However, a user can change that with the How Many Items Listed feature

RETURN TO TOP

3. How do I print a story from the archives?

If you wish to print the article after viewing the entire text, just click on the Print This Story feature on the lower right-hand side of the story.

RETURN TO TOP

4. How do I access a complete past issue of The Sports Business Daily?

If you are interested in getting a complete online issue of The Sports Business Daily for a specific date, use the Specific Issue Calendar box to select the year, month and day. This will provide all the headlines and stories posted to the online edition for that date.

RETURN TO TOP

5. How do I use the calendar search?

The calendar search is used when you are looking for an article within a particular time period. You will want to use either the From/To search or the Specific Issue Date search.

 When using either the From/To or the Specific Issue Date search, use the calendar icon to select your dates. *Note: If you type in the date, you may not receive the information you are looking for. Click on the calendar icon to choose your dates.


Use the arrows to find the date you are looking for.

  • Double arrow pointing back = 1 year back.
  • Single arrow pointing back = 1 month back.
  • Single arrow pointing forward = 1 month forward.
  • Double arrow pointing forward = 1 year forward.

RETURN TO TOP

6. Can I generate a combined search using any of the fields (such as team, sport,     etc.)?

The search function is an "OR" function not an "AND" function. The "OR" function means that if you search using a combination of the fields, your results will show AT LEAST one of the fields you searched under, but NOT necessarily all the fields you searched under.

EXAMPLE: You choose to search by sport (Golf), by company (Nike) and by topic (Legal). Your results may be:

1. Only one topic of the three will appear in each article result.
2. Two of the three topics will appear in each article result.
3. All three topics will appear in each article result.

RETURN TO TOP

7. What is the user agreement for reprinting stories from The Sports Business Daily or The Sports Business Daily Insider?
