title: Truth and Rumors - CLIPS
body:
WILLIAM HOUSTON
April 28, 2001
Toronto Globe And Mail

TRUTH & RUMOURS

William Houston's world of sports

Hockey top pitchmen

A survey by The Sports Business Daily, an on-line publication, ranks Pittsburgh Penguin star and part-owner Mario Lemieux as the National Hockey League's most marketable player in the United States.

Lemieux is followed by teammate Jaromir Jagr, Mike Modano of the Dallas Stars, the Florida Panthers' Pavel Bure and Brett Hull of the Stars.

The Daily surveyed more than 60 industry experts, including sports marketers, television and advertising executives and members of the media over the past few months.

Paul Kariya of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks ranks sixth on the new list. He's followed by Mark Messier of the New York Rangers, Devils goalie Martin Brodeur and Joe Sakic of the Colorado Avalanche.

Comments:

Stephen Disson, president and CEO of Disson & Associaties: "Lemieux is the only player, in my opinion, who is marketable nationally in the NHL."

Miami Herald hockey beat writer David Neal said Modano is helped by being an American. "The U.S. is very parochial-minded, we don't connect well with athletes from other countries."

Picket Advertising executive vice-president Bob Dorfman: "If you're peddling product to anyone besides the hockey fanatic, there's really no such thing as a marketable NHL player."

title: The NHL-CLIP
body:
Eric Duhatsche
December 23, 2000
Toronto Globe and Mail

The NHL

The answer: Gretzky, who did it in 234 games. It took Lemieux 287. Most popular sweater Expecting to receive an NHL jersey under the Christmas tree? According to Sports Business Daily, for the second year in a row the most popular sweater sold is the No. 19 of the Detroit Red Wings' Steve Yzerman. Next is the Dallas Stars' Mike Modano, who wasn't even in the top 10 a year ago, followed by LeClair, Hull, Sakic, Jaromir Jagr, Sergei Fedorov, Patrick Roy, Brendan Shanahan and Pavel Bure. With three players in the top 10, it isn't surprising that Red Wings' jerseys sell more than any other in the NHL, followed by the Maple Leafs, the Wild, the Stars, the Flyers, the Avalanche, the Blue Jackets, the Bruins, the Rangers and the Blues.

title: Packers-CLIP
body:
Bob Wolfley
December 21, 2000
The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel

Packers still a contender in the stores

The idea of the Green Bay Packers still grips consumers, even as the reality of the Packers as a contending force has disappeared.

The Packers rank third this year in National Football League merchandise sales, up one spot from the previous season, according to Sports Business Daily.

There is but one other team besides the Packers whose retail allure transcends the loss column.

The Dallas Cowboys remain in the No. 1 spot.

The Tennessee Titans have sprung up to second place, from their No. 9 slot in 1999. The Denver Broncos, who had occupied the second position last season, have fallen to sixth this year.

The Minnesota Vikings rank No. 4, a slot behind Green Bay. The defending champion St. Louis Rams rank fifth, up from No. 8 last season.

Tampa Bay, Oakland and Washington – none of whom were in the top 10 last year, occupy slots seven to nine, respectively. The San Francisco 49ers are at 10, down four places.

Minnesota's Daunte Culpepper, St. Louis' Marshall Faulk, Tennessee's Eddie George, Tampa Bay's Keyshawn Johnson and Minnesota's Randy Moss are the top individual salesmen for the league this year. No Packers player is among the top 10 in player sales this season.

title: Endorsements Tumble-CLIP
body:
Bob Wolfley
October 8, 2000
The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel

Endorsements may be next to tumble

Suzy Favor Hamilton's fall in the 1,500-meter final in the Olympics may result in lessening her endorsement prospects.

In an Olympics short on star power, at least U.S. athletes with star power, Favor Hamilton had been poised to come away a formidable winner at the endorsement cash window. A medal showing no doubt would have given those prospects a boost.

"She is so beautiful and articulate that I'm not sure if it will hold her way back," Rick Burton, director of the University of Oregon's Warsaw Sports Marketing Center, told Sports Business Daily. "But she could have been America's golden girl. She certainly will not get a bump, but that doesn't mean someone will not make an ad to take advantage of the situation."

Burton used to work in Milwaukee for Miller Brewing Co.

But Hamilton likely is better off than another group of athletes at the Games who hurt their chances to win endorsement deals because they behaved badly.

Sprinter Maurice Greene "really may have damaged his marketability," said Bob Dorfman of Picket Advertising. Greene won the fastest man on earth title with his victory in the 100, but he was part of the U.S. relay team that misbehaved after winning the gold medal in the 4x100-meter relay.

"The fact that he goes on national television to apologize is not an attractive scenario for endorsers," said Dorfman. "It's not only what he did in the relay, but just watching him in the blocks and his preening and swaggering, he's like an NBA star."

By not winning gold medals, soccer player Mia Hamm and cyclist Lance Armstrong did not help themselves or add to their already prominent statures.

Of the handful of ad executives that Sports Business Daily surveyed, each named a different athlete when asked to choose one whose marketability improved the most because of Sydney: U.S. pole vaulter Stacy Dragila, U.S. sprinter and long jumper Marion Jones and Australian swimmer Ian Thorpe were among those winning mention. Australia's cultural symbol, Cathy Freeman, U.S. swimmer Lenny Krayzelburg and U.S. wrestler Rulon Gardner also won mention.

title: TV-Radio Notebook-WOODS-CLIP
body:
David Barron
February 28, 2000
Houston Chronicle

TV-Radio Notebook
Astros end midgame shift

Sports Business Daily offers this tidbit on the drawing power of Tiger Woods: For the six PGA events that Woods won in 1999, final-round ratings were up by 45 percent. Final-round numbers were up for eight of the nine events in which he finished higher than in 1998 and were down for all four events in which he failed to live up to his 1998 performance. Numbers also dropped for all three events in which Woods did not play in 1999 after competing in 1998. . . .

title: TV_Radio-Super Bowl-CLIP
body:
David Barron
January 30, 2000
Houston Chronicle

TV-Radio Notebook
SUPER BOWL / Pre-game again excessive, extravagant

We'll be right back – Here are today's Super Bowl advertisers, as compiled by Sports Business Daily. ABC is expected to reap $135 million from in-game sales at an average cost of $2.2 million per 30-second spot, up 38 percent from last year's $1.6 million average on Fox. Running orders are subject to change:

First quarter: Three from Anheuser-Busch for Budweiser and Bud Light, Blockbuster (promoting the release of Runaway Bride), E-Trade, Healtheon/WebMD, John Nuveen (featuring actor Christopher Reeve), Motorola, Monster.com, Pepsi (Mountain Dew), Tropicana, 20th Century Fox, Universal Studios and WebEx.

Second quarter: Two more from Anheuser-Busch for Budweiser, BMW (pushing the X5 and 3Q sports utility vehicles), Dr Pepper (7-Up), Dreamworks (promoting Gladiator), FedEx, General Motors for Oldsmobile, the NFL, Netpliance (reportedly featuring the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders), Oxygen Media (promoting the launch of a new cable network geared toward women), U.S. Census Bureau, Visa and Volvo.

Third quarter: Anheuser-Busch for Budweiser, AutoTrader.com, BMW, Britannica.com (Peter Fonda, Lili Taylor and others ask questions and find answers on the encyclopedia's Web site), Buena Vista Pictures (promoting Mission to Mars), EDS, E-Trade, KForce.com, Hotjobs.com, Motorola, the NFL, OurBeginning.com (promoting wedding strategy), Pepsi for Mountain Dew, Universal Studios and the World Wrestling Federation.

Fourth quarter: Two more for Anheuser-Busch, Computer.com, Epidemic.com, LifeMinders.com, OnMoney.com, Pets.com, MicroStrategy.com, Monster.com, Visa and WSJ (Wall Street Journal) Interactive.

Spots with good pre-game buzz include EDS, which features the tagline "Herdin' cats: Don't let anybody tell you it's easy"; Anheuser-Busch (featuring the "whassssup" greeting, Wayne Gretzky playing designated driver at a bar for a friend who drives a Zamboni and the birth of a Budweiser Clydesdale) and the spot for the John Nuveem investment company, in which Reeve is seen rising from his wheelchair and presenting an award for research that leads to a cure for spinal cord injuries. The tagline is, "In the future, so many amazing things will happen in the world. What amazing thing can you make happen?"

At the other end of the spectrum, LifeMinders.com reportedly spent only $4,800 on its advertisement, which notes that how the company may not know much about advertising, it's a whiz at personalized e-mail.

No word from Channel 13 on advertisers for the local spots, so stay tuned.

title: TV-Radio-Gymnastics
body:
David Barron
July 31, 2000
Houston Chronicle

TV/Radio Notebook
Taped gymnastics event not beyond NBC's power

Sports Business Daily analyzed the three major sports news shows - ESPN's SportsCenter, Fox Sports Net's National Sports Report and CNN/ SI's Sports Tonight - during May to determine how each show allocated its time among sports.

SportsCenter devoted the largest percentage of its time to baseball (24.14 percent to 20.6 for FSN and 21/14 for CNN/SI). FSN led for NBA coverage with 18.62 percent to 17.63 for ESPN and 15.73 for CNN/SI, ESPN was tops in hockey (9.64 percent to 6.76 for CNN/SI and 6.68 for FSN), and CNN/SI was tops for the NFL (4.93 to 2.89 for FSN and 2.32 for ESPN).

In other categories, FSN devoted 4.61 percent of its air time to features compared to only .98 percent for ESPN (no surprise, since ESPN has Baseball Tonight and other sports-specific programs for such items), and CNN/SI was tops in terms of the percentage of time it devoted to horse racing, NASCAR and the PGA Tour.

SBD said perhaps the most interesting element of its analysis was the fact all three networks devoted less than 2 percent of air time to NASCAR, and FSN was at only 0.81 percent. "For all of us to be under 2 percent is an embarrassment," FSN executive producer Scott Ackerson told the newsletter.

title: Jumping Through Hoops-Robb Report-CLIP
body:
Jane Levere
July 1998 issue
The Robb Report

Jumping Through Hoops

It was a defining moment as the final seconds ticked off the clock during last year's inaugural Women's National Basketball Association championship game. At the Summit in Houston, over 16,000 fans roared their approval as the hometown Comets handily dispatched the New York Liberty, 65-51. On the court, dazzling guard and game Most Valuable Player Cynthia Cooper was showered with high fives and hugs. And across America, the game was broadcast live to millions of fans.

While some had questioned the viability of a women's professional league, the scene in Houston proved that women's basketball was very much alive. As the WNBA enters its second season this summer, there undoubtedly will be a groundswell of support for this increasingly popular league. Along with the success of the WNBA come lucrative endorsement deals for players, better salaries, and increased media exposure.

Success isn't restricted to the WNBA. Its rival, the American Basketball League, has attracted support from fans and corporate America.

Some 20 corporate sponsors are shelling out over $75 million to help underwrite both leagues, and ABL and WNBA marquee players are beginning to win lucrative endorsement contracts.

At the same time, though, some question if women can ever command the astronomical salaries and endorsement fees earned by the NBA's marquee players. As the WNBA season takes shape and the ABL gets under way later this year, there are bound to be as many questions about the players' economic futures as there are stories of their breakthrough successes.

LEAGUES OF THEIR OWN

The WNBA, the meticulously packaged and promoted offspring of the 51-year-old National Basketball Association, had a successful inaugural season. The average attendance of 10,000 per game was double the WNBA's expectations. According to the trade publication Brandweek, Spaulding, a WNBA sponsor, sold over 100,000 of the league's signature basketballs in 1997, and Champion, the league's exclusive apparel licensee, sold twice as much licensed clothing as it had anticipated.

The ABL, the lesser-known but arguably more talented women's basketball league that started in 1996, scored well during its recently completed second season. Attendance increased by 23 percent, to 4,300 spectators per game. The ABL's nine teams, which are owned and operated by the league, play in relatively smaller markets like Hartford and Columbus. The WNBA's 10 teams, which are jointly owned by the 29 NBA teams, are operated by individual NBA franchises in such major markets as New York, Los Angeles, and Houston. The ABL does not have the media exposure of the WNBA, whose games are shown on ESPN, Lifetime, and NBC. ABL games are broadcast on Black Entertainment Television and Fox Sports Network.

The ABL also does not have the marketing clout of the WNBA. It spent $3 million to promote itself during its second season, compared to a whopping $15 million reportedly spent by the WNBA during its inaugural season.

Despite these differences, corporate America is paying close attention to both leagues, sponsoring each as a way to promote its brands to the consuming public.

The ABL has eight national sponsors: Borden, First USA Partners, Lady Foot Locker, Nike, Phoenix Mutual Insurance, 24-Hour Fitness, Reebok, and Yahoo. IEG Sponsorship Report, a newsletter that tracks corporate sponsorships, says these sponsors have signed multiyear contracts totaling over $2.5 million annually.

Guided by the well-oiled, world-renowned NBA marketing machine, the WNBA has attracted heavier-hitting, higher-spending sponsors, including Adidas, American Express, Bud Light, Buick Regal, Champion, Coca-Cola, Fila, Kellogg's, Lee Jeans, McDonald's, Nike, Pinnacle, Sears, and Spaulding, in addition to Reebok. Industry officials estimate these companies are collectively shelling out over $75 million on three-year contracts, an unprecedented sum for women's sports sponsorship.

The two leagues aren't the only beneficiaries of this corporate largesse. Individual marquee players from both the ABL and the WNBA are winning lucrative endorsement contracts that are raising their estimated total annual earnings from $500,000 to $1 million.

Like their male counterparts, female basketball players' incomes come from their employers and individual endorsements.

From the start, ABL players have commanded higher salaries than WNBA players. The minimum salary paid by the ABL during its second season was $40,000, and the top was $150,000, compared to the WNBA's second season minimum of $15,000 and high of $62,500.

Reasons for this discrepancy reportedly include the ABL's 20-week-long season compared to the WNBA's 11 weeks. This means that ABL players can't earn second incomes playing overseas during the off-season, unlike WNBA players. The WNBA, with its three television contracts and big-time corporate sponsors, also offers players more media exposure and greater potential for endorsements than does the ABL, making it a more attractive employer despite the salary differential.

This media exposure and corresponding endorsement potential was apparently a prime factor in guard Nikki McCray's decision to defect this season from the ABL's Columbus Quest to the WNBA's Washington Mystics. Lon Babby, McCray's lawyer, said she switched in part "because she saw tremendous opportunities on and off the court with the WNBA. She felt it was the right move for the time.''

Besides a straight salary, the WNBA also pays each of its four marquee players a six-figure fee for doing personal appearances, a system that has not been adopted by the ABL. The quartet is composed of McCray, center Lisa Leslie of the Los Angeles Sparks, center Rebecca Lobo of the New York Liberty, and forward Sheryl Swoopes of the Houston Comets.

RINGING ENDORSEMENTS

Then there is the endorsement income. ABL players with national endorsement contracts include Jennifer Azzi of the San Jose Lasers, who represents Pert Plus shampoo and will soon have her own Reebok shoe; Saudia Roundtree of the Atlanta Glory, who also has a Reebok shoe; Dawn Staley of the Philadelphia Rage, who works with Nike; and Natalie Williams of the Portland Power, who represents Met-Rx, a diet supplement. ABL chief executive officer Gary Cavalli estimates his league's top players earn between $250,000 and $500,000 annually between their salaries and endorsement contracts.

The WNBA players command more substantial sums. Leslie, who is doing endorsements for American Express, Buick Regal, Nike, and Sears, did a onetime promotion for Pepsi last year and is appearing in an Anne Klein campaign this fall. Lobo represents Fleet Bank, Buick Regal, Sears, Mattel, Huffy Sports, Spaulding, and Reebok and says she is now seeking endorsement opportunities among other makers of children's products.

WNBA newcomer McCray has a multiyear shoe and apparel contract with Fila, and is doing a promotion with Frito-Lay. Swoopes, who gave birth to her first child during the WNBA's first season, has had a shoe contract with Nike for the Air Swoopes since 1993, and was the first female athlete to establish such a relationship. In addition, she represents Wilson, Discover card, Kellogg's, Sears, Clean Shower, and Turtle Shells, and has done deals for a phone card, video, book, and a Web site on America Online.

The endorsements fetch large sums of money. For instance, McCray's four-year contract with Fila totals $1 million, according to her agent. Other industry officials estimate the WNBA marquee players earn from $600,000 to nearly $1 million per year.

Just how these endorsements stack up against those of NBA players depends on who's doing the assessing.

"Before last summer, the top women basketball players did virtually nothing,'' says Gary Stevenson, an NBA consultant and former president of the league's marketing and media group. "To go from zero to $1 million in one year, that's exciting.''

The women's actual incomes pale, however, compared to incomes of the top NBA players. According to the most recent Forbes rating of incomes of the top 40 United States athletes-all men-11 were basketball players. Not surprisingly, Chicago Bulls star Michael Jordan topped the list, making an estimated $78.3 million in 1996 from salary and endorsements. Los Angeles Lakers center Shaquille O'Neal was seventh with an income of $25.4 million, while Grant Hill of the Detroit Pistons was number 10, earning $17 million. Other basketball players in the top 40 were Horace Grant, Alonzo Mourning, Juwan Howard, Gary Payton, Hakeem Olajuwon, Dennis Rodman, and Reggie Miller.

When it comes to endorsements, the contracts the WNBA now signs with its players contain restrictive clauses, some of which league officials say are designed to make the WNBA's various sponsorship agreements "ambush-proof.'' Critics, on the other hand, claim these restrictions prevent players from making more money. Specifically, players cannot endorse products on the air that compete with those of league sponsors during the season. For example, they cannot endorse Wheaties in the summertime, since Kellogg's is an official sponsor during that period. Most players also are contractually expected to be available for sponsor-related appearances. Industry observers say they are paid $500 for each appearance, a figure that fluctuates, the WNBA says.

Bruce Levy, a New York-based agent who represents players in both leagues, considers this system unfair. He says it essentially allows sponsors to use players as endorsers without paying them traditional endorsement fees.

Some observers believe the endorsement restrictions could eventually be lifted, to the players' benefit. "If the league survives,'' says Babby, "the players will get more leverage, and I suspect these restrictions will be challenged.''

Jim Andrews, vice president of IEG Sponsorship Report, agrees. "When you try to grow a sport, control has to be given back to the league,'' he says.

UNION TO THE RESCUE?

The formation of a players' union, now under discussion, is one solution to the problem of players' rights and their ability to win control over endorsements. Agents tend to favor unions since they would stand to make more money if players gain leverage over their employers.

There has been speculation that the NBA Players Association, which represents NBA players in union negotiations, could assume the same role for WNBA athletes. Another possible option calls for a group of agents to bargain on behalf of WNBA or ABL players.

Abraham Madkour, editor in chief of Sports Business Daily, does not expect relations between WNBA management and players to crumble and unionization to occur because of disagreements over endorsements and salaries. "There's not great support by women for a union,'' he says. "They're happy to have an opportunity to play. The league wants relations to be conciliatory and it wants to make sure that its marquee players are in the top markets. It behooves both sides to work together.''

Labor issues aside, there is also the question of how effective women basketball players can be as endorsers. Howe Burch, senior vice president of advertising and sports marketing for Fila, a WNBA sponsor, believes that women can succeed as endorsers, but their success will be limited. "Young women are less motivated by athletic heroes than men are,'' he says, adding that company research shows young women admire entertainers and fashion models more than female athletes.

Kenton Edelin, the lawyer for Lobo, Staley, and other ABL and WNBA players, disagrees. "Women can endorse any product you can think of, from TVs to toasters to cars and insurance,'' he says. "Sponsors now understand that women have just as much influence as men over purchasing, so women are in the same position to endorse products as men.''

The discord over the endorsement ability of women is reflected in observers' sharply divided opinions on the long-term earning power of female basketball players.

Echoing the beliefs of many, Madkour expects that while women can eventually crack the Forbes Top 40 athlete list, they won't match the earnings potential of Jordan or O'Neal. "The exposure is not there for women's sports,'' he says. "NBA stars are more popular and have higher name and face recognition than women players, so they're more attractive to companies that want to move their products.''

Leonard Armato, who represents both Los Angeles center counterparts O'Neal and Leslie, disagrees. "Women's basketball is still in its embryonic stages,'' he says. "As women's sports take more of a center stage, and when ratings equal those of men, the money on the court will even out and the money in the marketing world will even out to a large degree.''

Edelin believes women basketball players could earn as much as men within the next 10 years. "For a sponsor, gender is not important-the ability of the person to inspire a consumer to purchase a product is,'' he says. "If you can make 50 million people go and buy a product, whether you're a man or a woman, that has great value to a company.''

Continued exposure on television, he adds, will help female players' prospects. "The more national exposure women receive, the more they can justify the money they receive in endorsements.''

The ABL's Cavalli questions if it would be positive for women to reach the earnings level of men. "I'm not sure it would be healthy,'' he says. "I don't want to see the day when women get a $100 million endorsement contract for five years. A lot of people tell you the NBA is a league of excess, that everything revolves around money. I'm not sure it's a good thing. [Unlike the NBA], our women love the fans, have good relations with management, and are eager to build the sport.''

McCray, of the Washington Mystics, agrees.

"It's very important to kids,'' she says. "We're their future. We have to set standards now for the league to grow. We have to hold up the image, be very clean and positive.''

Regardless of the merits of eight-figure incomes, many expect the success women basketball players achieve as endorsers will improve the earning power of female athletes in other sports.

"Because of women's professional basketball's success, it will drive the market up for all female athletes in the position to get endorsements,'' says Edelin. "The ceiling has been raised for everyone. Sponsors now believe female athletes can sell products just like men have in the past.''

Talent broker Nova Lanktree, president of the Chicago-based Lanktree Sports Celebrity Network, says the success of the WNBA enhances women's sports.

"The way the WNBA is presented and the way players conduct themselves enhances the whole look of women in sports. It's all part of the synergy,'' she says. "The more advertisers observe the public responding in positive ways, the more attractive players will be to them.''

title: Driver Driven To Generosity-CLIP
body:
David Poole
July 27, 2000
Charlotte Observer

DRIVER DRIVEN TO GENEROSITY
HELBERT PUTS A CAP ON YOUNGSTER'S DAY

MAY WE WATCH? The Sports Business Daily, an Internet newsletter that monitors trends in the business side of sports, analyzed the content of three nightly cable sports news shows in May and discovered NASCAR got no better than 1.59 percent of the total air time on any of those shows.

The results surprised even some of the people responsible for those shows, ESPN's
11 p.m. "SportsCenter," CNN/SI's 11 p.m. "Sports Tonight" and Fox Sports Network's
10 p.m. "National Sports Report."

"There's not enough NASCAR coverage in our show," said FSN executive producer Scott Ackerson, whose show devoted 14 minutes, 20 seconds to NASCAR from a monthly total of 18 hours, 45 minutes – or 0.81 percent. "To do less than 1 percent of your show on NASCAR, I know that there are more than 1 percent of the viewers who want NASCAR. Not only for us, but for ESPN and CNN/SI, for all of us to be under 2 percent is an embarrassment."

ESPN devoted the most air time to NASCAR, 27:12, but that was 1.46 percent of its total content of just over 20 hours. CNN/SI gave NASCAR 15:56 out of 11 hours, 22 minutes of content, or 1.59 percent.

Major League Baseball, NBA, NHL and off-season NFL coverage all ranked first through fourth on each show, with coverage of the PGA Tour, horse racing and the future of Indiana basketball coach Bob Knight all drawing more coverage on all three shows than NASCAR.

title: Andretti To Start-CLIP
body:
David Poole
May 28, 2000
Charlotte Observer

ANDRETTI TO START IN TODAY'S RACE DESPITE BROKEN RIB

SPONSOR COSTS: Ever wonder what it costs Coca-Cola to have its name on Winston Cup racing's longest event?

According to research by The Sports Business Daily, a daily newsletter that monitors the American sports industry, Coca-Cola's title sponsorship with Lowe's Motor Speedway averages $2 million per year in a 10-year deal that runs through 2003.

UAW-GM also pays an annual average of $2 million in a five-year deal that expires after this fall's event to sponsor the Charlotte track's October race. And R.J. Reynolds pays $2 million per year in a five-year deal for The Winston that expires next year.

Those $2 million figures include cash paid to the track as well as money for tickets, corporate hospitality, advertising signage and other media expenditures.

The only other deal averaging $2 million annually is a three-year deal between Texas Motor Speedway and DirecTV.

title: Payouts higher than expected-CLIP
body:
Tim Griffin
May 11, 2000
San Antonio Express-News

Payouts higher than expected from Alamo Bowl;
Schools receive over $1.4 million

A sports business analyst said the 1999 Sylvania Alamo Bowl's payout is a promising sign for the local game.

Penn State and Texas A&M will receive checks of $1.478 million from the game, which attracted a sellout crowd of 65,380 at the Alamodome. The payout was 23.2 percent more than the bowl's projected $1.2 million payment to each team.

"Anytime you overdeliver, you raise the credibility of the event," said Abraham Madkour, editor in chief of The Sports Business Daily. "It bodes well for a bowl game in a tight, oversaturated market. There's an old credo in marketing: It's always good if you can underpromise and overdeliver."

Alamo Bowl executive director Derrick Fox said the record payout was the result of the sellout crowd and Sylvania's record title-sponsorship payment.

The Nittany Lions beat the Aggies 24-0. The game earned a 5.2 television rating, making it the most viewed cable football game of the year and third-most watched bowl game in ESPN history.

"We're very happy with how it all turned out," Fox said. "That's the proof in the pudding of what we've been saying. It speaks well with what San Antonio has been able to do during the bowl's history."

The bowl's previous top payout was $1.273 million in 1995 for a game between Michigan and Texas A&M. That game was the other sellout in the bowl's six-year history.

"I think their profile is good for one of the mid-tier bowls," Madkour said. "The ... game is one of the most successful games that isn't hooked up with the top four (Bowl Championship Series games). The success they've had will only allow them to upgrade the bowl and bring in better teams. It could pave the way to take them to a higher profile in the future."

The 2000 Sylvania Alamo Bowl will be played at 7 p.m. Dec. 30. It will be the only bowl game played on that night, Fox said.

title: The Media Business-CLIP
body:
Jane Levere
August 30, 1999
N.Y. Times

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Tennis group aims campaign at diverse audience to reverse slide in U.S. Open TV ratings.

ORGANIZERS and sponsors of the United States Open tennis tournament are aiming their advertising for this year's event, which begins on Monday in Flushing Meadows, Queens, at a younger, more diverse audience than tennis has traditionally attracted.

Campaigns by both I.B.M. and American Express, sponsors of the Open, feature people of differing races and ages. And the United States Tennis Association, which owns and operates the Open, is running an irreverent, humorous campaign for the tournament that is clearly designed to democratize the image of the sport.

Observers say this strategy is crucial now for the U.S.T.A. In the last 20 years, Nielsen ratings for the United States Open have plummeted from a high of 5.8 in 1981 to a low of 2.3 in 1997; they were 2.8 last year.

“The Open is competing with Major League Baseball, pro football, college football,” said Rick Burton, director of the Warsaw Sports Marketing Center of the Charles H. Lundquist College of Business at the University of Oregon in Eugene. “And it's got image issues. Its positioning is staid – it's Pete Sampras and Lindsay Davenport. They're talented athletes, but they're not very exciting to nontennis aficionados. Tennis needs more people like the Jensen brothers, the Williams sisters, to bring it a distinct personality.”

To develop a more dynamic image for the sport, the tennis association hired Fallon McElligott New York City, a unit of Fallon McElligott, which is known for its irreverent advertising. The agency's executive creative director is Jamie Barrett, who previously worked at Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., on advertising for Nike, the pre-eminent sports marketer, which is also famously irreverent.

Budgeted at a record $2 million, the association's campaign is meant to make the Open “inclusive to all kinds of fans, not just the hard-core tennis enthusiast,” said John Gerzema, managing partner of Fallon McElligott New York City. The campaign includes pictures on New York City buses of different groups of people seated in rows of stadium seats; the side of one bus shows a row of society matrons wearing hats and holding tiny dogs while the other side of the bus shows punk rockers. The ads say the Upper East Side and the East Village, respectively, are “going to the U.S. Open” and ask, “Are you?”

Advertising appearing in commuter trains in the New York metropolitan area repeats this theme, illustrating it, in one case, with a man who could hardly be described as fit leading a step aerobics class. The copy says the regular step aerobics instructor at Equinox, a Manhattan health club, “will be out at the U.S. Open next Thursday” and adds: “You may want to do the treadmill that day. Almost everyone's going to the U.S. Open. Are you?”

On cable, network and local television, the association is running four humorous 30-second spots depicting fictitious tests that compare tennis with various sports: for example, one commercial shows a pair of figure skaters unsuccessfully trying to complete a routine on a hard-surface tennis court. All spots claim nothing beats “the excitement of U.S. Open tennis.”

Like the tennis association, I.B.M. is aiming its U.S. Open advertising at a relatively young group, in this case technologically oriented, Internet-savvy consumers who are potential I.B.M. customers. The advertising is an extension of I.B.M.'s ongoing “e-business” campaign, which uses a red “e” logo to promote Internet-related products and services.

I.B.M.'s Open campaign features striking black and white photographs of youngsters playing tennis in New York City streets. Also in each ad are an inspirational, one-word headline, the red “e” logo and a statement that www.usopen.org, the tennis association's Web site, is “an I.B.M. e-business.” One ad, headed “e-believe,” shows children playing tennis on a sidewalk, a row of garbage cans serving as their net. Another, headed ''e-venus,'' shows two young black girls, seated on a stoop, emulating Serena and Venus Williams by braiding their hair with beads.

I.B.M.'s ads are running on the No. 7 subway line, which serves Flushing, and on outdoor posters in Queens and Manhattan. I.B.M. is also running related advertising, promoting the tennis association's Web site, on radio in New York and six other cities, in tennis publications, and on a variety of Web sites. All work is by Ogilvy & Mather, part of WPP Group.

American Express, another client of Ogilvy & Mather, is adapting its campaign featuring celebrity card holders for the Open. The advertising, which is running in tennis magazines and newspapers like The Wall Street Journal and on the No. 7 subway and billboards in Queens and Manhattan, depicts cardholders Venus Williams, Lindsay Davenport, Murphy and Luke Jensen, John McEnroe and Althea Gibson, who won both Wimbledon and the U.S. Open in 1957 and 1958.

Describing the United States Open as a “demographic hit rather than a mass dump,” Abraham Madkour, editor in chief of The Sports Business Daily, a newsletter, said the event gives American Express an “affluent audience that's a very good fit” and “allows I.B.M. to show off its technology.”

Mr. Burton of the University of Oregon said that although he found the American Express campaign “tired,” he saw I.B.M.'s strategy as “brilliant, because it allows them to marry their E-commerce interests with a new way of looking at tennis.”

He added: “Showing gritty, inner-city visuals instead of country clubs and crisp tennis whites speaks to how things are different. They've got to be cutting-edge for the way E-commerce is moving to reach their target audience.”

Jerry Solomon, president of national broadcast for SFM Media L.L.C., which is owned by Havas/ Media Planning, suggested that the United States Tennis Association, with its campaign, is “trying to bring the U.S. Open down from the elite to the common folk, without losing the elite.”

Mr. Burton, however, questioned whether that would actually be possible. “The U.S.T.A. could be caught in a crossfire, as it tries to reposition itself to a broader audience,” he said. “Down the road, companies like American Express might possibly pull out of their sponsorships if the Open no longer delivers upscale, high-end people.”

title: Between the Lines-CLIP
body:
Ron Rapoport
August 3, 1999
Chicago Sun-Times

BETWEEN THE LINES
One heartless steal vs. Little League team

I'm glad Cade McNown got his voidable years. Here's hoping he's not a voidable quarterback. . . . The St. Louis Post-Dispatch is running a poll asking readers if the Cardinals should trade Mark McGwire. Results so far: "Heck, no!" with 20 percent; "Sure, why not?" with 80 percent. Good thing it wasn't an essay test is all I can say. . . . Now here's the big hurt: Speaking of polls, two years ago, Sports Business Daily asked some experts to name the most marketable baseball players in the country, and Frank Thomas finished behind only Ken Griffey Jr. and Cal Ripken Jr. This year, Thomas didn't get a mention by any of the 90 people questioned. . . . The Seattle Post-Intelligencer says the Mariners have made Griffey an eight-year, $135 million offer, but he is upset the details have leaked out and suspects the team is looking for cover if he opts for free agency. . . . The Denver Post says baseball owners are talking about "dissolving" the Montreal Expos and Minnesota Twins. . . . Only $50 for a pregame party at Hi-Tops, tickets to the Cubs-Astros game Saturday and a contribution to the Jack Brickhouse Memorial Fund for Brain Tumor Reseach. Cheap at twice the price, I'd say. Call (847) 827-9910 for details. You're outta here

title: Stith's Celtic -CLIP
body:
Stith's Celtic status promising
Boston looking for a floor general

Marc J. Spears
April 29, 2001
Denver Post

According to results of a survey by The Sports Business Daily, Lakers guard Kobe Bryant is the NBA's most marketable player. Others in the top five are teammate Shaquille O'Neal, Toronto Raptors forward Vince Carter, Philadelphia 76ers guard Allen Iverson and Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kevin Garnett.

The Sports Business Daily surveyed more than 70 sports marketing, advertising and executives, sports business journalists, NBA observers, other experts and The Denver Post during the past two months.

All were asked, "In your opinion, who are the five most marketable players in the NBA?" In the survey, Bryant received 32 first-place votes and was listed on 89 percent of the ballots.

"Kobe Bryant has all the characteristics that make him appealing to corporate America. He is extremely talented and combines a dazzling presence with a winning smile," said Abraham Madkour, editor of The Sports Business Daily.

"He has the advantage of playing in the Los Angeles market and has helped bring "Showtime' back to Hollywood. He is a natural for any corporation looking for a marketing partner."

Bryant, 22, has endorsement deals with McDonald's, Adidas, Coca-Cola (Sprite), Spalding and Upper Deck, among others.

title: Lemieux urges Jagr-CLIP
body:
Lemieux urges Jagr to raise level of play

Ted Kulfan
April 29, 2001
Detroit News

Most marketable

Who is the NHL's most marketable player?

According to a recent poll by The Sports Business Daily of 60 sports marketing, advertising and public relations executives, the Penguins' Lemieux was the overwhelming choice.

Lemieux had 84 percent of the vote; his teammate, Jagr, had 54 percent, and Mike Modano of the Dallas Stars had 30 percent.

"Mario Lemieux embodies all that corporations look for in a partner," editor-in-chief Abraham Madkour said. "He has a courageous comeback story and led the movement to keep the Penguins in Pittsburgh. He is a good-looking, articulate, family man, a champion on and off the ice and a tremendous ambassador for the game of hockey."

There were no Wings in the top 10, although Fedorov did get a mention – sort of. One respondent had Fedorov and Florida's Pavel Bure tied for fifth, with this explanation: "Any player who dates Anna Kournikova obviously can market himself, and should be on this list by default."

title: Report: Raiders attendance -CLIP
body:
Robert Gammon
January 5, 2001
Oakland Tribune

Report: Raiders attendance occupies cellar of NFL

Even though the Oakland Raiders are in the playoffs for the first time since returning in 1995, and even though Saturday's game against the Miami Dolphins is sold out, a new report shows the team still ranks among the worst when it comes to getting fans to buy tickets.

Of the 31 teams in the National Football League, the Raiders finished 26th in total attendance for the 2000 regular season, selling an average of 57,814 tickets per contest, according to figures compiled by Sports Business Daily and based on NFL statistics.

The results released Thursday also reveal that 92 percent of the seats at Network Associates Coliseum were sold during the season – a percentage that also placed the Raiders 26th in the league.

It wasn't all bad news, however. The team's attendance jumped 16.2 percent in comparison to the 1999 season, when the Raiders drew 49,768 fans per game and the Coliseum was filled only 79 percent of the time. The year-to-year improvement was tops in the AFC and the third best in the NFL.

"They were up from last year and they did pretty well, but they still don't fill up the stadium consistently," said Bill McGrath, media relations manager for the trade publication Sports Business Daily. He noted that the Coliseum's capacity is 63,132.

The team's box office improvement also came as little consolation for Raiders officials, who lamented the relatively low turnout and continue to blame the poor results on the 1995 deal with the city of Oakland and Alameda County.

"Obviously, it's unacceptable," Raiders senior assistant Bruce Allen said of the latest figures. "We were promised a 100 percent (sellout) and that's what we expect."

Moreover, the team's attendance jump this season has had little effect on the mounting taxpayer debt caused by the 1995 deal that brought the Raiders home from Los Angeles. Costs – which were originally supposed to be nothing – are expected to reach $108 million by June 30.

And the only significant way to slow down those expenses is to sell more personal lease licenses – fees Raiders fans pay for the right to buy season tickets.

But as reported by The Oakland Tribune last month, PSL sales have not risen substantially this season, even though the Raiders have had a successful season on the field and sold more single-game tickets than ever before.

Still, local politicians are holding out hope that the Raiders continued improvement on the gridiron eventually will translate into more PSL sales, and in turn, taxpayer relief.

"Hopefully, once they win Saturday, there'll be more demand ... and I think we can not only get more sellouts, but sell more PSLs and season tickets," said Oakland City Council President Ignacio De La Fuente, who is also chairman of the Joint Powers Authority, a city-county hybrid that oversees the Coliseum and its relationship to sports teams.

But the Raiders believe there's a major roadblock to increasing ticket sales: The Oakland Football Marketing Association. The team maintains that the association, which is in charge of selling Raiders tickets and PSLs, is underfunded by the city and county, and as a result, is understaffed and overwhelmed.

Team officials point to two mishaps this week by the association as proof, including the accidental printing of about 500 duplicate playoff tickets mailed by mistake to fans.

According to the report by Sports Business Daily, the average attendance throughout the NFL during the regular season was 65,777, and 94 percent of the total seats in the league were sold during the year. Overall, the NFL set a record for total and average attendance.

The No. 1 team at the box office was the Washington Redskins, followed by the New York Giants, Kansas City Chiefs, New York Jets and Detroit Lions.

The teams that sold 100 percent of all seats were: the Carolina Panthers, Chicago Bears, St. Louis Rams, Philadelphia Eagles, Minnesota Vikings, Baltimore Ravens, Tennessee Titans, New England Patriots and Indianapolis Colts.

And the two teams that beat out the Raiders for the best attendance improvement from 1999 to 2000 were the New Orleans Saints with a 23 percent jump and the Carolina Panthers with a 19.2 percent increase.

title: Parsing Dennis Miller-CLIP
body:
By John F. Thorsberg
October 28, 2000
CBS.MarketWatch.com

Parsing Dennis Miller
Plus: Sideline style and top spectacles

Spectator sports

If you ever wondered why sporting events draw so much support from big spenders like FedEx and Anheuser Busch, here's some statistical information that will put the phenomenon in perspective.

More than 422 million spectators attended sporting events last year in the United States and Canada. According to a study by The Sports Business Daily, an online newsletter, that 422 million figure represents an average of 1.4 sports events attended during the year for each of the 303 million residents of the two countries.

IEG, Inc., the Chicago-based sponsorship consultant, estimates paid sponsorships in North America have grown from $1 billion in 1985 to a projected $8.7 billion this year. Sports accounts for about two thirds of the total.

The five biggest crowd-pleasing sports in order of attendance are: baseball, football, basketball, hockey and horse racing. Here's the rundown of the Top 10 sports on the 1999-2000 season list, as calculated by The Daily:

Not one of the next 10 sports on the list drew more than 1% of total attendance. Those sports ranged from No. 11 rodeo (2.7 million) and No. 12 jai alai (1.9 million) to No. 19

NCAA Softball (423,145) and No. 20 U.S. track and field (375,000).

The biggest surprise? No. 20 Curling (363,587) outdrew the two extreme sports extravaganzas - No. 21 X Games (301,390) and No. 22 Gravity Games (200,000) -broadcast by ESPN and NBC, respectively.
