title: Fox gets some relief -CLIP
body:
By Jon Friedman
October 23, 2000
CBS.MarketWatch.com

Fox gets some relief in World Series

NEW YORK (CBS.MW) – Fox Sports may yet have the last laugh on the skeptics who predicted subpar television ratings for the all-New York World Series.

The first game of the World Series on Saturday night, in which the New York Yankees defeated the New York Mets by a score of 4-3 in 12 innings, drew a preliminary overnight Nielsen Media Research rating with a 25 share, noted The New York Times, pointing out that Fox "defied the most dire predictions that viewers outside New York would not care."

The result was down 7 percent from a 15, or a 26 share, for the first game a year ago, when the Yankees defeated the Atlanta Braves on their way to a four-game sweep.

Fox had appeared to face steep odds of producing a Series with robust ratings. For openers, a matchup exclusively of New York teams could've turned off viewers in other cities. Plus, the emergence of the Yankees, going after their third consecutive baseball championship this fall, seemed uninspiring to fans who gripe that the Bronx Bombers win too often and too easily. The Yankees have now won 14 World Series games in a row, an all-time record.

In addition, this year's poorly received, oft-criticized Sydney Olympics set a precarious precedent for Fox, a division of News Corp. While the World Series is, of course, distinct from the Summer Olympics, Fox was hoping that a buzz from the Olympics would carry forward to the baseball championship.

"There is no sense of this World Series playing out on a national stage," Chicago Tribune media columnist Steve Johnson had said the day before the opening of the Series.

The Sports Business Daily, an Internet service, said Fox's broadcast of the second game generated a 15.2 (and a 23 share) preliminary Nielsen average rating, down 3 percent from the second game of the 1999 Yankees-Braves series.

Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig was quoted as telling the Washington Post that the ratings "have not caused alarm" in the game's management ranks.

Still, the doomsayers persist in making dire predictions.

Sports Business Daily noted that Prentis Rogers wrote in the Atlanta Constitution that the 2000 World Series is "on track to be the lowest-rated" in TV history.

title: Sponsors score on March Madness-CLIP
body:
By John F. Thorsberg
March 17, 2000
CBS.MarketWatch.com

Sponsors score on March Madness
Ads up right under the buzzer, plus more sports spots

SAN FRANCISCO (CBSMW) – College basketball is in the throes of March Madness, and sponsors are eager for some of that excitement to rub off on their businesses.

The NCAA's newest corporate partner, Total Sports, jumped into the sponsorship action just before tip-off.

North Carolina-based Total Sports, which plans a $50 million IPO late this month, isn't an NCAA newcomer. The company was already involved in the game via FinalFour.net, the official Web site it maintains for the NCAA men's and women's basketball championships. Total Sports has five networks with more than 100 Web sites featuring college sports, baseball, golf, motor racing and sportfishing.

Total Sports hosts Net sites for 12 of the 64 men's teams invited to the NCAA tourney, according to a survey by the Sports Business Daily. Fans Only Network, which specializes in online college sports, hosts 21 tournament team sites. Four teams host their own sites, and one is hosted by IBM.

title: Sports Business Briefs-CLIP
body:
SPORTS BUSINESS BRIEFS

Richard Alm
July 29, 2000
The Dallas Morning News

The Houston Rockets and negotiators for the Harris County-Houston Sports Authority finished their financing plan or a new $175 million arena this week, the Houston Chronicle report d. The deal isn't as generous as the one rejected by voters in Nove ber. The team's upfront contribution will rise to $105 million from $74 million. The city would receive 5 percent of naming-rights reve ue, plus a doubling of arena dates to 20. The Rockets want to go to the voters for a second time Nov. 7.

Austin-based AIM Technologies Inc., a 5-year-old company that sells fan-loyalty programs to professional and amateur teams, signed a de l this month with the Cleveland Rockers of the Women's National Bas etball Association. It's the first rewards program launched in U.S. women's professional sports. A quarter of the fans attending the te m's first home game enrolled in the Rockers Rewards program. AIM's 0 clients include the Dallas Stars, Texas Rangers and Dallas Maveriks.

The Sports Business Daily, an industry newsletter, finds a potentia market for the XFL, the new football league being launched next ye r by World Wrestling Federation Entertainment Inc. In a poll of mor than 1,000 respondents, seven of 10 wrestling fans said they had s me interest in the WWF brand of football. About half of National Fo tball League fans and half of sports fans professed an interest in eeing the new product.

Dallas-based eFANshop, an Internet commerce company that handles th sales of licensed merchandise, signed an agreement this week to op rate online stores for the East Coast Hockey League and all 25 of i s teams. The retail outlets will be up and running by the start of he season on Oct. 12.

title: Carter will fly -CLIP
body:
Carter will fly in someone else's shoes, say analysts:
Raptors star owes $13.5M:
Ruling in Carter case likely to deter other's from following suit

Jeremy Sandler
July 19, 2000
National Post

Maybe he should've pleaded temporary Vinsanity, perhaps then Vince Carter wouldn't be staring down the barrel of US$13.5-million dollar arbitrator's judgment against him for breach of contract.

Word came out on Monday that a Boston arbitrator had awarded the settlement to sports apparel maker Puma after Carter unilaterally and prematurely declared his relationship with Puma null and void late in 1999, just a 18-months after signing a multi-year deal to endorse the company's products.

Carter said Puma's shoes made his feet hurt and on this basis thought he had grounds to end the relationship. Evidently not. While there are sure to be several twists and turns before this case is resolved, one thing is certain, several shoe companies will vie for the podiatric publicity offered by having their gear laced up on Carter's flying feet as he soars over opposing NBAers for a rim-rattling jam.

But the fact that Puma was willing to go to court with one of its star endorsers signals a paradigm shift in the sports marketing world. In the late '80s and early '90s, when shoe companies were signing up athletes faster than ticket prices could rise, corporations were loath to appear belligerent with their athletes lest they alienate potential pitchman partners. Now there are far more athletes than endorsement dollars to go around.

"I do think that the companies now hold the leverage over the athletes," said Abe Madkour, editor-in-chief of The Sports Business Daily, a Charlotte-based publication that monitors the business of sports. "The market has just slowed dramatically as far as people buying athletic shoes.

"It makes [companies] think twice and restructure. Companies have shareholders to answer to. They had to show return with all the money they were throwing at the next Michael Jordan and no one was stepping up to be the next Michael Jordan. Companies just don't see the need or the benefit of doing this any more."

Bob Williams, president of Burns Sports Celebrity Service, Inc., a match-making firm for celebrities and businesses, agrees with Madkour.

"The whole marketplace has changed in the last few years," Williams said. "There used to be tremendous depth, so even your sixth man was getting top dollars. [Shoe companies] were even going into junior highs and grade schools [looking for talent].

"Your starting five on each [NBA] team had low to high six-figure contracts and even players coming off the bench had good contracts."

Swooning shoe sales caused by a variety of factors has changed all that.

"[Now] the majority of starters don't have shoe contracts," Williams continued. "The market has dropped out from underneath the shoe companies. When demand was high for their shoes, companies were willing to spend the money. The shoe companies have been left holding the proverbial bag."

With talk of Tiger Woods being an endorsement billionaire and a retired Michael Jordan still raking in endorsement fees, it may seem nonsensical to suggest athletes aren't signing big money deals, but Toronto-based agent and lawyer Gord Kirke sees a gap, and he's not talking about a place to buy capri pants.

"You don't see a lot of mid-range deals," Kirke said. "The truth of the matter is that there are a few elite athletes getting very large deals. In the middle there seems to be a gap where the middle- range athletes aren't getting deals."

As long as the shoe flu is lowering the amount of available money, some athletes will go to low-cash or no-cash deals involving stock options and profit percentage agreements, many in the dot-com area.

Shaquille O'Neal of the NBA champion Los Angeles Lakers is probably the biggest in this regard. O'Neal let deals with multi-nationals, such as Pepsi and Reebok expire, opting instead for stock-loaded deals with little-known tech outfits, such as SportsLine.com, Dunk.net and FreeInternet.com.

Burns' Williams is skeptical of the dash to dot-com endorsements.

"Up until this point, it has been an emerging trend. I don't think it is going to continue based upon the current dot-com marketplace," he said. "Most athletes jumped in at the end of the dot-com craze. Unfortunately, they were jumping in at the wrong time. Athletes are very conservative by nature. It doesn't take too many athletes to get caught up in a dot-com deal that goes bankrupt before they go back to the tried and true of cash up front."

Agent Kirke doesn't think the endorsement market will stay depressed forever.

"I think it's cyclical. I think there will be a return. I think it still matters to the public what athletes are doing and saying. I can't say when that will be, but it will come."

For Carter, that day may not be soon enough, but Madkour doesn't think the cat fight with Puma will count as a permanent strike against Air Canada, as Carter is sometimes known.

Questions about whether Carter can even afford to pay a US$13.5-million settlement may be moot. Madkour believes either Carter and Puma will reach an agreement to work together or another shoe company will buy out Carter's debt and bring him on as a spokesman. Whatever happens, Madkour did say Puma's mauling of Carter will dissuade on-court stars from trying their hand in court.

"You are going to see a lot of agents and players think twice before opting out because [their] shoes don't fit."

title: Off The Rack-CLIP
body:
Off The Rack: Sports Magazines

Keith Olbermann
June 11, 2000
Contentville

June 2000–I want to start this column with an overview of sports periodicals, then present a brief look at my own Top Ten and give a preview of what you will henceforth find in this space: particular examples of the very good and the very bad. As active, intense, and (flatly) panicky as sports-magazine and newspaper publishing seems to be at the moment, we'll never be short of stuff to review or changes to note.

Not a bad idea to offer a disclaimer here, too: I will be on occasion writing about periodicals that I've worked for or that have written about me. My only full-time affiliations were with Baseball America (1997) and Sports Illustrated (1998). I quit the former after they published a reader's truly wounding letter about me, with which the editors seemed to agree, and my association with the latter ended after what had been a genuinely mutually satisfying weekly baseball column. In addition, my sportscasts are quoted frequently in The Sports Business Daily. Otherwise I haven't been actively connected to anything in this field since Baseball Magazine folded in 1981.

In any event, I'm not writing for MediaManagementville, am I? Ideally, criticism is about biting the hand that feeds you, or feeding the hand that slaps you, if the work deserves it.

Now as to that overview: It would be nice to say that sports periodicals are stratifying into niches. In point of fact, they're foundering. Nowhere has the ascension of sports cable, sports radio, and now sports dotcoms done more damage than among the weeklies, biweeklies, and monthlies, who scramble to find something to publish for an increasingly preinformed public. This Top Ten list, ranked by the degree to which each periodical succeeds in accomplishing what it could or can, reflects my belief that there may soon be a dozen viable sports websites, but that we're not going to see a flock of magazines going head-to-head.

1. Sports Business Daily: A daily Reader's Digest of all the sports news that has nothing to do with the scores. This is the new wave of the industry: There is no hard-copy edition, just an e-mail or fax, sent out every weekday around 12:30 P.M. Eastern, 20 or so single-spaced pages of information culled from an extraordinary array of media outlets. Coverage of the fight between the NBA and its coaches over wearing microphones during games, for instance, referred to reporting and commentary from 21 different newspapers and three television networks – from NBC to the Contra Costa Times. This is not general-interest reading, and the 25,000 or so subscribers each pay $1,050 annually, but the publishers claim a renewal rate of 84 percent. In it, I find an average of three or four stories per day that wind up on my television, radio, or Internet reports. The only entity comparable in terms of comprehensiveness is The Associated Press.

2. The Sporting News: Gone are the days of "The Bible of Baseball," wherein the manager of the Dubuque Dubs might be quoted. TSN has instead reinvented itself as an "insider's" tool for all sports, and has unexpectedly bounced back after years of mistakenly trying to compete with SI.

3. Baseball America: This biweekly cleaned itself up enough aesthetically to survive on a diet of minor-league and college-baseball coverage, scouting and analysis worthy of the professionals, and solid columnists, especially the always delightful Jayson Stark. A tendency to pander to fantasy-league players is a distraction.

4. Sports Illustrated: The tradition continues, even though most of its elements have been superceded by television, the Internet, and specialty magazines. The American Society of Magazine Editors recently named 82 finalists in its various award categories, and SI had four of them, behind only The New Yorker and Esquire. Moreover, all four were for writing: two to Gary Smith, one to Frank Deford, one to the team of Don Yeager and Bill Nack. But assuming that hard-copy, well-reported, lyrically composed feature writing can hold the fort against the websites, when does SI's next generation of readers show up?

5. ESPN Magazine: Yes, there's no way to tell where the ads end and the articles begin. Yes, it is the editorial equivalent of eating whipped cream three meals a day. But it sure is a pretty magazine, isn't it?

The others:

6. USA Today Baseball Weekly

7. The Hockey News

8. Beckett Baseball Card Monthly

9. The Sports Business Journal

10. Sport

title: NHL struggles -CLIP
body:
National Hockey League NHL struggles to find crowds, TV audience

December 27, 1999
Des Moines Register

Deck: Attendance is down, so is coverage on three major cable outlets.

In recent weeks, there has been a startling decline in attendance for several NHL clubs.

In October, the Sports Business Daily tracked the content of three major cable highlight shows: ESPN's "SportsCenter," CNN/SI's "Sports Tonight" and Fox Sports Net's "Prime Time."

NHL coverage finished fourth behind baseball, the NFL and college football on CNN/SI and FSN and third on ESPN, ahead of college football. Baseball was in the midst of the playoffs and World Series, but the NFL and college football only played on the weekend, while the NHL was running games every night starting Oct. 1.

"I think you just have to concede that the NHL, in terms of hierarchy of fan interest, doesn't have it," CNN/SI Managing Editor Steve Robinson told Sports Business Daily. "It has a passionate audience, but I just think in terms of the raw numbers, you're not going to find anywhere near the level of interest for early season hockey that you have for many of the other sports."

This season, the NHL is in the first of a record five-year, $600 million deal with ESPN/ABC. That nearly doubled the amount of the previous contract, which had Fox as the network outlet and ESPN as the national cable source.

That was the good news.

But Fox, NBC and Turner will pay at least $2.4 billion during the next six years to televise NASCAR. That's about $400 million a season.

title: Mariners fans-CLIP
body:
Mariners fans: Don't read this

USA Today Baseball Weekly
July 28, 1999 issue

Seattle's Ken Griffey Jr. was named baseball's most marketable player in a survey of 90 industry experts conducted by The Sports Business Daily.

Griffey, who also earned the distinction in 1997, placed ahead of, in order: Mark McGwire, Sammy Sosa, Derek Jeter, Cal Ripken and Griffey teammate Alex Rodriguez.

NBC Sports president Ken Schanzer called Griffey "the gold standard, the best player of his generation."

However, some panelists suggested that Griffey could increase his visibility by playing in a larger market.

Said Sportscorp president Marc Ganis: Griffey "needs to leave Seattle to maximize his marketability, both for himself and for baseball."

title: As Fans Age-CLIP
body:
As Fans Age, Promoters Seek to Revamp Baseball

Patrick Hruby
September 6, 1999
Insight Magazine

It's a muggy, sunny Sunday afternoon in early summer, the air thick like a triple-scoop frapp around Foxboro Stadium in Massachusetts. Cars and trucks are backed up for what seems like a mile up and down the sole access road to the stadium.

Fans are here to watch their favorite sport, traffic and heat be darned. Their excitement is palpable, exemplified by two 8-year-olds who seem positively giddy, both of them smiling broadly and fidgeting in anticipation.

"We like soccer in general," says Kyle Carbone of Shrewsbury, Mass. "We're crazy about it." His pal, Ryan Breen, eagerly agrees. "It's pretty amazing how many fans are out here."

The boys are here for a Women's World Cup soccer match, along with some 50,000 others, ready to cheer on the U.S. national team. They play soccer, of course. Basketball and hockey, too. They watch the Boston Celtics, they watch the Bruins and they even tuned in to watch an out-of-town team, the Dallas Stars, win the Stanley Cup. But they don't watch baseball. Or play it. Ryan has never been to a Red Sox game - he's "just not into seeing it."

Baseball is in trouble. Just ask Mike Veeck. The game's in his blood, passed down by dad Bill Veeck, the former owner of the Cleveland Indians, Chicago White Sox and St. Louis Browns.

Mike has stuck with baseball through the bad times - he was the mastermind behind 1979's Disco Demolition Night in Chicago - and the good, as owner and co-owner of a number of minor-league teams, including the St. Paul Saints. He loves the game more than most Washingtonians love politics, sex scandals and the politics of sex scandals.

But he's worried. Worried about a problem that runs under the surface of the game. "Baseball's graying," he says. "In case anybody hasn't noticed, baseball is not the top priority for an 11-, 12, 13- , 14-year-old boy or girl. We're not growing new fans."

Call it the "generation Y(2k) bug" - Major League Baseball's, or MLB's, growing disconnect with today's youth. For an increasing number of children, the sport that once was the soundtrack of summer has become an inaudible buzz, a seemingly irrelevant blip on a radar screen dominated by alternative sports, PlayStations and faster- paced, better-marketed competitors. Consider:

• Just 12 percent of "average" MLB fans are between ages 12 and 17, according to a 1998 ESPN/Chilton sports poll.

• Only 6 percent of Fox's 1998 regular-season baseball TV audience was 12 to 17 years old, compared with 9 percent for the National Basketball Association, or NBA, and 10 percent for the National Hockey League, or NHL.

• Just 44 percent of teens said they were "very or somewhat interested" in MLB, compared with 54 percent for the National Football League, or NFL, and 57 percent for the NBA, according to a 1998 survey of teens by Illinois-based Teenage Research Unlimited.

The baseball number dropped to 43 percent in 1999, leading Teenage Research Unlimited to comment that the Mark McGwire vs. Sammy Sosa home-run race "has seemingly not increased teens' interest in the sport." As if to underscore the point, the same survey noted that only three of the 20 most popular athletes among teen-agers were baseball players. The NBA had seven in the top 20, the NFL nine.

"You see a thing where the kids are in no way thinking baseball," says Art Taylor, director of urban youth sports for Northeastern University's Center for the Study of Sport in Society. "It's the pace of the game, every other thing about it, and even if they play Little League it's their second or third sport."

Indeed, youngsters aren't merely tuning baseball out - they're not playing the game, either. A 1998 study by the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association,or SGMA, ranks baseball as only the fifth most-played sport among youth ages 12 to 17, trailing basketball, volleyball, soccer and football. Among children ages 6 to 11, baseball ranked fourth. More disturbingly, from 1997 to 1998, baseball participation among youth ages 12 to 17 fell 7 percent, while soccer increased 20 percent and ice hockey 53 percent.

Those numbers reflect an overall drop in baseball participation among the general public. Between 1988 and 1998, the number of people who played baseball at least once a year fell by 12 percent, according to a separate SGMA study; by contrast, soccer participation rose 18 percent and basketball 26 percent.

Baseball's slide comes as no surprise to Ann Clurman, a generational-marketing specialist with the New York consumer- research firm Yankelovich Partners. According to Clurman, 50 percent of children ages 6 to 17 said that they liked to play baseball in a 1995 survey. That number had dropped to 41 percent by 1999. During the same period, interest in basketball, football and soccer went up. "Baseball has seen a steady decline," says Clurman, who counts herself a baseball fan. "Of all the things we look at, it's pretty sharp."

Baseball simply can't afford a drop in youth interest, sharp or otherwise. Not when those same children someday will determine the game's financial and spiritual health - maybe even its survival. Made up of the roughly 60 million individuals born between 1979 and 1994, generation Y is the largest generational cohort since the baby boom. And like the boomers before them, the members of generation Y one day will wield a tremendous amount of cultural and consumer power.

Eventually, generation Y's tastes will be the nation's tastes. Its heroes will be the nation's heroes. Its pastime will be the nation's pastime. Its hard-earned money will pay the $200 million-plus salary of tomorrow's .245-hitting in-fielder. And if baseball can't capture generation Y's collective imagination now, it may not get a second chance.

"If they don't grab ahold of these kids when they're very young, then they lose them," says Abraham Madkour, editor in chief of Sports Business Daily. "It's much easier to be a fan, and follow as a fan, and stay a fan when you're young than to try and turn older people on to a sport."

Compounding the problem is MLB's rapidly aging core fan base. According to the ESPN/Chilton poll, the average baseball fan is more than 40 years old. And in 1998, 49 percent of Fox's regular-season baseball audience was older than 50. "Go to spring training," Taylor says. "What you find is about 90 percent of the people are 70 years and older."

Those fans, to put it bluntly, aren't going to live forever. Unless they're replaced, it's possible that MLB one day could be reduced to second-tier status.

How did it come to this? According to marketing experts and league observers, there's plenty of blame to go around. For one thing, baseball hasn't helped its own cause. Not with surly sluggers such as Baltimore Oriole Albert Belle treating the general public with the respect and warmth typically reserved for pickpockets. Not with free agents and greedy owners alike chasing profits over pennants. And not with one of the most exciting seasons in recent memory fading under the intensity of an ongoing labor-management rift that makes the Hundred Years' War feel like a long weekend. "Certainly baseball has shot itself in the foot - repeatedly - with work stoppages and labor problems," Madkour says.

For another, baseball has become less family friendly. According to Sean Brenner of the Chicago-based Team Marketing Report, the average cost for a family of four to attend an MLB game is $121.36. And although that makes baseball less expensive than other major- league sports, it's far more expensive than, say, a night at the movies - but it doesn't encourage repeat visits.

At its core, baseball is a farm game, played to the rhythm and pace of the agrarian society that spawned it. The game's subtle charms are lost on a generation weaned on MTV and powered by Intel. "It might be the pace of the game," marketing specialist Clurman says. "More kids have their own rooms and their own TVs, and those televisions are hooked up to cable or satellite. They're doing a zillion things while the TV is on. So it may be that unless there's a lot of action and excitement and movement going on, they are really sort of tuning out to baseball."

Making matters worse, the typical MLB game has become even slower in recent years. From carousel-style pitching changes to glacial at- bat routines (scratch, spit, twirl bat, call time, step out of the box, repeat), average total game time across the American and National leagues has increased from 2:45 in 1988 to 2:48 in 1998. "You need to do something about the slow parts of the game," Northeastern University's Taylor says. "Like batters stepping out of the box - say you get out of the box one time, fine, but you go out a second time, and you're out. You could put a kind of rollerball enthusiasm in the game if you tried. But right now it's way too slow."

The average starting time for the 1997 World Series was around 8 p.m. The average game lasted roughly three hours. That's good for advertisers, who covet the largest prime-time audience possible, but bad for youngsters who happen to have a bedtime. Young people "need to watch the game," Madkour says. "And to watch it, they need to be awake. So the games can't be running to 12:30 at night."

When the legendary Ted Williams was surrounded by a cluster of today's top players at this year's All-Star Game, it was a poignant moment linking baseball's past and present. It also was indicative of the backward-looking attitude that permeates the game - a Ken Burns ethos that isn't always relevant to the "SportsCenter" generation.

"Ken Griffey Jr. was telling me that he'll sit and watch an NBA promo and then a baseball promo, and then the first thing he wanted to do was go pick up a basketball," says Chris Wilder, editor of the Source Sports. "Because it's exciting, there's people running around, jumping, dunking and they're showing emotion. On a baseball diamond, you've got to look to the bench to see it."

And while the NBA, the NHL and even the stodgy NFL have labored to connect with today's youth culture on its terms, MLB hasn't done the same. "An important thing the NBA is doing is embracing the hip-hop generation - and that's who the audience is, that entire generation listens to hip-hop," Wilder says. "That's what they grew up on and that's what they know. But a player in baseball can get in trouble for wearing his hat backwards during batting practice. And that's ridiculous. Not only is baseball not embracing it, they're pushing it away."

In fact, MLB's previous youth-marketing efforts have been spotty at best - and nonexistent at worst. For years, many marketing experts say, the league rested on its laurels while its rivals aggressively pursued young fans. The NBA, for example, spurs grass-roots participation with its three-on-three "Hoop It Up!" tournaments, bombards the airwaves with fast-paced highlights set to hip-hop beats and generally sells a slate of larger-than-life cartoon superheroes. Five years ago, the NFL hired Sara Levinson, a former copresident at MTV, to head its marketing efforts - and now finds itself the most popular league among teens.

MLB's response? The short-lived, ill-fated "What a Game" campaign. "[NBA Commissioner] David Stern figured out where things should be, and [NFL Commissioner] Paul Tagliabue copied him," Taylor says. "The last thing they wanted to do was cut kids out. But we're fighting for the corporate money, we're fighting for the older generation and we're not fighting for the kids. Look at NBA Inside Stuff [an NBA- themed children's TV show]. That's great. What does baseball have that's like that? Absolutely nothing."

Baseball's ownership structure partially may be responsible for the game's marketing malaise. While the NBA and NFL take their marketing cues from the top down, resulting in a consistent message - "Feel the Power" and "I Love This Game" - MLB's diffuse base makes it difficult to create and apply a single marketing plan that team owners can agree on. Internal debate runs rampant, Sports Business Daily's Madkour says, over how much money should be spent on national marketing, how much should be spent on local marketing, what the message should be and - most contentiously - who should pay for it.

"If these were generals, we'd certainly lose the war," Taylor says. "Bud Selig is one of the nicest people that I've met, but he has no power over the owners. And that creates the opportunity to do whatever you want to do - run the dullest program, the most exciting program - with very little feedback. You have to really make a mistake or be hated, and usually it's both, before there's any intervention."

All this may be changing. Last December, MLB combined its various promotional branches (including its development, promotions and advertising programs) into a single marketing department, ensuring a more coordinated effort. And according to newly appointed marketing czar Kathy Francis, baseball is prepared to make youth marketing a priority.

"You don't have to do a lot of in-depth research to see our future lies with families and kids," says Francis, MLB vice president of marketing. "The question is: What do we need to do?" Already this year, MLB has launched or expanded a number of programs aimed at young fans:

• "Yardball," a four-on-four variant of the game played with a plastic ball and bat on a miniature diamond. Yardball has been introduced in 15 markets; Francis hopes to bring it into school systems next year. "It's intended to bridge the gap to the pickup games you once played." she says. "You don't need a lot of space or equipment to play."

• "Club MLB Roadshow," a traveling trailer featuring interactive kiosks, video games and batting and pitching cages. Launched in New York's Central Park before the All-Star Game, the trailer has made stops at Camden Yards in Baltimore and Fenway Park in Boston and is headed for Tampa Bay. "If kids can't get to the ballpark, we'll bring it to them," Francis says.

• A relaunch of "Diamond Skills," a modern version of old-style pitch, hit and run competitions. More than 450,000 youngsters competed in the program this year, Francis says, working through local park and recreation departments and youth leagues and culminating at the All-Star Game.

• MLB's Reviving Baseball in the Inner Cities (know as RBI), a program intended to increase youth participation in disadvantaged areas. Founded in 1991, the program involved more than 120,000 children last year. "Every kid deserves an opportunity to play," Francis says. "The game should be available. For baseball, there's an untapped pool of talent and a fan base we can tap into."

Of course, a handful of measures don't make for a comprehensive youth-marketing strategy. In September, Francis says, her department will present to the league a fully integrated plan - one that better coordinates local and national marketing efforts, shines a spotlight on the game's brightest young stars and emphasizes children and families.

"A few years down the road, you'll see a more focused approach, an expansion of programs," she says. "There will be a focus on families and kids. We'll be talking to families through their kids. Clubs are taking time out of their schedules to meet with us. There's a willingness and a desire to continue to build. Baseball is ready. It has the support, and the leadership is in place to do the right thing."

But will it be enough? Will the game refurbish its image, reconnect with children and recapture some of the cachet it once held? Or will it continue a slow fade into obscurity, perhaps even irrelevance, in a future sports landscape dominated by its competitors?

It's up to baseball to decide. "Once you tag them as a Yankee fan and they're 6, 7, 8 years old, they're going to stay Yankee fans and they're going to go to games," Madkour says. "They're going to buy products, watch games on TV. And hopefully, when they grow older and have children, they're going to raise them to be Yankee fans.

"But it's not just an idea. You have to put marketing dollars behind it, put money into a campaign, bring in marketing partners and have them help leverage the game and its players with ads, displays, promotions, sweepstakes. Every time you go into Wendy's and you get a little NHL pack or sticker, that goes a long way. Major League Baseball still needs to go a long way."

title: Privacy Policy
body:
SPORTSBUSINESSDAILY.COM
PRIVACY POLICY

Last revised June 13, 2001

In addition to reviewing this privacy policy, please read our Terms of Service. Your use of SportsBusinessDaily.com constitutes agreement to its terms and conditions.

SportsBusinessDaily.com is produced by Street & Smith Publications, Inc., a division of American City Business Journals, Inc. This policy does not cover information collected on sites linked to from SportsBusinessDaily.com.

It is the goal of SportsBusinessDaily.com to bring you information that is tailored to your individual needs and, at the same time, protect your privacy. The following is a summary of the various ways we treat the information you provide us while using our site.

SportsBusinessDaily.com only collects personally identifying information with your specific knowledge and consent. For instance, when you register for our services, complete a survey, subscribe to our publications, or submit information for editorial purposes, you are asked to provide information such as your e-mail address, name or phone number. Optional information such as your age or gender may also be requested.

SportsBusinessDaily.com uses this information to provide you with the service you have requested. For example, if you subscribe to our service, we may use your e-mail address to send you a confirmation notice and your mailing address to send you other offers. We may also use the information to communicate with you about new features, products or services, or to improve the services that we offer by tailoring them to your needs.

SportsBusinessDaily.com does not sell any of our users' personal information. We may, however, share information with carefully selected companies who we think can offer you services and products of interest to you. If you do not wish to have your information shared, write to us at info@sportsbusinessdaily.com. If you do not wish to receive communications from us, simply follow the unsubscribe instructions contained within the e-mail. If you've registered on any part of SportsBusinessDaily.com, you may also change or update your member preferences or information at "My Account," in the top right corner of the navigation bar on each page.

We also allow access to our database by third parties that provide us with services, such as technical maintenance or forums software, but only for the purpose of and to the extent necessary to provide you with those services. Any third party who has access to our database for this purpose is bound by the terms set forth in this policy. There may also be occasion when we are legally required to provide access to our database in order to cooperate with police investigations or other legal proceedings. In those instances, the information is provided only for that purpose.

You may have read about "cookies," nuggets of information that are placed by a Website in a storage place on your own computer. We use cookies to control the display of ads, to track usage patterns on the site, or to record registration and personalization information. For example, if you register on any part of SportsBusinessDaily.com, you can opt to save your user name and password and other registration information. This cookie "recognizes" your browser when you return to our site so you do not have to log in every time. We also use cookies to control user access to our site.

Our cookies do not contain any information that is, in itself, personally identifying.

Some of our advertisers occasionally serve you cookies as well. We do not have control over cookies placed by advertisers.

If you don't want cookies, your Web browser likely includes an option that allows you to not accept them. We don't recommend using this option, though: It makes browsing our site a less enjoyable experience.

Finally, while your individual information is protected as outlined above, we reserve the right to use aggregated, anonymous data about our users as a group for any business purpose, such as analyzing usage trends and seeking compatible advertisers and partners.

KIDS AND PARENTS: SportsBusinessDaily.com is not intended for use by children, especially those under age 13. No one under age 13 is allowed to provide any personal information or use our public discussion areas, forums and chats. Minors under the age of 18 are prohibited from making purchases, including subscriptions, on the site.

If your children disclose information about themselves in our public discussion areas, they may get unsolicited messages from other parties. Accordingly, you should tell them not to do so.

If you're worried about your children's activities or their privacy on our sites, we encourage you to send us an e-mail addressed to "Privacy Policy Coordinator" at info@sportsbusinessdaily.com

This Privacy Policy may be modified from time to time; notice of changes will appear on this page, so check back often. Any such changes will be prospective, never retroactive.

If you have concerns or questions about any aspect of this policy, please send us an e-mail addressed to "Privacy Policy Coordinator" at info@sportsbusinessdaily.com. We welcome your feedback. You can also send us regular mail at the following address:

Privacy Policy Coordinator
Sports Business Daily
120 West Morehead Street, Suite 220
Charlotte, NC 28202

title: Iverson Stars In-CLIP
body:
Iverson Stars in “in your face” Reebok Ads

Michael McCarthy
June 8, 2001
USA Today

The duel between NBA stars Kobe Bryant and Allen Iverson is moving from the hardwood to Madison Avenue.

Reebok airs a new Iverson TV ad in Sunday's Game 3 of the NBA Finals between the Los Angeles Lakers and Philadelphia 76ers. The spot, called "Any More Questions?" plays off Iverson's gritty playoff performance, as well as the makeover of his bad-boy image off the court.

The Iverson ad busts up what seemed like an all-Kobe, all-the-time commercial wave. During Game 1 of NBC's telecast on Wednesday, the Lakers star hawked sneakers and burgers in a total of six spots for sponsors Adidas and McDonald's.

Teammate Shaquille O'Neal appeared in a spot for Nestle Crunch. Even Vince Carter, whose team is out of the playoffs, appeared in a pair of Gatorade ads.

Iverson – the NBA's MVP this year – was shut out, with the exception of the NBA's own "It's all Good" ads.

Bryant was ranked the NBA's "most marketable player" in a survey by Sports Business Daily this spring, according to editor Abe Madkour. O'Neal and Carter came in second and third. Iverson finished fourth.

But controversies over Iverson's tattoos and rap lyrics have made advertisers "cautious" in the past, says Brandon Steiner of Steiner Sports Marketing, who matches marketers with sports endorsers. "Kobe is safer," he says.

This weekend, Iverson will try to answer Bryant's mainstream appeal with the start of a marketing push for Reebok, which signed him to a multimillion-dollar deal in 1996.

The spot, created by Berlin Cameron & Partners, New York, and airing in big cities, calls out his honors this season. Iverson proclaims in a voiceover: "When you work hard, good things happen. And this year everything happened right for us." The in-your-face tag line – "Any more questions? Reebok." – plays off of his nickname The Answer.

It also deliberately tries to answer questions about Iverson's commercial appeal, says John Wardley, Reebok's vice president of brand communications. Reebok is "delighted" its big bucks Iverson investment is paying off.

Reebok also is "turning the heat up" on Iverson-related merchandising with a new "MVP" collection of footwear and apparel, general manager Todd Krinsky says.

Iverson's other endorsement deal is with Sega. But his recent performance may build interest. "It's safe to say there are a lot of people who want to do business with Allen," says Larry Woodward, his lawyer. "Hopefully, he will win a championship, and we will sit down this summer and weigh opportunities."

And a championship ring would enable Iverson "absolutely" to compete with Bryant in the endorsement arena, predicts Jonathan Press, NBA's vice president of marketing partnerships.

title: Mr. Excitement-CLIP
body:
Inside The NBA

Mr. Excitement
Marcus Camby sends a charge through the Knicks and their fans

Sports Illustrated
Febuary 7, 2000
By Jackie MacMullan

THE POWER surge in Madison Square Garden begins when 25-year-old Knicks forward Marcus Camby pulls off his warmup jersey. When he jogs to the scorer's table, the executives halt their business discussions, the diehards pound their chests and the little kids screech in anticipation of what Camby will do when he steps onto the court.

On good nights he treats the crowd to an electric slam off a loose rebound or a breathtaking weakside rejection. On bad ones Camby's in foul trouble early, drawing one call for going over the back, another for reaching in. Either way, fans will return to see Camby try to make something happen. Sports Business Daily published a list of the 20 best-selling NBA jerseys in the first half of this season; Camby's number 23 was more popular than Karl Malone's jersey or Eddie Jones's.

"I can feel the buzz," Camby says of the stir he creates at the Garden. "It's a lot better than last year, when the boo-birds were out I wasn't even getting into the games, and they were still screaming at me,'We want Oak! We want Oak!' Man, that was tough."

The buzz last season centered on Camby as a pawn in a power struggle between former general manager Ernie Grunfeld and coach Jeff Van Gundy. Grunfeld had traded popular power forward Charles Oakley to the Raptors for Camby despite the reservations of his coach. Van Gundy stubbornly benched the slender 6' 11" forward, who in his two seasons in Toronto had been branded an immature kid who wouldn't play hurt. Van Gundy contends that it was impossible to develop an immediate feel for a new player after a prolonged lockout and a shortened preseason.

Camby's vindication came in the playoffs, when his energy fueled New York's improbable journey to the Finals-and saved Van Gundy's job. This season Camby is averaging 26.7 minutes, up 6.2 from last year, and there's no longer any question of his importance in the rotation: He's a favorite for the Sixth Man Award.

Ask Camby if he's Van Gundy's guy now, and he laughs and says, "I don't think I'm one of his core guys, guys who've been here, like Larry Johnson, Allan [Houston] and Pat [Ewing]. But I think he's my guy. When his job was in jeopardy, I could have gone in the tank against Miami in the first round, and we wouldn't even be sitting here. But I played hard for him. I understand his philosophy now, and he respects me more"

It helps their relationship that Camby doesn't demand shots, which Van Gundy must delicately distribute among Ewing, Houston and Latrell Sprewell. The Knicks are a collection of complex factions. Camby's boys are Sprewell, forward John Wallace and guard Rick Brunson. The clean-living Houston and point guard Charlie Ward have been nicknamed the Christian Coalition, while Ewing, the proud old warrior, stands alone, his friends having been traded, his skills eroding, his stature on the team diminished. He doesn't talk much these days, and team officials wonder how it will end.

"Pat's used to being the Guy in this city," says Camby, who has taken some of Ewing's minutes. "But I can't worry too much about him. He's still going to come in and get his number called. Hey, I don't get any plays called for me. I get my baskets off hustle plays. The one thing I do feel bad about is the injuries Pat's had. The Achilles [tendon tear] has set him back two to three years. His wrist is still messed up. He's playing through a lot of pain."

Even though New York was tied with Miami atop the Atlantic Division at 26-16 through Sunday, there are concerns. The Knicks were 10-8 against the top eight teams in each conference and 10-12 on the road. Sprewell, who demanded a starting role, is filling the small forward slot though he's better suited to play the two guard, Houston's position. The strain of being 190 pounds and trying to hold off threes such as 250-pound Juwan Howard is taking its toll on Sprewell, and Van Gundy frets about his wearing down.

Camby, meanwhile, must prove he can provide the consistency New York so desperately needs from him. At week's end he was averaging 10.2 points on 48.7% shooting, along with 7.9 rebounds and 2.24 blocks. He still hears whispers that he's not tough enough, stemming from the stretch earlier in the season when the team asked him to play through painful tendinitis in his left knee, and he sat for two games instead. One other thing: Camby no longer catches opponents by surprise.

"Every time the ball goes up, there are two guys keeping me off the glass," he says. "One guy is banging me at the three-point line, then another guy is hitting me at the free throw line. Then there are teams who send a spy out on me. Like the Pistons. Every time I check into the game, they send in Jerome Williams to bother me. That kid, he's crazy."

As the Feb. 24 trading deadline nears, rumors will swirl about the Knicks' upgrading their two-headed point guard, Ward and Chris Childs. There will be talk of Ewing's role and questions about Sprewell's position. There will be updates on the relationship between Van Gundy and Camby.

New York survived far worse turmoil to reach the Finals last year. Camby, who found a way to thrive under those conditions, has a handle on what it will take to get back there. "We don't all have to be best friends," said Camby, "but we've got to play like we are."

title: LPGA Ad Campain-CLIP
body:
Golfers Trying to Catch Up to the Boom in Women's Sports

Jane Levere
July 19, 2001
N.Y. Times

The Ladies Professional Golf Association will introduce a new advertising campaign on Saturday to raise its profile in the highly competitive field of women's sports.

Although the L.P.G.A., at 51, is the oldest women's professional sports association, and the 41 events on its tour receive 260 annual hours of television coverage — a number it says exceeds TV coverage of women's basketball, tennis and soccer — women's golf is not as well known as those sports, experts say. And, they say, it has not benefited from the skyrocketing interest in men's golf generated by Tiger Woods.

"Women's golf has been off the radar in many people's minds, although it's been out there at the same time the Tiger Woods phenomenon has propelled the P.G.A., and at the same time as the women's team- sports revolution," said Rick Burton, director of the Warsaw Sports Marketing Center at the University of Oregon in Eugene.

"Because of this, it's become less visible as an entertainment property to the media and the networks," Mr. Burton said. "That's probably why they've come to the conclusion they need an advertising campaign to create a platform for their sport."

The advertising, by T. G. Madison of Atlanta, is the association's first campaign since 1998 and the first by the agency.

The TV spots, which run at 30 or 60 seconds, depict either L.P.G.A. stars or up-and-coming players as girls and as adults. The spots use lyrics from a song from "Gigi," which say, "Thank heaven for little girls. They grow up in the most delightful way." The tagline is "L.P.G.A., positively amazing."

The longer ad features the current top three players, Annika Sorenstam, Karrie Webb and Se Ri Pak, as well as Lorie Kane and Meg Mallon.

The 30-second spots generally spotlight individual players like Dottie Pepper and Grace Park.

Starting on Saturday afternoon, the ads will run on cable and network television during L.P.G.A. tournaments, beginning with the NBC broadcast of the Sybase Big Apple Classic at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Ads will also run during the "Battle at Bighorn" on ABC on Monday evening, July 30, featuring Woods, David Duval, Sorenstam and Webb.

The campaign's print ad, which depicts Park as an adult and as a child in a kimono, is running in magazines including Golf for Women; new versions of it will be created later this year, as will radio spots.

The value of the advertising through 2002 — the majority of which will appear on national television — is about $5 million, more than double what the association spent in the previous three years. Competitive Media Reporting, a research firm, estimated that the L.P.G.A.'s ad budget from 1998 through 2000 was $2.2 million.

Its previous campaign, by the Dallas office of DDB, a unit of Omnicom, focused on the athletic ability of the players. The L.P.G.A. does not buy advertising time; it receives public service advertising time as part of its television contracts.

Virgil Shutze, chief creative officer of T. G. Madison, said the song from "Gigi" and photographs of players as girls were chosen because "they show the evolution of little girls who grow and emerge as wonderful human beings and phenomenal world-class golfers."

The goal of the advertising, said Karen Durkin, L.P.G.A. vice president for marketing, is to "create a stronger emotional connection between the fans and players."

"A lot of our fans are asking to learn more about the players," Ms. Durkin said. "We want to strengthen the brand and raise the profile to build our fan base in a very competitive marketplace."

Sports industry experts generally praised the intentions but questioned the campaign's long-term effectiveness.

Abraham Madkour, editor in chief of The Sports Business Daily, an industry trade publication, said, "when you think of the L.P.G.A., it's hard to figure out what it stands for." He added that the association was losing the competitive battle for coverage, sponsors and general attention to the Women's Tennis Association Tour, which has stars like Venus and Serena Williams. "The L.P.G.A. Tour is still lacking personalities," he said.

Bob Yanofsky, a TV advertising sales executive with Blair Television of New York, a subsidiary of Petry Media, said that the L.P.G.A.'s TV ratings last year were far weaker than those for women's tennis and men's golf.

According to Nielsen Media Research, the final round of the women's United States Open of golf had a 1.6 rating, compared with a 3.7 rating for the final round of the women's tennis tournament at Wimbledon; a 4.5 rating for the finals of the women's tournament at the United States Open in tennis; and an 8.1 rating for the final round of the men's United States Open in golf.

"These numbers reflect the fact that word hasn't gotten out about women's golf," Mr. Yanofsky said. The new advertising, he said, could be a step in the right direction. "It takes time," he said, "and it depends on how and where they spend their money."

Mr. Burton of the University of Oregon warned that running the campaign on golf programming could diminish its reach. "I don't know if they'll convert new viewers," he said.

title: Bad Boys Marketing-CLIP
body:
Bad boys, whatcha gonna do? Make a bundle in a series of ads sparked by 'lad culture'

Michael McCarthy
July 25, 2001
USA TODAY

Forget sensitive and sincere. The bad boys are back on Madison Avenue.

Swaggering, loud-mouthed, sometimes obnoxious personalities are making a comeback as endorsement stars in the $250 billion ad industry.

The latest: Heineken has signed tennis bad boy-turned-TV commentator John McEnroe to a 2-year endorsement deal that ranges from TV ads to T-shirts.

''John has got a great personality. People are more drawn to him now than when he was younger,'' says Ken Kunze, director of marketing for Heineken U.S.A.

The bad boy trend is being driven by the rise of ''lad culture,'' says futurist and trend spotter Marian Salzman of Euro RSCG. The success of men's magazine Maxim has shown Madison Avenue that there's a market for bad boy endorsers and boys-will-be-boys humor.

''It's trendy again to be obnoxious. The lad culture is very hot,'' Salzman says.

Also, aging baby boomers who watch -- and make -- TV commercials still enjoy politically incorrect icons from the '70s and '80s, such as smarmy ''Joe Isuzu,'' back on the air after 11 years, and fired Indiana University coach Bob Knight, rehabilitated in a recent ad.

Despite their loose-cannon image, sports figures such as Knight also have name recognition with younger as well as older consumers, says Abraham Madkour, editor of Sports Business Daily.

''It's a struggle right now to find effective spokespeople. So why not McEnroe? Why not the General (Knight)?'' Madkour asks. Some bad boy ads:

* Heineken plays off McEnroe's bratty tennis behavior with a spot first airing next month during U.S. Open coverage. The spot shows McEnroe having a nightmare and moaning, ''It can't be out!'' and ''How can it be out?'' Inside his nightmare: Johnny Mac at a bar where the Heineken tap has run out. ''It's not fair,'' McEnroe rages. ''You can't be serious.''

Lincoln hired McEnroe for two spots that aired during Wimbledon. Heineken is spending $10 million to $12 million to back its sponsorship of the Open. ''John is opinionated. But he has a hipness that 24-year-olds respect,'' Kunze says. The agency is Lowe Lintas & Partners, New York.

* Minute Maid parodies Knight's basketball bad temper by showing him praising players and referees after drinking orange juice. The spot scores strongly with males and younger consumers, Minute Maid says. Agency: Leo Burnett, Chicago.

* Comedian David Spade plays a repulsive barfly in new commercials for Coors. Spade hits on women and tries to cadge free brew from wary bartenders. Agency: Foote Cone & Belding, Chicago.

* Isuzu has dusted off ''Joe Isuzu'' (actor David Leisure), who appeared from 1986 to 1990. Why? Joe appeals to Isuzu's 35- to 48-year-old customer base, says Rick Balsiger, vice president of marketing. Agency: Goodby Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco.

* Reebok, encouraged by basketball bad boy Allen Iverson's stellar performance during the NBA playoffs, rushed out a new commercial starring ''The Answer.'' Agency: Berlin Cameron & Partners, New York.

The bad boy trend is part of a cultural shift of male consumers aggressively ''pushing back'' against female control over an estimated 70% to 80% of consumer purchases, Salzman says.

''We're seeing a big movement away from the soft, sensitive male. This is part of the backlash against the women's movement. And it's been in the making for 25 years,'' Salzman says

You may love them or hate them, Salzman says, but outlaw personalities, whether real guys or fictional Tony Sopranos, have strong consumer appeal:

''We're all so bundled up. But there's something authentic and real about the Bobby Knights who don't have any control. These people just let it loose.''

Is my password case sensitive?

Passwords may be a combination of lowercase letters, uppercase letters and numbers. The combination that you used must be typed in exactly the same each time you log in.

Can others use my login to access The Sports Business Daily?

Your site login and password are only for your use, as the subscriber. Multiple users will not be able to access The Daily under the same login. Please see our Terms of Service for further information.

Can I access The Sports Business Daily from more than one computer?

You can access The Daily from multiple computers. However, your site login and password are for your use only, as the subscriber. Multiple users cannot access The Daily under the same login. Please see our Terms of Service for further information.

title: Nominations
body:
NOMINATIONS OPEN FOR THE DAILY'S YEAR-END AWARD

Who is your MVP of the sports industry this year? Who has had that All-Star season to remember? Surely, there is one person or group that continually left you shaking your head and saying, ‘Wow, they are doing some serious damage!' The choice may be easy, or it may take some serious thought – either way, we want to know who is under consideration for your top honors! THE SPORTS BUSINESS DAILY is now accepting nominations for our 2002 SPORTS INDUSTRIALIST OF THE YEAR award. The annual award honors a person or entity who, over the past year, has best personified our view of sports as a global entertainment business. All nominees should have a clear and measurable impact on the industry through creative and innovative thoughts and practices.
Previous SPORTS INDUSTRIALIST OF THE YEAR Winners
1995: NBA Commissioner David Stern
1996: Major League Soccer
1997: Fox Sports TV Group Chair David Hill
1998: Coca-Cola VP & Dir of Media and Marketing Assets Chuck Fruit and former VP & Dir of U.S. Marketing Asset Management Steven Koonin
1999: NASCAR Senior VP/Marketing Brian France
2000: NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue
2001: ESPN President George Bodenheimer

Bodenheimer Took
Top Honors In '01

The winner will be selected by the editorial staff of THE DAILY. Nominations can be made in writing, on video or in person, and must be received by Friday, November 8. You can submit your nominations and supporting material/video/JPEG and other files directly to nominations@sportsbusinessdaily.com. If sending by mail, please send to The Sports Business Daily, Editorial Staff, 120 West Morehead Street, Suite 220, Charlotte, NC, 28202.

If you have any questions, please contact our editorial staff.

Every issue features coverage of the deals, trades, contracts and boardroom power plays that shape the rapidly changing sports industry. Regular columns cover every aspect of the sports industry from media and marketing to finance and facilities.

Category Exclusivity:

title: Bill Magrath Bio
body:
William H. Magrath
Media Relations Manager

Bill Magrath is the Media Relations Manager for SportsBusiness Daily, the leading daily publication on the business of sports.

Mr. Magrath is responsible for all newsgathering facets for SportsBusiness Daily and is the liaison to all print, media and interactive clients.

Mr. Magrath is a specialist in sports media and sports marketing research and he joined SportsBusiness Daily as Media Relations Manager in July 1998. Prior to joining SportsBusiness Daily, he was a consultant for ESPN Sports Almanac specializing in researching and updating content for the publication.

From July 1994 to October 1997, Mr. Magrath was an Account Manager for IDX Systems and Pyxis Corporation, both leaders in the healthcare industry. He also worked as an Operations Manager for Neworld Bank in Boston.

Mr. Magrath graduated Summa Cum Laude with a M.S. in Sport Administration from Northwestern State University (LA) and worked in the Sports Information Department. During his tenure there, he was Advertising Director for the Louisiana Sports Hall of Fame event, lead game operations staff member and taught undergraduate Health and Human Performance classes as well as research assistant for department chair.

Mr. Magrath also has a B.S .in Marketing from North Adams State College. He is single and resides in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: NFL Most Marketable-USA TODAY-CLIP
body:
Warner vs. Favre calls to mind QB clashes of past

Richard Weiner
January 18, 2002
USA TODAY

It sounds like a matchup concocted by the NFL to hype a big Sunday playoff game, to show that great quarterback matchups really still exist:

A good old-fashioned showdown with three-time MVP Brett Favre and his Green Bay Packers trying to knock off the best team in football, the St. Louis Rams, led by two-time MVP Kurt Warner.

The two most popular and marketable players in the league, according to fan voting for the Pro Bowl and a survey released Thursday by Sports Business Daily.

Competing for the first time since the Packers cut Warner as a camp quarterback in 1994 because he was too far behind Favre on the depth chart.

A pair of unshaven gunslingers in their prime who made it through tough times and now look to claim their second Super Bowl titles.

Thing is, it's all true.

  • "It's amazing," says San Francisco head coach Steve Mariucci, who was the Packers quarterback coach when Favre and Warner were in the same camp. Mariucci's 49ers had ample experience with both quarterbacks, losing to Warner's Rams twice in the regular season and to Favre's Packers last week in the wild-card round. "It's so well-deserved for both those guys. It's also exactly what the league needs right now."
  • "Oh, man, it's going to be a shootout," says linebacker Mike Barrow, whose defending NFC champion New York Giants also faced both quarterbacks this season. "You've got Kurt Warner. He's like Jesse James. He's got his gang. And Brett Favre. He's like an old Clint Eastwood character from a Western. The Good, the Bad and The Ugly. When he's good, you know he's going to beat you. When he's bad, he still can beat you. Even when he's ugly, he can beat you!"
  • "You're talking about two of the best quarterbacks to ever play the game," says Detroit coach Marty Mornhinweg, another former quarterback coach from Mike Holmgren's legendary Packers staff. Mornhinweg's team also faced Favre and Warner this year. "They both have total grasps of their systems. They both have great running backs behind them. They both have great receivers to throw to. It's going to be a showdown."
  • "You should talk with someone who had better success against them," says a chuckling Atlanta coach Dan Reeves, whose Falcons were another common foe. "Those are two really tough guys who take their shots but find ways to win. Yes, they do it differently. But I don't know if Brett has the weapons the other guy does."

Last offense on field wins?

Barrow is reminded of Pittsburgh's Terry Bradshaw facing Dallas' Roger Staubach during the 1970s. That type of quarterback rivalry carried into the next decade or so. But in the last few years, the NFL has lost to retirement some of its all-time great quarterbacks: Joe Montana, John Elway, Dan Marino, Steve Young and Troy Aikman.

This season the question has been whether any team could slow Warner and the Rams. Buoyed by a rebuilt defense,St. Louis won a franchise-record 14 regular-season games and became the first team to score more than 500 points three years in a row.

Running Mike Martz's dazzling offense to near perfection, Warner became the sixth player to capture multiple MVP awards; he also won during the Rams' Super Bowl title season of 1999. He led an offense that finished first in the NFL in total yards and passing. He topped the NFL in passing (101.4 rating) and touchdowns (36), and his 4,830-yard passing total was the second highest in history.

Favre, who won consecutive MVPs from 1995-97, finished third this season behind Warner and teammate Marshall Faulk. About the only key statistic Favre topped Warner in was fourth-quarter passer rating: Favre, at 104.4, was second in the league, while Warner, at 101.4, was third.

The Packers are one of only a few teams given a chance to go intoSt. Louis and win, with even Favre admitting this week, "I think I'm playing my best football right now." Warner, on the other hand, had the flu and only Thursday was allowed to call signals in practice as he recovers from a bruised vocal cord.

"That's a noisy place to play," Reeves says of the Dome at America's Center in St. Louis. "I think the real key, the only way Green Bay has a chance to win, is if they steal three or four passes." Warner finished with a career-high 22 interceptions.

Still, that might be too much to ask for a Packers secondary that allowed 49ers receivers to get past them last weekend. Both quarterbacks, 49ers defensive coordinator Jim Mora says, can kill teams after a blitz. "And you better mix it up," Mornhinweg says. "If you show either of them the same look four or five times, they'll have it figured out real quick."

Both overcame adversity

Neither Favre nor Warner is afraid to take a chance during a game, perhaps an offshoot from how each overcame adversity.

Favre spent a year in Atlanta before being traded in 1992 to Green Bay — where success also brought battles with painkillers and alcohol. Warner's rags-to-riches journey made for a best seller. He toiled penniless in the minor leagues until an injury to Trent Green cleared a path for him to lead the Rams to the Super Bowl. This despite having no NFL experience and after the Rams left him unprotected in the expansion draft.

The similarities end there. And not just because their systems are different. Warner is much more accurate. Favre is definitely more mobile. Warner is all about the Bible. Favre talks to opposing players about hunting and fishing.

"Brett controlled the huddle but could joke around at any minute," says Rams guard Adam Timmerman, a former Packer who played with both quarterbacks during their Super Bowl wins. "Kurt is more reserved, businesslike. He lets others do the talking."

Favre was on his way toward capturing the unprecedented three consecutive MVPs when Warner showed up as an undrafted rookie out of Northern Iowa. The differences stood out even then. Favre was the lead prankster for a unit that also included Mark Brunell and Ty Detmer. The three rode Warner as they would any rookie, calling him "Pop," as in Pop Warner, or "Chachi," because he looked like a friend of Mariucci's who was nicknamed after the character from TV's Happy Days.

"Kurt was fresh off the shelf," Mariucci says. "Brett was right on the verge."

Warner, questioned via e-mail earlier this week when doctors urged him to rest his voice, noted Favre hasn't missed a game since.

"In a way, I'm glad I didn't make it there," Warner says.

So is the league.

title: NFL Most Marketable-Wolfley-CLIP
body:
Bob Wolfley
January 22, 2002
The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel

Pitchmen also like Warner, Favre

Sports Business Daily surveyed 70 people in the TV, sports marketing, advertising and media industries and asked them who they thought were the five most marketable players in the National Football League.

The top two vote-getters are playing against each other today in a late-afternoon playoff game.

St. Louis Rams quarterback Kurt Warner finished first and Green Bay Packers quarterback Brett Favre finished a close second in the balloting, which asked respondents to give five points for their first choice, four points for their second choice, and so on down to one point for their fifth choice.

Warner and Favre finished far ahead of the rest of the field. Warner got 219 points to 205.5 for Favre. Warner received 22 first-place votes and Favre 18. Warner was named somewhere on 83.6% of all ballots cast. Favre was named on 82.8% of all ballots cast.

No one else was in double figures in first-place votes.

The rest of the top 10 was: Peyton Manning (112 points), Donovan McNabb (85), Marshall Faulk (69), Jerome Bettis (47), Doug Flutie (40), Emmitt Smith (23), Michael Strahan (21) and Shannon Sharpe (16.5).

Said San Francisco-based Pickett Advertising executive Bob Dorfman, referring to Warner: "He could be wearing a second Super Bowl ring after this season and will never get busted with a trunk-load of pot."

SportsCorp President Marc Ganis said Favre "epitomizes the NFL: talent, toughness, a warrior, shows his heart, a leader of men."

title: Motor Sports
body:
Get In Pole Position!

Start your engines with The Sports Business Daily’s
SPECIAL MOTORSPORTS ISSUE
  • The latest on Ford Motor Company's marketing strategy in auto racing and why it considers NASCAR a key component for its motorsports initiative.
  • With a marketing program in place in Europe, Red Bull is turning to the IRL’s Eddie Cheever to increase its market share in the U.S.
  • Sprint discusses how it is leveraging its tie to the Petty family to reach its key 25-54-year-old target market.
  • Motorsports marketing executives discuss the changing face of today's NASCAR drivers and how this new youth element could be a boon to corporate sponsors.
  • Complete Nielsen TV ratings for NASCAR's Winston Cup and Busch series.
  • NASCAR discusses its new, three-year partnership with iN Demand, which will provide a digital, multi-channel TV package to complement Winston Cup races.
  • CART is hoping the new joint promotional efforts around its races will help increase its brand awareness and help solidify its identity and long-term security.
  • Historical consumer trends detailing interest in various motorsports.

title: Sports Name Game Heats Up-Clip
body:
Pro sports name game heats up

Michael McCarthy
June 12, 2002
USA TODAY

Sports sponsorships are starting to look like a smart play again.

The estimated $35 billion industry slumped as companies cut marketing budgets. The economic downturn and the ghostly sight of such financially troubled brands as Enron and PSINet on professional sports stadiums made marketers cautious about naming-rights and sponsorship deals.

Sports marketing remains a high-stakes game. Companies annually shell out about $27 billion on traditional sports advertising, according to Sports Business Daily, and more than $1 billion on endorsements and Internet ads. They spend an additional $6.4 billion on sponsorships, says IEG Sponsorship Report.

While the days when a company would throw millions at pro sports just for the luxury boxes and a chance to backslap star players likely won't return, big naming-rights deals this month are evidence cash is starting to flow back into sports.

Both sides learned lessons. Advertisers are driving harder bargains and looking to make money off the deals, rather than viewing them as simply building brand awareness and goodwill.

And teams are seeking stable Fortune 500 partners. Formerly hot Web firm PSINet, for example, left the Baltimore Ravens high and dry last year when it sought bankruptcy protection less than two years into a $105 million, 20-year naming-rights deal. The team paid more than $2 million to escape.

"Sponsorship spending is showing some signs of rebounding since the post-9/11 slowdown. But I stress 'some signs,' " says Abraham Madkour, editor-in-chief of Sports Business Daily. "For every deal announced, there are one or two other deals that remain in limbo until a corporation is able to commit the resources necessary."

Signs of life:

  • The big deal. CBS and the National Collegiate Athletic Association said Tuesday that they have signed an 11-year, $500 million deal to put the Coca-Cola brand on everything from NCAA championships to CBS broadcasts of "March Madness" basketball games.
  • The name game. The implosion of Enron has opened the door for the first naming-rights deal in Coke's 115-year history. Its Minute Maid unit signed a $100 million, 28-year deal June 5 with baseball's Houston Astros to rename the former "Enron Field" as "Minute Maid Park." The team couldn't get the Enron name off the new park fast enough. Signs from the $100 million, 30-year deal were down before the start of the season.

Last week, the Astros were feverishly putting up Minute Maid signs and printing new tickets for Monday night's home game.

Minute Maid also gets pouring rights, for Coke, too — barring Pepsi from the park. "We think it will produce over $100 million in value between advertising visibility, products sold and goodwill in the community," says Dan Schafer, vice president of communications.

Astros owner Drayton McLane said Minute Maid's "financial security" was a " big part" of his decision.

"They knew they had to get away from the Enron stigma as fast as possible," says Madkour.

The other name deal this month: Lincoln Financial Group will pay $139.6 million over 20 years to name the NFL's Philadelphia Eagles new stadium Lincoln Financial Field.

  • Squeeze play. While Major League Baseball's 2002 season is threatened by a labor dispute, Tim Brosnan, executive vice president, says that in "frank conversations" with MLB's 18 sponsors, "not a single one" has threatened to pull out of their deals.

    • In fact, MLB sponsors such as MasterCard plan to spend an estimated $250 million in marketing through the World Series (if there is one) to tout their baseball connections. That's up 25% from last season, says Brosnan.

    MasterCard agency McCann-Erickson, New York, is running a baseball-theme ad campaign now showing two buddies on a summer road trip to visit all 30 MLB ballparks.

  • Strange bedfellows. Pro leagues have been able to cut marketing deals with companies beyond the typical sneaker/soda/beer complex. Toy company Lego signed a multiyear deal with the NBA that will allow the company to roll out a line this year called "Lego Sports." NBA Commissioner David Stern said the Lego deal shows "the interest in the NBA from global companies and powerful brands."

    • One threat for the Big Four pro sports, however: Ethan Green, vice president of London-based sponsorship consultant Redmandarin, says sponsors are testing shifting some spending into Gen Y "action sports" such as snowboarding and skateboarding.

title: NCAA-Coke Deal-Clip
body:
Coke Beats Pepsi for NCAA Rights
In a Deal That Tops $500 Million

Betsy McKay
June 12, 2002
Wall Street Journal

Score one for Coca-Cola Co. The beverage company struck a deal with Viacom Inc.'s CBS unit and the National Collegiate Athletic Association for sponsorship rights, in a win against PepsiCo Inc.

The 11-year agreement is valued at more than $500 million, three times what Pepsi was paying, and gives Coke the right to advertise and promote its brands during NCAA championships. The three partners said the deal is part of an overall plan by CBS and the NCAA to draw more attention to NCAA championships other than the men's basketball championship, with greater marketing and television coverage of women's basketball, hockey and other sports.

Coke will pay about $14 million in rights fees and advertising outside of CBS, and $22 million in media spending on CBS for the first year, with annual increases in each payment, according to a person close to the negotiations. The terms of the deal were reported by Sports Business Daily, a trade publication. Pepsi, which had been a sponsor since 1995, paid a $4 million rights fee and $9 million for media this year. The Purchase, N.Y., company submitted a $78 million bid for a three-year renewal.

Sean McManus, president of CBS Sports, said Coke had been chosen because of its "extremely aggressive" offer in rights fees and "extremely comprehensive" marketing program. "The NCAA was looking for a company that was going to make college athletics an important part of their plans on a 52-week basis."

The deal is something of a surprise because Coke walked away from the NCAA sponsorship in 1995, opening the door to Pepsi. But Chuck Fruit, Coke's senior vice president of Worldwide Media and Alliances, said "marketing rights were much more limited" in previous NCAA pacts.

The deal followed an initial meeting between Coke Chairman Douglas Daft and NCAA President Cedric Dempsey, and was aggressively pursued by Coke. The company earlier this year lost its sponsorship rights to the National Football League, the number one television sport, when Pepsi swooped in and offered a more lucrative package.

"We had a great relationship with the NCAA," said a Pepsi spokesman, Dave DeCecco. But he said Coke's pact is "an awfully expensive ticket to the big dance."
