title: SPORTS BUSINESS TIPS AND QUIPS FROM TEN DAYS ON THE ROAD
body:
Print This Story

SPORTS BUSINESS TIPS & QUIPS FROM TEN DAYS ON THE ROAD

Sorting through notes, quotes and e-mails after a road trip to Seattle and Jacksonville.

Seahawks CEO Tod Leiweke is one of the most well-respected and well-liked people in the business. He is kind, witty and down-to-earth. Just how down-to-earth? When he became CEO in 2003, he purchased season tickets just like a regular fan, buying two seats in the team’s steep Hawks Nest at Qwest Field. Leiweke said at the National Sports Forum that he sat in those seats with his brother, AEG President Tim Leiweke, during the team’s home playoff loss to the Rams. “It was game time and Tim said, ‘Where are our seats?’ Tod said, laughing. “I pointed to the Nest and said, ‘Up there.’ I was the only one in the section with a coat and tie on and I actually ended up breaking up a fight.”

Tod Leiweke

Sharing his philosophy on team leadership and customer service, Leiweke said, “All of our fans invest money. They invest time. Both money and time are important, but the most important thing they invest is emotion. We are in the service business and we must respect the fans when they are giving us their hard-earned money.” Leiweke said his group has “really paid attention to the back of the house. Especially fans who are part-time workers that help make the experience at the stadium a better one for our fans. We tried to do some little things that may have been overlooked before. We got them bottled water when they came to work, we got them coat hooks so they could hang up their coats when they came in. It may not seem like much, but that’s important to treat these people right.” One other refreshing philosophy is the importance of working together and learning from each other in the sports world: “The sports industry is a small industry,” Leiweke said. “Too often we try to compete when we could partner and learn from each other.”

Leiweke noted how ticketing technology is benefiting teams and noted his surprise at the more than 20,000 tickets that were printed at home for the team’s playoff game – for which the team had less than a week to sell out the building to ensure it would not be blacked out.

Qwest Field

The Seahawks earlier this month hosted attendees of the National Sports Forum at Qwest Field, which is a real jewel of a building. It has wonderful design elements, sight lines and stunning visuals of downtown Seattle. Of the 111 total suites in the building, the team added 27 in time for the 2004 season – one of which is the new “Touchdown Suite,” which features a sports bar theme and is one of the lower-end suite products that the team introduced. The cost to lease the suite last year, which holds up to 40 people, was $9,000-12,000 per game, with each person receiving a game ticket and food. The suite was so successful that the Seahawks are re-evaluating the pricing, but has not determined pricing for 2005.

The team also has developed the Mike McCormack Boardroom, named after the franchise’s first GM. The boardroom holds up to 40 and is a venue that is invitation-only for corporate sales group. The room, which includes a football-shaped table in the middle with real pigskin, is used for meetings during the week and is marketed to the team’s corporate partners.

The team’s large retail store that is located in the expansive open concourse on the street level does anywhere between $70,000-135,000 in retail sales per game. The team also has six kiosks and 13 permanent retail locations in the stadium.

After a tour of the facility, Aramark hosted an elaborate evening in the club level that was overseen by the facility’s executive chef, Justin Blair. The Aramark chiefs outdid themselves with a extensive menu, as attendees dined on such specialties as achiote scallop quesadilla; rock prawn ceviche with lime and cilantro; a confit of duck on wonton crop with arugula and edamame and potato buckwheat blini with dill crème fraiche and charred mandarin orange. A cold buffet included imported cheeses, featuring quillisascut goat cheese, smoked tillamook cheddar, rogue valley blue and tomato boursin with cranberry chutney accompanied by figs and kiwi grapes. The seafood display presented in a marble ice well with seaweed and wheat grass included lobster, prawns, Queen Charlotte dungeness crab, smoked scallops and mussels. A salmon display included smoked and BBQ salmon and wild coho salmon gravlax. A sushi and maki display featured prawns, ahi tuna salmon, with pickled ginger, wasabi and soy sauce. The hot food included pan seared halibut cheeks with jackfruit and tangerine glaze, and the carving stations included crusted rack of lamb in a port reduction, a lolla rossa salad with gorgonzola, roasted red pepper and white truffle balsamic vinaigrette, along with a pancetta wrapped venison tenderloin and thai red curry prawns. Everything was excellent -- my compliments to the chefs.

Chuck Armstrong

Also in Seattle, the affable Chuck Armstrong, who is president of the Mariners, spoke to attendees of the National Sports Forum after concessionaire Centerplate provided a lunch of fresh sushi, shrimp, seafood salad, crab legs, as well as a full pasta bar, prime rib and a highlight of banana foster for dessert. Armstrong, who oversaw the opening of Safeco Field in 1999, said of the six-year old ballpark, “We’ve done fan surveys and people come just for Safeco Field. It’s worked out better than anyone would have thought. I treat her like my fourth child. I think she is feminine.”

The Mariners ranked anywhere from 16 to 18 in total MLB team revenue when they played at the Kingdome, but the franchise is now in the top five.

The Mariners have also done some retrofitting at the suite level. The team took a portion of their press box on the third base side and turned it into their “Press Box Suite.” The suite is priced anywhere from $5,800-$9,000 per game, depending on the date and opponent. The ticket itself is equivalent to a $50 box seat. However, the cost involves much more than the purchase of the 18 tickets, as patrons can divide the full suite cost by the 18 people, which would include parking, food, beverage and the pre-game tour. But the ticket itself is $50.

The Mariners’ 372-seat Diamond Club is title sponsored by XO Communications. The Diamond Club has a waiting list and seats don’t turn often. Only two seats turned this year and both went to title sponsor XO.

Howard Schultz

Still in Seattle: You can see Sonics owner Howard Schultz meet with season-ticket holders before the game at the team’s club level at KeyArena. He is very visible during the game, sitting courtside at center court. The day after a tough 103-84 loss to the San Antonio Spurs, Schultz said, “One of the things I have had trouble with in pro sports ownership is how personal you take this.”

One of the dilemmas facing Schultz is the marketing of the league. “How do you market the NBA and who do you market it to?” he asked. “I have a hard time sometimes. I mean the guy having the best year in the NBA arguably is Steve Nash, but you don’t see his face anywhere in terms of how the NBA is marketed. Why not? The best story of the NBA is Grant Hill. Why aren’t we marketing Grant Hill? He’s a unbelievable story and he’s an unbelievable person. But we have other players who are the marquee names because they sell sneakers. I don’t get it.”

Looking ahead to the CBA talks with the NBPA, Schultz said, “The players, I don’t believe, believe that most NBA owners are losing money. They go, ‘How could you afford to sign that player?’ to ‘Look at the franchise value appreciation,’ and point to Boston. We are on a collision course with time if the economic model does not fit more equitable for both the owners and the players. At the same time, you’re in league meetings sometime when other owners say that and then a week later you read in paper where they have given marginal players $100 million dollars and you just shake your head. So it’s a weird situation, it’s very perverse sometimes, because the owners are your partners and competitors and not everyone has the same mindset.”

The founder of Starbucks also talked about brand building. Schultz: “I think in the last twenty to twenty five years, the thing that I have learned is the equity of building a brand today is extremely costly. It is much more expensive to build a brand and market a product today than ever before. And what I have learned is that there are significant enduring values to building it internally first. To set out with a culture, a mission statement, a set of values and guiding principles that are not just a piece of paper, but that really do matter. And whether you are marketing coffee or a basketball team, they have to be tied to everything you do.” He went on to say, “I think there are three guiding principles that are important to me. One, you have to build an emotional connection to the customer, a connection that is authentic, that is true, that is not based on marketing but is instead based on who you are, what you do, and what you are committed to. Second, you have to build trust with every constituency that exists within your enterprise and every constituency that you touch. And third, probably more so in sports than anything else is, you have to build hope. The fan base -- the customers -- have to have hope that what you are doing gives them hope that you’re going to succeed.”

What are the three brands that Schultz admires most and why? “Apple was just voted the number one brand in the world and I think it’s tough to argue with the impact that they have had,” he said. “What really intrigues me about Apple is that it has transformed and changed their company from a PC manufacturer to an unbelievably innovative company around music and entertainment, and who knows what else they will do. I think Nike has done an incredible job over a long period of time of standing for something important. I love the retail company IKEA, it’s all over the world.”

Michael Robichaud

If you’re not using the product of the company you’re pitching to, you better start. Nextel senior director of sports marketing Michael Robichaud said at the National Sports Forum: “I can’t stress enough about using our product. I find it just incomprehensible how people [we have deals with] would not use our product. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve had the conversation where, ‘If people buy our product, we will get money for it and give it to you [the property], so why would you go and do business with our competitor and expect us to renew?’ That is still something we struggle with.” IMG senior vice president of corporate consulting David Abrutyn, who advises DHL on sports sponsorships, agreed: “I’m amazed how many people send a proposal wanting the business of DHL and send it using UPS or FedEx. When the client asks, ‘How did this proposal come?’ you have to be honest with them and say, ‘Well, it came in brown.’ It seems really basic and that you wouldn¹t have to make that comment in today¹s environment.”

Siemens Canada Senior Vice President of Communications & Government Affairs Steve Jones, when talking about the exposure his company has received from their sports sponsorships of pro teams in Canada: “After the Todd Bertuzzi fight (in March, 2004), the next day he was on the front page on every single newspaper across Canada, and he’s pummeling this guy right in front of the Siemens sign. It was great. There is nothing like sports branding.”

Heard Around…

One NBA team president, on how he approaches ticket sales: “I worry about the people who like our game. I can’t focus on getting new fans who are not interested in our product. I need to focus on those that have tried our game and like it. I need to get them to more games and to get them to upgrade their packages, from three games to five games to 12 games. That has to be our emphasis, not on trying to recruit people that aren¹t favorably predisposed to our product.”

David Stern

It was striking listening to top-level team executives talk about the differences between NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and NBA Commissioner David Stern. The NFL exec said, “The difference is that Paul Tagliabue focuses on three things: labor peace, television and managing his owners, and that’s great. But he has no idea who the marketing people at the team level are. Now David Stern focuses all on those key league issues, but he knows all his team people, and he knows them by name.” The NBA team president chimed in at the same time, “David knows their names, how they are doing and what they are not doing well enough!”

In a discussion with team and league executives, the question came up of what could be done to improve the image of NBA players. One suggestion was to pay the players extra money to do more community work and remain in their community during the off-season. That drew a laugh from former NBA team executive and current Mandalay Baseball Pro Teams President Jon Spoelstra, who said, “Speaking as someone from Portland, we’re looking at all possible ways of getting the players OUT of the city during the offseason.”

One NBA team president on David Stern: “He is the best listener I’ve ever known. That’s David¹s strength. He’s also such an intuitive marketer. You¹re in a meeting with him and discussing some pretty complex marketing and sales topics, and he will be looking out the window when you’re talking to him and you can see him just compress all this information you are feeding him and you know he gets it.”

In-game presentation continues to be a key topic in NBA circles. Ask three NBA league executives who does the best job and you get Mavericks, Kings, Heat, Bulls, Grizzlies and Rockets. One executive said, “They have good people who focus on it and really spend on it.”

Tales From “The Longest Yard”…

Paramount Pictures held a media briefing (and free lunch, of course) to promote the Memorial Day release of “The Longest Yard,” a remake of the 1974 classic. The new iteration stars Adam Sandler, Chris Rock and Burt Reynolds and features Michael Irvin and Bill Romanowski. Sandler received football training from ESPN’s Sean Salisbury, and Irvin commented about the QB performance of Sandler, “He threw some good throws, and I would tell him, ‘If you threw that pass, you DID NOT learn from Sean Salisbury!” Reebok manufactured the uniforms in the film. Rock speculated on what football movie he and Sandler would do for a remake next, “We are doing ‘Brian’s Song’ after this.” More Rock, when asked how he was holding up with no hockey, “All of Harlem is in tears right now. I just remember our pick up hockey games. It was a magical time.”

Abraham Madkour is Executive Editor of The Sports Business Daily and SportsBusiness Journal. You can reach him at abem@sportsbusinessdaily.com.

title: Archive FAQ
body:
Archive FAQ's

1.

What are the basic keyword search tips?
2.
 How does the search system work?
3.
 How do I print a story from the archives?
4.
 How do I access a complete past issue of The Sports Business Daily?
5.
How do I use the calendar search?
6.
Can I generate a combined search using any of the fields (such as team, sport, etc.)?
7.
 What is the user agreement for reprinting stories from The Sports Business Daily or The Sports Business Daily Insider?
8.

Where do I direct questions on how to use the archives?


1. What are the basic keyword search tips?

To search, you can enter a word or words in the keyword box and use either any word, all words or whole phrase to refine your search.

The whole phrase search method looks for the exact phrase you type into the search box.
 
An all words query will return results containing at least one occurrence of every single one of the keywords or phrases you enter.
 
An any word query will return results containing at least one occurrence of at least one of the keywords or quote phrases you enter. This is the least specific type of search.

Keywords should include words that you feel are vital to the story that you want from our database. The keywords could appear either in the story headline, text or source credit. The search system is not case sensitive. Entering "Nike" will search for "Nike", "nike", and "NIKE".

Refine your search further by selecting to search a particular section of or either:

- The Sports Business Daily or The Daily Insider
- The Sports Business Daily
- The Daily Insider

In addition, you can specify a sport, company or team to search by, and the time period in which the article was published. You can select a specific category by checking or unchecking with the CTRL key.

RETURN TO TOP


2. How does the search system work?

The default action of the Advanced Search page is Any Word. This is not a boolean search, so the system will search for words like "AND", "OR", "NOT" that are put in the search string.

EXAMPLE: If a user puts in the search term, "Cowboys not stadium", the system would offer the following results:

 ALL WORDS: Matches any articles containing some form of "Cowboys", "not", and "stadium". The words may not be near one another or in any order, the only criteria is that all three words (in some form, even as parts of other words) must be in an article, to result in a match.
 
ANY WORD: Matches any articles containing any or all (but at least one) of some form of "Cowboys", "not", or "stadium".
 
WHOLE PHRASE: Matches any articles containing the entire phrase as it is typed (spaces are counted also) in a case insensitive manner. "Cowboys not stadium" will match "Cowboys not stadium", "COWBOYS NOT STADIUM" or "cowboys not stadium".

SEARCH BY TOPIC:

Items appearing in The Sports Business Daily from January 2001 to the current issue have been categorized by certain industry subjects.

*NOTE: Issues from 1994 through 2000 are not searchable using the topic categories. Please use the keyword search for best results.

SEARCH RESULTS:

Search results will list feature articles with a number, the story headline, a few pertinent sentences of the story, section of the publication, and issue date and publication the item appeared in. Additionally, the word or words you searched for will be highlighted in yellow.

EXAMPLE:

Click on the headline to read the full story. The full text of these stories is only accessible to subscribers of The Sports Business Daily. You can register now for a free trial subscription. If you want full access to our archives, please complete your subscription by calling our sales department at (704) 973-1500.

By default:

 Articles are sorted by the most recent story first. You can change that function with the Sort By feature.
The first ten articles of a search request are displayed on a page. However, a user can change that with the How Many Items Listed feature

RETURN TO TOP

3. How do I print a story from the archives?

If you wish to print the article after viewing the entire text, just click on the Print This Story feature on the lower right-hand side of the story.

RETURN TO TOP

4. How do I access a complete past issue of The Sports Business Daily?

If you are interested in getting a complete online issue of The Sports Business Daily for a specific date, use the Specific Issue Calendar box to select the year, month and day. This will provide all the headlines and stories posted to the online edition for that date.

RETURN TO TOP

5. How do I use the calendar search?

The calendar search is used when you are looking for an article within a particular time period. You will want to use either the From/To search or the Specific Issue Date search.

 When using either the From/To or the Specific Issue Date search, use the calendar icon to select your dates. *Note: If you type in the date, you may not receive the information you are looking for. Click on the calendar icon to choose your dates.


Use the arrows to find the date you are looking for.

  • Double arrow pointing back = 1 year back.
  • Single arrow pointing back = 1 month back.
  • Single arrow pointing forward = 1 month forward.
  • Double arrow pointing forward = 1 year forward.

RETURN TO TOP

6. Can I generate a combined search using any of the fields (such as team, sport,     etc.)?

The search function is an "OR" function not an "AND" function. The "OR" function means that if you search using a combination of the fields, your results will show AT LEAST one of the fields you searched under, but NOT necessarily all the fields you searched under.

EXAMPLE: You choose to search by sport (Golf), by company (Nike) and by topic (Legal). Your results may be:

1. Only one topic of the three will appear in each article result.
2. Two of the three topics will appear in each article result.
3. All three topics will appear in each article result.

RETURN TO TOP

7. What is the user agreement for reprinting stories from The Sports Business Daily or The Sports Business Daily Insider?

Articles taken from this database are for personal use only and may not be reprinted without the permission of the original source. If you have questions, please contact help@sportsbusinessdaily.com

RETURN TO TOP

8. Where do I direct questions on how to use the archives?

If you are a subscriber to The Sports Business Daily and are having problems in accessing our archives, e-mail help@sportsbusinessdaily.com or call 704-973-1500.

RETURN TO TOP

title: NBC Wins 2010 & 2012 Olympic TV Rights
body:
NBC WINS 2010 & 2012 OLYMPIC TV RIGHTS, GE BECOMES TOP SPONSOR

By Steve Woodward, Street & Smith’s SportsBusiness Journal, Special to The Daily

General Electric and its television networks, including NBC, MSNBC and CNBC, retained the U.S. rights to the Olympic Games on Friday with a landmark $2.201B winning bid that pays for broadcast rights and a newly created global sponsorship category.

GE/NBC, outbidding Disney (ABC/ESPN) and News Corp. (Fox), agreed to pay the IOC $820M for the rights to the 2010 Olympic Winter Games and $1.18B for rights to the 2012 Games, plus an additional $160M to $200M during an eight-year period to secure for GE a place among the 11 existing members of The Olympic Program (TOP) designating global sponsors.

The TOP sponsorship being tied to the TV rights is unprecedented. The agreement makes GE a global sponsor for 2005-2008 and 2009-2012, and marks a dramatic increase in that fee during a four-year period. Existing TOP sponsors for 2005-2008 are expected to pay $50M to $60M for global rights. "The TOP commitment made it a very compelling offer," said Richard Carrion, Chair of the IOC's finance commission, in a media conference call from Lausanne, Switzerland, site of the rights bidding Thursday and Friday. He said the actual rights category GE will own has yet to be determined because "we just received the offer a few hours ago," suggesting it was unexpected. The GE/NBC bid exceeds by 32.6% the $1.507B combined rights fee paid for the 2006 Winter Games in Turin, Italy, and 2008 Summer Games in Beijing. The massive financial commitment is in place even though the host city of the 2010 Games will not be decided until July 2, and the host of the 2012 Games, for which New York is a candidate, in 2005.

The USOC's 12.75% cut of the TV fee will be $255M in the 2009-2012 period.

As part of the multi-tiered deal, GE/NBC is committing $12M to broadcasts of U.S. Olympic Trials for both the Winter and Summer Games and $10M to the development of enhanced Olympic video archiving technology.

The Olympic Games are "the only thing that puts mom, pop and the kids in front of the TV at the same time," said NBC Sports and Olympics Chair Dick Ebersol. Ebersol added, "The Olympics are very good business for NBC."

title: Sports Industrialist Of The Year
body:
Nike Chair & CEO Phil Knight Awarded Executive Of The Year

By Terry Lefton, Editor-at-Large, The Sports Business Daily

Nike Founder, Chair
& CEO Phil Knight
The difficulty with The Sports Business Daily and our sister publication, SportsBusiness Journal, naming Nike Founder, Chair & CEO PHIL KNIGHT as our joint Executive of the Year is not that he is undeserving; it really is the antithesis. Having built the most ubiquitous trademark in sports and one of the most renowned global brands, one could justifiably ask: Why this year? Why not every year? The answer lies in Nike's remarkable endurance, singularity of purpose, and clearly defined mission — all of which allowed the world's largest sports company to emerge from a two-to three-year slump in the sneaker market with its market dominance intact and a clear path to future growth.

THE YEAR IN REVIEW: Coming off record annual and quarterly results, Nike shares, hovering around $63 at press time, were up more than 50% from the 52-week low of $41. (To be fair, it's a resurgent time for the industry, with Reebok recently posting its best quarterly results in six years.) Nike secured key foundations for future success with the addition of the Converse brand in July, buying retro cachet with another established brand and possibly entry into different channels of distribution. In addition, the company in May signed who could be the next decade's two most important endorsers: 18-year-old No. 1 NBA pick LEBRON JAMES and soccer wunderkind FREDDY ADU, then 13, who will likely be playing professionally before his 16th birthday. Adu is a naturalized U.S. citizen who turns 15 in June. Nike complemented those signings with the addition of CARMELO ANTHONY, the No. 3 pick in the NBA draft, and Lakers star KOBE BRYANT, although the sexual assault charges facing Bryant since July have rendered him useless as an endorser. Nike continued to build upon its soccer credentials, second only to worldwide leader adidas, and separate itself from numerous specialty brands, and moved toward a reconciliation with Foot Locker, America's biggest shoe retailer, after a yearlong skirmish over distribution.

Nike’s Advertising Continues Success

FASHION & ADVERTISING ALSO KEY: Progress was made in other areas of business. While Nike veterans have never been totally comfortable with the company's apparel line — even Knight admits, "I still struggle with the 'f' [fashion] word" — others at the company's Beaverton, OR, headquarters are gradually becoming more bullish on the category. Apparel now represents about 33% of Nike's total revenue, and observers believe that side of the business is being run more efficiently and effectively since it is no longer treated as an accessory to footwear. And when it comes to advertising, Nike again proved to have few equals, as Knight in June became the first marketer to repeat as "Advertiser of the Year" at the Cannes International Advertising Festival.

POISED FOR GROWTH: Not a bad year, and considering how well-positioned the company is for the future, it is not difficult to assert that sport's most influential company has become even more important over the past 12 months. "Nike has weathered a storm that hit every athletic footwear and apparel manufacturer and seemingly come out stronger," said NBA Commissioner DAVID STERN, "They've reasserted themselves on the endorsement front, continued to grow their soccer position to the point where they are a real global factor and made appropriate responses to the questions there were about their labor conditions." Said JOHN SHANLEY of Wells Fargo Securities: "They are still looking for growth in the U.S., as is the rest of the industry, but they've had some nice hits with products like Shox and Air Force One and they've already seen a nice lift from the LeBron shoe, which should sell out. At retail, their better relationship with Foot Locker has picked up the stocks of both companies and it should really help Nike in the spring selling season. The biggest concerns I see are a slowdown in athletic product demand in Europe, but their Asian business has really improved and there's still a lot of opportunity there."

CHALLENGES REMAIN, OF COURSE: There are challenges facing the eager Beavertons. Nike's domestic sales continue to lag, along with the rest of the industry, and technology issues at Nike Golf have been well-documented. But Knight remains bullish on the division, and points to Nike Golf's increased share in the ball category, where it now ranks as the fourth-largest brand after sales growth of almost 10% in early '03. While he feels the golf division is unquestionably gaining market share, he also points to the acquisitions of Converse and Hurley as the businesses with the most domestic growth potential, since they are expected to gain incremental U.S. distribution for Nike products.

"THEY DON'T NEED MY MEDDLING": Now 65, Knight continues to be the inspiration behind the brand and the culture at the company he founded. In a corporate structure typically atypical, he exists within a group headed by two presidents, CHARLIE DENSON and MARK PARKER. That leaves him free to be "selectively hands on" in terms of his management style. "They don't need a lot of my meddling," insisted Knight during a recent interview.

Knight, Nike Made A Big
Splash With Signing Of LeBron

LEBRON: Insiders will tell you that one thing Knight "meddled" in a lot over the past year was Nike's biggest PR splash of '03, the signing of James to a seven-year endorsement deal worth $90M. Knight's emphasis on signing James was similar to when he successfully lobbied to sign MICHAEL JORDAN 19 years earlier, when many within Nike's headquarters were touting the attributes of Univ. of Kentucky C SAM BOWIE, who was infamously chosen one pick before Jordan in the '84 NBA Draft. "Believe me, that number got so big, the [James] deal doesn't get signed without my endorsement and I was enthusiastic about him from the very beginning," said Knight, hours after jetting back from Cleveland to witness James' home debut. "He's probably the best 18-year-old basketball player that has ever lived. The question is, 'Will he be the best 25-year-old basketball player that ever lived?' You pay your money and take your chances, but endorsement-wise, he is the whole package."

WHATEVER IT TOOK: adidas and Reebok were in a frenzied competition with Nike to sign James, but it seemed that Nike had no ceiling on what it would pay to obtain him, lest he turn out to be the next Jordan. "Phil told me he had an unlimited budget and planned to exceed it," said a principal at one of the nation's biggest sports marketing firms. Knight maintained, however, "there was a price we wouldn't go beyond." As for the economics of the whole deal? "The early reads on interest in his shoe [the Air Zoom Generation, due at retail on Dec. 20] and the sale of [James] apparel already shows us what we thought all along," Knight said. "We're going to make money on this deal."

FOOT LOCKER DISPUTE: One simmering issue over the past year has been the dispute between Nike and Foot Locker, its biggest retailer with 1,450 U.S. stores. In response to reduced orders from Foot Locker, Nike scaled back or eliminated shipments of its marquee shoes. But Knight confirmed reports that that feud has ebbed, if not ended, and in recent SEC filings, both Foot Locker and Nike said the chain had increased its U.S. orders. So is there an armistice? "Basically, that's correct," Knight said, "but I think the 'war' with Foot Locker was a little overblown, so now the word 'peace' is maybe a little overblown as well." Foot Locker officials would not elaborate on their relations with Nike beyond their most recent SEC filing stating the increase in orders. But while the chain is now on track to receive future high-end products, it won't be getting the initial shipment of the LeBron James shoes, which will debut at competing chains, including Finish Line, Athlete's Foot and Footaction. It is unclear whether Foot Locker will receive subsequent releases of the line.

Knight Still Willing To Throw The Hail Mary

THE CULTURE CLUB: Those who know him well say the culture Knight has instilled over the past 30 years is what keeps Nike vibrant. Thus, a brand as ubiquitous as any in the U.S. can remain as edgy as a start-up, both in products and marketing. "Normally, when you get to companies of this size, everybody is looking for certainty, if only because of how much their shares are worth," said DAN WIEDEN, chief creative officer and CEO of Portland-based Wieden & Kennedy, the agency that has been producing Nike's arresting advertising for the past 22 years. "[Knight] is sitting at the head of a $10[B] company built from the trunk of his car, but to this day his passion for sports has not waned and neither has his willingness to take risk. With as much success as Nike's had, he's still not averse to throwing a Hail Mary."

PERSONALITY-DRIVEN: Those are admirable qualities for any leader, particularly one Forbes ranks as the 31st-richest American, with a fortune estimated at $5.8B. The question is how inseparable is Knight from the brand and its culture? "Our culture has everything to do with our success, but it is by no means only my doing," Knight said. "Nike is young and irreverent and I am neither." Many who have worked for Knight dispute that assertion. "You can't really separate the brand of Nike from the person of Phil Knight," said College Sports Television co-Founder and Exec VP CHRIS BEVILACQUA, who left the job of Nike Dir of Global Negotiations in '99. TOM FOX, Gatorade VP/Sports & Event Marketing and a former Nike Dir of U.S. Sports Marketing, said the relationship Knight holds with the company he founded is similar to the connection former Univ. of Oregon track and field coach and Nike co-Founder BILL BOWERMAN had with Knight. "The Nike mentality is an athlete's culture," Fox said. "That's one reason there's lots of athletes and ex-athletes working there. Risk-taking is encouraged, and finding the story of an athlete before the hype kicks in is almost second nature." Adds LIZ DOLAN, a former VP/Global Marketing at Nike who was at the company from '88-97, "Phil is so relentlessly competitive that you can't help but absorb it." IMG co-CEO BOB KAIN recalls the time he called Knight to advise him that ANDRE AGASSI was going to drop the swoosh for a competitor's offer. "Andre's heart wasn't in it," Kain told Knight. That was enough to stoke Knight's competitive fires. "I may not have his heart, but I will not lose his feet," Knight told Kain, subsequently signing Agassi to a 10-year extension that is still in effect.

ADJUST YOUR SPEED: Two stories are told when colleagues are asked to recollect what Knight was most often heard saying around Nike's 175-acre Beaverton campus. One is a Knight dictum: "A good company isn't good at one thing, it is good at 17 things." No one seems to know why the number was 17, but little matter. The other is a tale that may be more mythical in nature. It involves Knight, when he was a long-distance runner at Oregon, seeking counsel from coach and confidant Bowerman on how he could improve his performance. Bowerman's answer, so legend goes, was that Knight simply had to adjust his speed — and run somewhere between two or three times faster, depending on who is telling the story. This is seen as a window on Knight's management style: focus on the finish line and the goals, and rarely allow his charges to lose their way. "People that work at Nike understand that no matter how big the company gets, the mission is to serve the athlete," said Rick White, who was GM of Nike's subsidiary brands from '97-99. "He is not likely to tell you exactly how to do something," recalled Dolan, now host and producer of "Satellite Sisters," an ABC Radio Networks radio talk show heard weekly in 72 U.S. markets, "but he constantly reminds you of the goal, and that's to win."

WIN OR ELSE: Bevilacqua was reluctant to provide specific details on some of the high-profile athlete and league deals he engineered during his five years at Nike. But he recalls learning from Knight that whichever side has time on its side has a pronounced advantage. He also remembers advice from Knight during some very protected deals. "He made it clear that if you didn't get it done, you shouldn't come home," Bevilacqua said.

Click Here To View Clip

THE IMAGERY: Together, Nike and Wieden & Kennedy have crafted some of the most memorable advertising of the past 20 years, cementing Nike's reputation as a brand that either knows the intersection of sports and pop culture better than any other, or perhaps actually creates it. The legacy is one in which ad phrases become embedded in everyday life, with "Just Do It," "Bo Knows" and "It Must Be the Shoes" common refrains. SPIKE LEE's treatment of Michael Jordan and his animated interactions with the Looney Tunes characters spawned the film "Space Jam." There are other indelible images from Nike campaigns — including PETE SAMPRAS and Andre Agassi playing tennis in the streets of Manhattan, or the Brit streaking a soccer pitch, garbed only in a scarf and his Nike Shox that was a critical hit in '03. "If you want to have a hall of shame and show some bad ads, we might win that one, too," Knight said with a laugh, "but we do actually work hard at taking risks."

UNSCRIPTED: Knight has come a long way from the man who told Wieden, when they first met, "I hate advertising." Now he sits as the only two-time advertiser of the year winner at Cannes. "He used to think there could be no better advertising than having an athlete wearing Nike shoes on the cover of Sports Illustrated," Wieden said. The strategy remains unscripted. "There has never been a search for a formula. From the beginning, what was exciting was that nothing was off limits. It was always, 'What you did yesterday was great, but for tomorrow I want to see something new and different.' That's also what's made them great designers." The best advertising injects emotion into consumer categories where it really doesn't exist. The Nike/W&K combination never had the dilemma of a boring category because sports connects with all aspects of the human condition on a daily basis. Still, they've exploited it for marketing purposes like no one before or since. "What you learn at Nike is the connection between athlete, brand and consumer," said Professional Bowlers Association Commissioner FRED SCHREYER, Dir of Sports Marketing at Nike from '87-93 and founder of the now defunct Nike Sports Management division in 1992. "That's how Nike can be everywhere and still stay 'cool.'"

Chatting With Lance On The Mountain
In ’00 The Best Day Of Knight’s Life

A SPORTS JUNKIE: For all the mysticism ascribed to Knight, those who have worked with him say he is easier to understand than most people think. He's just a sports junkie who happened to translate and amplify his passion into athletic shoes. Sure, signing James, Anthony and Adu were nice coups in '03. His time with MJ is memorable. But he still tells confidants that the best day of his life was in July '00 when he chatted with LANCE ARMSTRONG from Armstrong's coach's car while the five-time winner was traversing the mountain stage of the Tour de France, followed by a quick helicopter ride over to Scotland to witness TIGER WOODS win the British Open at St. Andrews. "I'll see Phil at the [Nike] cafeteria and he doesn't want to talk about the new deal we're negotiating," said TOM ROSS, who runs Octagon's men's tennis business, which includes high-profile Nike endorser LLEYTON HEWITT, "but he'll talk about Pac-10 football with me for 20 minutes." "He's the world's ultimate sports fan," Dolan said. "Because he's so passionate about sports, he intuitively understands who's out there as an endorser that the public will be passionate about." The love of sport and the lessons learned in athletic competition are part of the foundation supporting Nike. The Nike culture is the rest — and Knight and Nike deserve kudos for maintaining that strength while growing to more than 23,000 employees. "In terms of running a business that big, to be able to have all those employees on the same page is remarkable," Schreyer said. "It has always been very clear what Nike's brand stands for — the athlete — and that's what separates them."

PASSION: Wieden compares Knight's infatuation with sports to his own obsession with advertising. Each man's passion is so genuine that the creative work, and the shoes, are built on instincts honed to near perfection. Accordingly, the odds are long that Knight will ever retire; nor will Wieden ever sell out to one of the holding companies that control much of the agency business. "Look at the heads of all the agency conglomerates — none of those guys actually have anything to do with advertising; they have no love of the craft, they are strictly balance-sheet guys," Wieden said. "Phil is still deeply involved in sports and it shows in everything Nike does."

title: Staff Openings
body: Street & Smith's SportsBusiness Journal has an immediate opening for a staff writer, covering a variety of sports business beats. Candidates will be asked to file both breaking news stories and analysis pieces while competing in a national marketplace. Adherence to deadlines, both daily and weekly, is expected. Ability to advance stories and incorporate art and research into news writing is important. The job, based in Charlotte, NC, requires some travel. At least two to five years of business reporting is requested. If interested, please send resume and salary requirements to jobs@sportsbusinessjournal.com.

title: Street & Smith's Sports Group Upcoming Events
body:
Sports Sponsorship Symposium
September 27-28
New York City
With its debut in 2003, the Sports Sponsorship Symposium has already become the "must-attend" event for executives at every segment of the sports sponsorship mix. In two years, the program has built a reputation for providing a combination of open-dialogue discussion and in-depth case studies from some of the industry's top sponsors and advertisers.

Sports & Social Responsibility
October 18-19
New York City
On October 18 and 19, Street & Smith's SportsBusiness Journal and SportsBusiness Daily will host the inaugural executive forum on Sports & Social Responsibility. This unprecedented event will bring together leaders from the sports industry, academia and government to discuss and debate theintersection between sports and society. Topics such as the role of the athlete in today's society, the influence of the media on the image of athletes, the challenge and threat of performance enhacing drugs and teach the values of sport through youth programs will be among the many topics discussed.

PLAYERS INC/Street & Smith's Sports Media & Technology
November 15-16
New York City
This conference gathers the executives who are shaping the future of sports media. Issues discussed include new technology, revenue models, audience measurement and the integration of media into the fan base. Featured speakers come from every area of this industry including properties, sponsors, media, agencies, technology providers and marketing.

Motorsports Marketing Forum
November 29-30
New York City
The prime gathering of the sponsorship community in motorsports, this Forum is the platform for sponsors, league officials, teams, track owners and ad agencies to present their ideas on sponsorship, the future of racing and the driver-fan relationship. With featured speakers from sanctioning bodies, the media, team management and sponsors, this Forum has become an indispensable stop on the motorsports circuit for the past five years.

Intercollegiate Athletics Forum
December 7-8
New York City
This program brings together athletic directors, university presidents, media and sponsors to discuss the issues surrounding present-day college sports. With speakers from the ranks of academia, marketing firms, media and corporate sponsors, this event is the one time of year when these constituencies can discuss their mutual issues and opportunities.

Forty Under 40
March 29, 2006
New York City
The SportsBusiness Journal Forty Under 40 Awards program was initiated in 1999 to identify and honor the most promising young executives in sports business under the age of 40. Candidates are nominated from all areas of sports business – teams, leagues, media, marketing, advertising, sponsorship, law, finance, construction and design … just to name a few. A committee of SportsBusiness Journal editors and writers select the forty executives from among hundreds of nominations received each year. Winners will be announced in our March 20, 2006, issue and will be honored at our Forty Under 40 Awards Banquet on Wednesday, March 29 at The Pierre Hotel in New York City.

Concluded Events

Sports Facilities and Franchises Forum
May 16-18
Philadelphia, PA
The one conference each year where the varied interests in sports facility development, design, operations and revenue generation can meet to discuss issues and present new ideas regarding the successful development and operations of sports facilities.

Octagon/Street & Smith's Sports Group World Congress of Sports
March 8-9
New York City, NY
In 2005 the World Congress of Sports will return to The Waldorf-Astoria in New York City. And on the evening of March 9th, Street & Smith's Sports Group will be hosting its annual Forty Under 40 awards banquet, making it convenient for you to attend the two most celebrated events on the business of sports.

2004 Octagon/Street & Smith's Sports Group World Congress of Sports
March 3-4
Newport Beach, CA
A recap of the 2004 Octagon/Street & Smiths' Sports Group World Congress of Sports, including video, slideshow and more.

Canada Sports Forum
September 8-9
Toronto, ON
Following a highly successful inaugural conference in '03, the Canada Sports Forum will attract the biggest names in the country's sports industry to a two-day, broad-ranging program on the challenges and opportunities for Canadian-based sports businesses.

Sports Media & Technology
November 9-10
New York City
This conference gathers the executives who are shaping the future of sports media. Issues discussed include new technology, revenue models, audience measurement and the integration of media into the fan base. Featured speakers come from every area of this industry including properties, sponsors, media, agencies, technology providers and marketing.

title: 2008 MediaKit - Technical Specs
body:
Online Marketing Introduction
Audience Information
Rate Card
Technical Specs
Testimonials
Technical Specs

All creative must include a click url and/or click instructions. All Flash files must be in a compressed or zip format to be e-mailed.

ACCEPTED STANDARD CREATIVE TYPES
Online: GIF, JPEG, Flash (up to 30 seconds), Dynamic HTML, HTML Banners, Image map, Dart tags
Email Alerts: GIF or JPG (NO FLASH)
Third Party Served Ads: We reserve the right to pull third party served ads that are not rendering or are rendering slowly.

AD FORMAT/CREATIVE TYPES

  • No deceptive creative tactics. These include ads simulating computer system warning dialog boxes that lead the viewer to believe their computer, our server or the system is experiencing technical difficulties or that they need to click on the box (ad) to eliminate the message from their screen.
  • If third party served, Flash creative must sniff for the plug-in, and if not present, serve a gif.
  • Ads must not modify any elements of a user’s browser or computer settings.
  • Ads must not resemble SportsBusinessJournal.com or SportsBusinessDaily.com editorial content (exact or close replica).
  • Ads must not include references to SportsBusinessJournal.com or SportsBusinessDaily.com unless part of previously arranged co-promotions.

FLASH 6 REQUIREMENTS
Flash creatives must be delivered as .swf Flash Player files. Flash ads must include click Tag tracking that contains the following action script:

on (release){if (clickTAG.substr(0,5) == “http:”)
{getURL(clickTAG, “_parent”);}}

For further instructions, please go to: http://www.adobe.com/resources/richmedia/tracking/

GENERAL GUIDELINES

  • Size: Ads should be no larger than 40k.
  • Border: If ads are on a white background, they must include a black, encasing one pixel rule.
  • Duration: 30 seconds.
  • Rotation: Site-served ads must have no more than 5 creatives per ad size, per order.\
  • Alternate Gif: Animated GIFs must be provided for all Flash creatives.
  • Alternate Text: Cannot exceed 50 characters.
  • Sound: The use of audio streams must be initiated by click only. If deemed too distracting, SportsBusinessJournal.com or SportsBusinessDaily.com reserves the right to ask that the advertiser remove them.
  • Third Party Serving: SportsBusinessJournal.com or SportsBusinessDaily.com allows third party serving of creative within IFrametags. fourth party serving of creative is not allowed.
  • Testing: Creative must be delivered 48 hours prior to launch for testing and Q&A. All creative must function uniformly on both Mac and PC platforms, as well as multiple browser versions of Netscape and Internet Explorer. Any units not conforming to all outlined specifications will not be placed online and will result in delayed start dates.

For sales inquiries, contact Julie Tuttle
National Ad Director
212-500-0711 or jtuttle@amcity.com
